Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances, City of Nacogdoches, Texas" and may be so cited. 
(Code 1971, § 1-1) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to adopt a civil and criminal code of ordinances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 53.001 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances and resolutions passed by the city council, the following rules shall be observed and the following definitions shall apply, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Generally. The provisions of this Code shall be liberally construed to effect the purposes expressed therein or implied from the expression thereof. In case of doubt or ambiguity in the meaning of such provisions, the general shall yield to the particular. Reference for interpretation and construction shall tend to further the accomplishment of the elimination of the particular mischiefs for which the provisions were enacted. Words shall be construed in their common and usual significance unless the contrary is clearly indicated. 
    Charter. The term "Charter" shall mean the Charter of the City of Nacogdoches, Texas, as printed in part I of this volume. 
    City. The term "city" shall mean the City of Nacogdoches in the County of Nacogdoches and State of Texas. 
    City boards, committees, commissions, officers and departments. Whenever reference is made to boards, committees, commissions, officers or departments, it shall be construed as if followed by the phrase "of the City of Nacogdoches, Texas." Reference to such boards, committees, commissions, officers and departments shall be deemed to include authorized deputies, agents or representatives. 
    City council. The term "city council" shall mean the city council of the City of Nacogdoches. 
    Code. The term "Code" shall mean the Code of Ordinances, City of Nacogdoches, Texas, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Computation of time. In computing any period of time mentioned in this Code, the day of the act, event or default after which the designated period of time begins to run is not to be included, and the last day of the period so computed is to be included, unless it is a Sunday or a legal holiday, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is neither a Sunday nor a holiday. 
    County. The term "county" shall mean the County of Nacogdoches, Texas. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision or section appears requiring a city officer or employee to do some act or make certain inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection, unless the terms of the provision or section designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships, associations and corporations, as well as to males. 
    Highway. The term "highway" shall include any street, alley, highway, avenue, public place or square, bridge, viaduct, tunnel, underpass, overpass or causeway in the city, dedicated or devoted to public use. 
    Joint authority. Words purporting to give authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it is otherwise declared. 
    Month. The term "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number shall include the plural, and any word importing the plural shall include the singular. 
    Oath. The term "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the terms "affirm" and "affirmed" shall be equivalent to the terms "swear" and "sworn." 
    Or, and. The term "or" may be read "and," and the term "and" may be read "or," if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The term "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The term "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, corporations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate, as well as to individuals. Where criminal prosecution may lie, the officers of any corporation shall jointly and severally be subject to prosecution as being included within the term "person." 
    Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The term "property" shall include both real and personal property. 
    Roadway. The term "roadway" shall mean that portion of a street improved, designed, or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic. 
    Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of the street between the curb, or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature or subscription. The term "signature" or "subscription" shall include a mark when a person cannot write. 
    Standard time. All hours of time mentioned in this Code refer to and shall be determined by Central Standard Time, or Central Daylight Saving Time, as the case may be. However, if at any future time any different standard of time is established by the state for an area which includes this city, all such hours shall be determined by such officially proclaimed standard, so long as the standard remains in effect. 
    State. The term "state" shall be construed to mean the State of Texas. 
    Street. The term "street" shall be construed to include any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, lane and viaduct in the city, dedicated and devoted to public use. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 541.302(5). 
    Tense. Words used in the present or past tense include the future, as well as the present or past. 
State Law reference- Tense, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 312.003(a). 
    Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. The abbreviation "Vernon's Ann. Civ. St." shall mean the latest edition or supplement to Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes. 
State Law reference- Statutory references, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 312.008. 
    V.T.C.A. The abbreviation "V.T.C.A." shall mean and refer to the latest edition or supplement of Vernon's Texas Code Annotated. 
State Law reference- Statutory references, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 312.008. 
    Written or in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by writing, printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The term "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
(Code 1971, § 1-2; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Charter reference- Rules of construction, art. VII, § 5 et seq. 
State Law reference- Construction of laws, definitions, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 311.001 et seq. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be the title of such section nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall it be so deemed when any section, including the catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(Code 1971, § 1-3) 
Sec. 1-4. - References to chapters, articles, divisions or sections. 
    All references in this Code to chapters, articles, divisions or sections are to the chapters, articles, divisions and sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. 
State Law reference- Construction of statutory references, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 311.027. 
Sec. 1-5. - History notes. 
    The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect, but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. 
Sec. 1-6. - References and editor's notes. 
    References and editor's notes following certain sections of this Code are inserted as an aid and guide to the reader and are not controlling or meant to have any legal effect. 
Sec. 1-7. - Continuation of existing ordinances. 
    The sections appearing in this Code, so far as they are the same as those of the Code of Ordinances, City of Nacogdoches, Texas, 1971, and of ordinances existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as a continuation thereof and not new enactments. 
Sec. 1-8. - Prior offenses, penalties and rights not affected by adoption of Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any city ordinance in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect or any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Code 1971, § 1-5) 
Sec. 1-10. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city. 
(2)  Granting any right or franchise. 
(3)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city. 
(4)  Making any appropriation or adopting the budget. 
(5)  Levying or imposing taxes not contained in this Code. 
(6)  Establishing or prescribing grades of streets in the city. 
(7)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor. 
(8)  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city. 
(9)  Extending or contracting the boundaries of the city. 
(10)  Prescribing the number, classification, benefits or compensation of any city officers or employees or any personnel policies and procedures and relating to the Texas Municipal Retirement System and federal old-age and survivors benefits. 
(11)  Approving or prescribing rates, charges and fees, including rates for garbage collection or for public utilities. 
(12)  Prescribing through streets, parking and traffic regulations, speed limits, one-way traffic, limitations on loads of vehicles or loading zones. 
(13)  Calling an election. 
(14)  Authorizing street maintenance agreements. 
(15)  Which is temporary although general in effect. 
(16)  Which is special although permanent in effect. 
(17)  The purpose of which has been accomplished. 
(b)  All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the city secretary's office. 
Sec. 1-11. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code of Ordinances may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. If chapters, sections and subsections or any parts thereof are repealed by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed, or omitted in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code by the city council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code shall be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Nacogdoches, Texas, is hereby amended to read as follows: ...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section not existing in the Code is to be added, the following language shall be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Nacogdoches, Texas is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered _______, which section reads as follows: ...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(d)  All sections, articles, chapters or provisions desired to be repealed must be specifically repealed by section, article or chapter number, as the case may be. 
(Code 1971, § 1-4; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 1-12. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is declared to be the intention of the city council that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared invalid or unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such invalidity or unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code, since the phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections would have been enacted by the city council without the incorporation in this Code of any such invalid or unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Code 1971, § 1-6; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 1-13. - Altering Code. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend, by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever except by ordinance or resolution or other official act of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 1-7) 
Sec. 1-14. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  Whenever in this Code or in any city ordinance an act is prohibited or is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor or whenever in this Code or city ordinance the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any such ordinance that governs or regulates fire safety, zoning or public health shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding $2,000.00. The violation of any other provision of this Code or any other ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00. No penalty shall be greater or less than the penalty provided for the same or a similar offense under state laws. 
(b)  Each day any violation of this Code or any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1971, § 1-8) 
Charter reference- Maximum penalty for violations, art. II, § 22[27]. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to prescribe penalties for violations of Code, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 54.001.

Footnotes:

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-91-2-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERSONNEL POLICIES 

Sec. 2-141. - Purpose and objectives. 
(a)  Purpose. The personnel policies in this division are designed to bring to the city service a high degree of understanding, cooperation, efficiency, and unity through systematic, uniform application of modern personnel practices. 
(b)  Objectives. The fundamental objectives of good personnel administration sought to be achieved by these policies are to: 
(1)  Promote and increase efficiency and economy in the service of the city. 
(2)  Provide fair and equal opportunity to all qualified applicants to enter and advance in city employment on the basis of merit and fitness as ascertained through fair and practical methods of selection and promotion, without regard to sex, race, color, religion, disability, age, national origin, or any other nonmerit factor. 
(3)  Maintain recruitment, advancement, and tenure practices enhancing the attractiveness of a city career and encourage each employee to give the employee's best effort to the job and the public. 
(4)  Maintain compensation based upon the relative duties and responsibilities of positions in the service of the city. 
(5)  Develop high morale among city employees by fostering good working relationships and by providing uniform personnel policies, opportunity for advancement, and consideration for employee welfare. 
(6)  Ensure that employees are protected against coercion for partisan political purposes and are prohibited from using their positions with the city for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the results of any kind of official election. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(a)) 
Sec. 2-142. - Applicability. 
    The personnel rules in this division apply to all city employees. An "employee" is any person appointed to a position in the city service. A person on retainer or under contract is not considered to be a city employee in the absence of a specific agreement to that effect. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(b)) 
Sec. 2-143. - No contract created. 
    The employee handbook is not a contractual agreement. Written applications for employment, statements concerning introductory status, as well as the personnel policies do not imply an agreement of contract between the employee and the city. The personnel policies are available in the personnel office for inspection and review by all city employees. Employment with the city may be terminated by the city at any time without liability for wages or salary except such as may have been earned at the date of termination. Employment with the city is for no definite period of time, and the city can change wages, benefits, and conditions at any time. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(c)) 
Sec. 2-144. - Dissemination. 
    All city employees will be informed of the existence of the personnel policies. All full-time employees will be provided a copy of the personnel policies and all amendments and revisions as they are adopted. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(d)) 
Sec. 2-145. - Amendments. 
(a)  The city council may unilaterally change, rescind, supplement, or supersede the personnel rules at any time without notice. 
(b)  The provisions of the personnel rules control over any contradictory statement made by any city supervisor. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(e); Ord. No. 1534-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-146. - Administration and division of responsibility. 
(a)  With the exception of matters reserved to the city council, the city manager may change or amend the personnel rules in this division within the law to the extent the city manager deems necessary in order to more effectively and efficiently promote the interest of the city and its employees. The director of personnel is authorized and directed to interpret, develop and implement necessary procedures and regulations for the efficient administration of these policies. 
(b)  Department heads and supervisory personnel are responsible for enforcing the provisions of these policies and for cooperating with the personnel department on all related matters pertinent to their organizational units. Department heads may adopt supplemental personnel policies, procedures and work rules not in conflict with these city-wide policies subject to the approval of the city manager or personnel director. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(f); Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-147. - Equal employment opportunity policy. 
    It is the employment policy of the city to obtain individuals qualified and/or trainable for positions in city service without discrimination based upon race, color, religion, national origin, sex, age, physical or mental disability, except when age, sex or physical requirements constitute a bona fide occupational qualification necessary for the proper and efficient fulfillment of the job. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(g)) 
Sec. 2-148. - Affirmative action policy. 
(a)  Purpose. In order to achieve equal employment opportunity with the city, a passive prohibition against discrimination is insufficient. An affirmative effort is required to create and preserve an environment conducive to equal employment opportunity. The city will perform those actions necessary to ensure that discrimination does not and will not exist within its jurisdiction. 
(b)  Scope. This policy refers without reservation to all recruitment, selection, and placement, training, promotions, benefits, transfers, layoffs, termination and any other matter affecting employees within the city. This policy will be administered to provide employees with the necessary opportunities for growth and advancement on the basis of individual merit, ability and capability. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(h)) 
Sec. 2-149. - Sexual harassment policy. 
(a)  Policy. It is the policy of the city that all employees are entitled to a work environment that is free from sexual intimidation and any unwelcome sexual advances. The city prohibits any form of sexual harassment as defined under title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. Any employee who engages in any conduct or action which constitutes sexual harassment is subject to disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
(b)  Purpose. The purpose of this policy is to define sexual harassment and to outline the responsibilities of supervisors and employees when this problem is encountered. 
(c)  Definition. Sexual harassment is defined as unwelcome sexual advances, requests for sexual favors, and other verbal and physical conduct of a sexual nature when: 
(1)  Submission to such conduct is made either explicitly or implicitly a term or condition of an individual's employment; 
(2)  Submission to or rejection of such conduct by an individual is used as the basis of employment decisions affecting such individual; or 
(3)  Such conduct has the purpose or effect of unreasonably interfering with an individual's work performance or creating an intimidating, hostile, or offensive working environment. 
(d)  Examples. In relation to the definition in subsection (c) of this section, such conduct includes but is not limited to the following: 
(1)  Repeated offensive sexual flirtations, advances, or propositions; 
(2)  Continued or repeated offensive verbal abuse of a sexual nature; 
(3)  The display of sexually suggestive objects or pictures; 
(4)  Any offensive or abusive physical conduct of a sexual nature. 
(e)  Procedures. Any employee who complains in good faith of sexual harassment will be protected against retaliation or reprisal for making the complaint. All allegations of sexual harassment shall be maintained in a separate filing system and shall not become a part of the employee files. 
(1)  Each supervisor is responsible for maintaining the supervisor's workplace free of sexual harassment. This duty includes discussing this policy and procedure with all employees and ensuring them that they are not required to endure insulting, degrading, or exploitative sexual treatment. 
(2)  Any employee who believes that the employee has been the subject of sexual harassment or who knows of such acts within the city's employment should report the alleged act immediately to the employee's supervisor. Should the immediate supervisor be the offending party in a harassment complaint, the employee may report to the next level of management or to the personnel department. 
(3)  Any sexual harassment observed or reported to a supervisor will be immediately investigated, and the result of the investigation will be reported through the chain of command to the department head. 
(4)  All activities and actions required to resolve sexual harassment complaints will be conducted by management in order to protect the rights of both complaining and offending parties. 
(5)  Disciplinary action shall be taken against any employee in violation of this policy. Such disciplinary action will be determined by the nature of the wrongful act and may result in dismissal. 
(6)  If the employee is not satisfied with the action taken by the supervisor, the employee may bring the complaint to the attention of the personnel director and follow the normal procedure for filing a grievance as stated in the grievance procedures of the personnel policies. 
(f)  Confidentiality. All allegations of sexual harassment shall be treated with strict confidence by all parties involved. Failure to comply with the confidentiality requirement will subject the violator to disciplinary action. 
(g)  Note. At any time during an investigation an employee feels uncomfortable reporting the details of an incident to a supervisor of the opposite sex, the employee will be given the opportunity to report the details to someone of the same sex. 
(Code 1971, § 2-31(i)) 
Sec. 2-150. - Employee responsibilities. 
(a)  Political activity. Except as otherwise provided by law, the following restrictions on political activity shall apply to city employees: 
(1)  City employees may seek election to any public office provided that a mandatory leave is requested, approved, and taken effective no later than the announcement date for candidacy or the official filing deadline for office, whichever comes first, and remains on leave until either withdrawing from the contention or until the election is over. Employees who are elected to salaried public office are required to resign from city employment effective the date they take office. 
(2)  No city employee shall circulate petitions or campaign literature for elective city officials or in any way be concerned with soliciting or receiving any subscriptions, contributions, or political service from any person on behalf of such elective official. 
(3)  No employee shall engage in political activities during the employee's working hours with the city. 
(b)  Solicitations. The following restrictions on solicitations shall apply to city employees: 
(1)  The city forbids unauthorized requests for money and all other types of solicitation on city property and during an employee's work time without the express approval of the city manager. 
(2)  The distribution of any unauthorized literature, pamphlets, or material not related to city operations is prohibited during work time and at all times in work areas. 
(3)  No employee shall be required to make any contribution or be penalized or rewarded in any way in connection with the employee's employment according to the response to any authorized solicitation. 
(c)  Dress code and appearance policy. Department heads may specify certain uniforms for employees in such departments when appropriate for specific work, hygiene or safety. 
(d)  Conditions of work. Conditions of work shall be as follows: 
(1)  Hours of work. The hours during which city offices and departments are open for business shall be determined by the city manager. A department head shall implement schedules to meet these general requirements and to provide for other specific requirements of the department. The city administrative offices observe regular working hours from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday. 
(2)  Attendance. Employees shall be required to be at their places of work in accordance with work schedules established by their department. Any employee who fails to report, leaves the workplace without proper authorization, arrives habitually tardy, or misuses authorized absences may be subject to disciplinary action, including termination. 
(3)  Absences. Absenteeism is to be discouraged; however, there are occasions when an employee must be absent. When these times occur, the employee shall notify his supervisor of the situation and follow the prescribed rules regarding the type of absence taken. It is the employee's responsibility to personally arrange absences directly with the immediate supervisor. It will not be acceptable, except under emergency conditions, to have friends or family members arrange absences, nor will it be acceptable to request coworkers to inform the immediate supervisor of absences. 
(e)  Use of job title. All jobs are designated by job titles on all official records, payrolls, and communications. No job will carry an official title which has not been approved by the city manager as being appropriate to the duties performed. 
(f)  Working relationships. It shall be the responsibility of employees to perform the duties of their positions at a high level of cooperation, efficiency, and economy acceptable to their department and the city. Department heads and supervisors shall plan, organize, direct, and control the work of their units to achieve the objectives of the department, including the establishment of performance standards for positions within their jurisdiction. 
(Code 1971, § 2-32) 
Sec. 2-151. - Hiring practices. 
(a)  Creation and filling of positions. All positions and employment in the city service are created for the sole purpose of accomplishing the necessary work program or services of the city as approved in the adopted budget. 
(b)  Medical examination. After a conditional offer of employment, before being appointed, each prospective employee is required to undergo a medical examination by a physician designated by the city, the cost to be borne by the city. Any employee desiring to be examined by his private physician may do so at the employee's own expense. No one who is given a medical examination shall be employed unless the examining physician certifies that the person meets the minimum standards of physical fitness required for the position. Certain classes of employees may be exempted from this subsection upon approval of the city manager. 
(c)  Preemployment drug screening. The policy and procedures for preemployment drug screening shall be as follow: 
(1)  Policy. The city will not hire any applicant for employment found to be engaging in the use or consumption of controlled substances or the abuse of alcohol, unless such controlled substance is prescribed for the user by a physician, and then only if such controlled substance is being used/consumed for the purpose intended. 
(2)  Consent. All applicants for employment shall be required to consent to and pass a controlled substance screening, as a prerequisite to employment. 
(3)  Failure of screening. Applicants for employment who do not consent to and pass the required controlled substance screening will not be hired. Further, such applicants for employment will not be reconsidered for employment for a period of 12 months following a failed or refused controlled substance screen. 
(4)  Confidentiality. All preemployment controlled substance screening results shall be the private and confidential property of the city and will not be shared with anyone except the applicant or as required by a court order or to legally protect the city. 
(d)  Nepotism. The policy for nepotism shall be as follows: 
(1)  Purpose. The purpose of the nepotism policy is to avoid the perception of favoritism and cronyism in government through interpersonal relationships, and to prevent conflicts of interest arising as a result of defined relationships between employees. 
(2)  Policy. An applicant shall be ineligible for employment if related within the second degree of affinity (marriage) or within the third degree of consanguinity (blood) to the mayor, any member of the city council, the city manager or assistant city manager. This prohibition does not apply to any person continuously employed by the city for a period of two years prior to the election of the mayor or city councilmembers, or the appointment of the city manager or assistant city manager. 
(3)  Supervision. No employee may directly or indirectly supervise or be supervised by a member of his immediate family or within the third degree of consanguinity. 
(4)  Marriage/cohabitation. Any situation, in which marriage or cohabitation by employees working in the same department occurs, must be rectified by transferring to another department as soon as a position is open for which the individual involved is the most qualified. Unless an acceptable option is chosen within 120 days, the employee with the shorter length of service will be discharged. 
(e)  Residence. There shall be no absolute residence requirement for city employment except as may be provided by law. Employees likely to be called to work in cases of emergency may be required to reside within reasonable commuting ranges of their places of work. 
(f)  Training policy. It is the policy of the city to strive to provide for the necessary training of its employees. The type of training provided by the city is of an on-the-job nature. The city, at its own expense, may send employees to schools, conferences, or seminars as these training situations become available. 
(Code 1971, § 2-33; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-152. - Orientation. 
(a)  Orientation period policy. Every person initially appointed to the city shall be required to successfully complete an orientation period of six months. Every person promoted in the city service shall be required to successfully complete an orientation period of six months. The initial and promotion orientation period provides a specific timeframe for supervisors to monitor, evaluate, and assist an employee in adjustment to service with the city in general and to the position in particular. 
(b)  Purpose. Department heads and supervisors shall use the orientation period to closely observe and evaluate the work and fitness of employees and to encourage adjustment to their jobs and the city service. Only those employees who meet acceptable standards during the orientation period shall be retained in their positions. 
(c)  Benefits. Employees will accrue vacation and sick leave during the orientation period. Orientation employees may, however, only take sick leave during the orientation period. 
(d)  Failure of orientation. An employee shall fail orientation when, in the judgment of the department head, the employee's fitness and/or quality of work are not such as to merit continuation on the job. Failure of orientation may occur at any time within the orientation period and shall not be considered part of the disciplinary process. 
(Code 1971, § 2-34) 
Sec. 2-153. - Compensation. 
(a)  Policy. It is the city's policy to provide equitable compensation for its employees in the form of pay and fringe benefits to attract and retain qualified personnel for all positions. The compensation that an employee receives from the city is based on a schedule of positions, salaries, and wages as approved by the city council and contained in the annual budget. 
(b)  Job descriptions. Jobs are distinguished by a written job specification including job title, duties and responsibilities, and a statement of minimum qualifications necessary for satisfactory performance of the duties of the job. 
(c)  Responsibility. The personnel office shall be responsible for administration of the pay, benefits, and job specifications and qualifications. The personnel office shall revise existing policies and recommend the revisions as the need arises. 
(d)  Continuous study of salary rates. Upon request of the city manager and periodically as the need arises, the personnel office shall prepare an analysis of prevailing rates of pay for similar public and private employment in the area and at large, taking into consideration cost-of-living factors, budget effects of various alternative pay plans, and other factors which may be pertinent in recommending changes in the plan. On the basis of this information, the city manager may recommend changes in pay policy, or change individual pay rates as necessary to keep the pay current, uniform and equitable. 
(e)  Method of payment. The method of payment shall be as follows: 
(1)  Pay periods. Pay periods and dates of payment shall be set by the city manager. 
(2)  Hourly employees. Employees employed on a hourly basis are paid weekly on Fridays. 
(3)  Salaried employees. Employees on a salary will be paid semimonthly on the 15th and the 30th of each month. 
(f)  Overtime. Employees shall work overtime when necessary, and only on the prior approval of the department head. Overtime on any job will be allocated as evenly as possible among all employees. The city's policy is to pay overtime (11/2 times the regular rate) for all time worked over 40 hours per week, excluding firefighters. Department heads are not normally paid overtime, but are given compensatory time. 
(g)  Compensatory time. The city prefers to provide compensatory time off in lieu of monetary overtime compensation at a rate of 11/2 hours of compensatory time for each hour of overtime worked. Fair Labor Standards guidelines will be followed for compensatory time accumulation and compensation of overtime. Department heads and supervisors shall keep employees' accumulated compensatory time to a minimum. Department heads and supervisors may limit amounts of compensatory time accumulated and may schedule compensatory time off for employees. Upon termination, an employee will be paid for accumulated compensatory time at the employee's regular rate of pay. 
(h)  Christmas bonus policy. The city usually provides for a Christmas bonus to full-time employees depending on the restrictions of each year's fiscal budget. 
(i)  Merit system. 
(1)  Policy. Merit pay increases will be based on the results of the performance evaluation and the employee's ability and efficiency in performing the employee's duties and any additional criteria as determined by the city manager. Automatic pay increases shall not be provided for seniority or tenure. All merit increases may be granted only by the city manager on recommendation of the department head. 
(2)  Evaluations. Performance evaluations will be administered twice a year. All merit raises are subject to the restrictions of the current fiscal budget. 
(j)  Payment of accumulated leave upon termination of employment. 
(1)  An employee will be paid for 25 percent of accumulated sick leave, to a maximum of 30 days paid, if the employee has a minimum of two years of service upon termination of employment and separates in good standing. Good standing is defined as follows: 
a.  Gives proper notice of termination to the department (two weeks). 
b.  Takes only appropriate days off during the last two weeks of employment, i.e., weekends or scheduled days off. 
c.  Turns in all city equipment, uniforms, etc., that have been issued. Equipment must be in acceptable working condition. 
d.  Termination for violation of city personnel policies, standard operating procedure, safety policies, or excessive absenteeism will not be considered leaving in good standing. 
(2)  Failure to return city-issued equipment, uniforms, materials, records, or other items may result in delay of payment of terminal pay. Terminal pay may also be delayed due to any pending investigation of an employee. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 2-154. - Leave. 
(a)  Holiday leave. The holiday leave policy shall be as follows: 
(1)  Municipal offices, with the exception of those in emergency categories, shall be closed on the following official holidays: 
a.  New Year's Day. 
b.  Martin Luther King Day. 
c.  Good Friday. 
d.  Memorial Day. 
e.  Independence Day. 
f.  Labor Day. 
g.  Thanksgiving. 
h.  Thanksgiving Friday. 
i.  Day before Christmas (December 24). 
j.  Christmas Day (December 25). 
(2)  If a regularly scheduled holiday falls on a Saturday or Sunday, the holiday is taken on Friday or Monday, respectively. 
(3)  Full-time employees are entitled to paid holidays. Part-time regular employees who would normally have worked on the day observed as a holiday are paid for the number of hours they would have worked had the holiday not occurred. Seasonal employees will receive time off for the holiday without pay. 
(4)  An employee who is absent without authorization or who is on leave without pay on the day immediately preceding or following a holiday shall lose pay for the holiday as well as the pay for that day. 
(5)  An employee who is on vacation, approved military leave, or a scheduled, nondisciplinary leave of absence when a holiday is observed will be paid the employee's regular rate for that holiday. 
(6)  All employees who are required to work on holidays shall be given an alternate day off and shall be paid regular rates for the time worked on the holiday. 
(7)  Holidays falling within an employee's vacation period or within a period of absence properly chargeable to illness shall not be counted against vacation or sick leave. 
(8)  Employees desiring to observe religious holidays not coinciding with official holidays may be given time off without pay or may be authorized to use accrued vacation leave or compensatory time. 
(b)  Vacation leave. The purpose of and policy for vacation leave is as follows: 
(1)  Purpose. Vacation leave is provided for the specific purpose of allowing employees periods of rest and recreation. 
(2)  Policy. All full-time employees earn vacation from the date of employment. Vacation is earned according to the following schedule: 
Years of Service Days Earned Per Month Days Earned Per Year Hours Earned Per Year 0-5 0.83 10  80 6 0.92 11  88 7 1.00 12  96 8 1.08 13 104 9 1.17 14 112 10 1.25 15 120  
a.  Accrued vacation may be used after six months of employment. Accumulated vacation can be carried forward beyond a calendar year. Employees with less than ten years service can accumulate a maximum of 21 days or 168 hours of vacation. Employees with over ten years service can accumulate a maximum of 30 days or 240 hours of vacation. When maximum vacation is accumulated the employee does not earn vacation until accumulated vacation is reduced below the maximum. 
b.  Certified individuals employed in either the police or fire department are entitled to 15 vacation days each year with pay if the member has been regularly employed in the department for at least one year. 
c.  Vacation leave may not be taken prior to the completion of six months of employment except in cases of emergency to be determined by the department head. 
d.  Vacation cannot be taken in advance of being earned. All vacation leave must be approved in advance by the department head. Any employee requesting in excess of 15 consecutive working days of vacation leave must have department head and personnel department approval. 
e.  Leave credits are not transferable between employees. 
f.  Seasonal and temporary employees do not earn vacation. 
g.  Part-time regular employees earn vacation in the proportion that their regularly scheduled work period bears to the regularly scheduled work period of full-time employees in the same department. 
h.  Leave may be taken in four-hour or half-day increments. Although employees are encouraged to take vacations in full-week segments, vacations can also be taken in units of half days and whole days. 
i.  All leave requests must be approved by the department head so that schedules and duties may be adjusted to create minimum disruption of normal work operations. Except in extraordinary circumstances, vacation time must be requested at least one week in advance. 
j.  Holidays falling in the vacation period of the employee will not be counted as part of vacation leave. 
k.  Employees who leave the employment of the city in good standing after serving six months will be paid for their unused vacation time. Employees terminating prior to six months of service will not be paid for vacation time. 
l.  Employees shall not be allowed to receive pay for accrued vacation in lieu of taking time off. 
m.  Employees may not receive cash payment on accrued vacation except upon termination, retirement, or death. 
n.  Employees shall not be allowed to borrow vacation time against future accrual. 
o.  Employees who are laterally transferred, promoted, or demoted shall retain accrued vacation leave. 
p.  Fire department employees who work shifts other than a regular forty-hour week are charged vacation time at the rate of two days per shift. 
(c)  Sick leave. The purpose of and policy for sick leave is as follows: 
(1)  Purpose. The intent of sick leave is to preclude loss of income for absences due to illness or injury during the employee's regular workweek. 
(2)  Policy. All full-time salaried city employees earn 11/4 days of sick leave per month or 15 days per year, based on their anniversary date. Sick leave may be accumulated not to exceed 120 days. 
a.  Full-time hourly employees earn five days of sick leave per year. 
b.  Fire department employees who work shifts other than a regular 40-hour week are charged sick leave time at the rate of two days for one shift. 
c.  During the orientation period, sick leave shall accumulate and may be used. 
d.  Sick leave may not be used in advance of being earned. 
e.  Sick leave credits are not transferable between employees. 
f.  Employees may use vacation time in lieu of sick leave. 
g.  When absence due to illness exceeds the amount of paid leave earned and authorized, the pay of an employee shall be discontinued until he returns to work. 
h.  Employees who are laterally transferred, promoted, or demoted shall retain accrued sick leave. 
i.  Employees can use sick leave for medical, dental, or ocular appointments; personal illness; or physical incapacity. 
j.  To receive sick leave, the employee must notify his immediate supervisor within the time limits established by the department. 
k.  Failure to ensure proper notification without a valid reason shall constitute absence without leave. 
l.  No city employee shall be entitled to sick leave while absent from duty on account of the following causes: 
1.  Disability arising from any sickness or injury purposely inflicted or caused by willful misconduct. 
2.  Sickness or disability sustained while on leave of absence without pay. 
3.  Ordinary tiredness or restlessness. 
4.  Disability acquired as a result of another job. 
m.  A department head may require an employee to take sick leave when evidence exists that an employee is ill or injured and where the department head believes the employee's medical condition may pose a personal hazard or impose risk to others. 
n.  Employees who are absent for more than three successive days of unconfirmed illness may be required by the department head to submit a physician's statement. An employee who consistently uses sick leave as it accumulates may be required to submit a physician's statement for any claimed illness or injury causing an absence from work for more than half a day. 
o.  An employee who misuses sick leave may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including dismissal. 
p.  An employee will be paid for 25 percent of accumulated sick leave, a maximum of 30 days paid, if the employee has a minimum of two years of service upon termination of employment. The employee must separate or resign in good standing. 
(d)  Family Medical Leave Act. The purpose of and policy for family medical leave is as follows: 
(1)  Purpose. The Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) requires covered employers to provide up to 12 weeks of unpaid, job-protected leave to "eligible" employees for certain family and medical reasons. Employees are eligible if they have worked at least one year, and for 1,250 hours over the previous 12 months. 
(2)  Reasons for taking family medical leave. Unpaid family medical leave will be granted for any of the following reasons: 
a.  To care for the employee's child after birth, or placement for adoption or foster care. 
b.  To care for the employee's spouse, son or daughter, or parent, who has a serious health condition. 
c.  For a serious health condition that makes the employee unable to perform the employee's job. 
Any accumulated leave (sick, vacation, compensatory, etc.) will be used in lieu of unpaid leave. 
(3)  Advance notice and medical certification. Employees will be required to provide advance leave notice and medical certification. Taking of leave may be denied if requirements are not met. 
a.  The employee ordinarily must provide 30 days' advance notice when the leave is "foreseeable." 
b.  The city may require medical certification to support a request for leave because of a serious health condition and may require second or third opinions, at the employer's expense, and a fitness for duty report to return to work. 
(4)  Job benefits and protection. 
a.  For the duration of Family Medical Leave Act leave, the city will maintain the employee's health coverage. 
b.  Upon return from Family Medical Leave Act leave, most employees will be restored to their original or equivalent positions with equivalent pay, benefits, and other employment terms. 
c.  The use of Family Medical Leave Act leave cannot result in the loss of any employment benefit that accrued prior to the start of an employee's leave. 
(e)  Emergency/bereavement leave. The purpose of and policy for emergency and bereavement leave is as follows: 
(1)  Purpose. Emergency leave is designed to minimize the need for full-time employees to use vacation leave or compensatory time in cases involving death or illness in the employee's immediate family or household. 
(2)  Policy. Any full- or part-time employee may be granted emergency leave with pay by the employee's department head in case of illness or death of members of the immediate family. Seasonal employees may be granted unpaid leave. Such leave will not exceed five working days in a 12-month period to any employee. This leave does not count against sick leave or vacation time. 
(3)  Restrictions. Immediate family is restricted to the following: 
a.  Spouse. 
b.  Child (natural, step, adopted). 
c.  Mother. 
d.  Father. 
e.  Brother. 
f.  Sister. 
g.  Grandmother. 
h.  Grandfather. 
i.  Aunt. 
j.  Uncle. 
k.  Father-in-law. 
l.  Mother-in-law. 
m.  Brother-in-law. 
n.  Sister-in-law. 
o.  Daughter-in-law. 
p.  Son-in-law. 
q.  More distant relative residing in the home of the employee. 
(f)  Funeral leave policy. Leave for attendance of funerals not provided under emergency leave may be granted, through department heads, not to exceed two days per calendar year. 
(g)  Military leave policy. Military leave will be granted in accordance with state and federal laws. 
(h)  Court leave. The policy for court leave is as follows: 
(1)  Pay continued. Employees called upon for jury service will receive their regular salary from the city during such services. 
(2)  Enforcement officers. Court appearances as a city enforcement officer (fire, police, inspections, etc.) are compensated as actual hours worked and are not classified as paid leave. 
(3)  Witness. An employee directed to appear as a witness for the city, the state, or the federal government will be compensated for the employee's time as stated in subsection (h)(1) or (2) of this section. 
(4)  Documentation required. An employee summoned either for jury duty or as a witness must provide an official certificate of attendance to the employee's immediate supervisor. 
(5)  Personal legal business. An employee absent for personal legal business must use accrued vacation or compensatory time. Leave without pay may be used with the department head's approval. 
(i)  Civic leave; time off to vote. Employees are encouraged to register to vote. It is the responsibility of the employee to contact his immediate supervisor regarding choosing a time to vote. The supervisor may select another time if the chosen time conflicts with departmental duties. The supervisor, however, must give sufficient time to the employee to exercise his right to vote. 
(j)  Career enrichment leave. Career enrichment leave may be granted as follows: 
(1)  With the approval of the city manager, a department head may grant an employee administrative absence with pay for purposes of attending a professional conference, convention, training activity, legislative proceeding or civic function or meeting or for purposes of coordinating with governmental and/or private agencies and entities in the interest of the city. 
(2)  All employees in the city service shall be entitled to necessary time off with pay for the purpose of taking qualifying or promotional examinations for other positions within the city service. The amount of time allowed for this activity shall be limited as prescribed by the city manager. 
(k)  Leave of absence without pay. A leave of absence without pay may be granted as follows: 
(1)  Restrictions. Department heads, with the approval of the director of personnel, may grant leaves of absence without pay to regular employees, not to exceed 30 days in duration. In granting such leave, the department head shall give primary consideration to the city's need for the employee's services. A leave of absence without pay may be granted for any legitimate purpose, such as absence for illness, disability, and pregnancy; however, the employee will be obligated to show that the granting of such leave is to the interest of the city. A leave of absence without pay in excess of 30 days may be granted only with the approval of the city manager, and in no case shall the leave exceed six months. 
(2)  Request of leave. Any employee requesting a leave of absence without pay must submit a written request to his department head at least two weeks prior to the date upon which the requested leave is to begin. The employee is responsible for keeping the department informed of his intention and/or ability to work. 
(3)  Limitations. A department head may revoke a leave of absence if the cause for granting leave was misrepresented or has ceased to exist. An employee who takes time off without the approval of the employee's department head or otherwise fails to return to work on the date designated is subject to disciplinary action, including termination. 
(4)  Insurance coverage. An employee on unpaid leave of absence will pay for the employee's dependents coverage and any premium for the employee's own coverage that the city does not currently pay. An employee must make arrangements to pay the costs of the coverage with the personnel department. An employee's failure to make payments to the city on a timely basis will result in the insurance being discontinued. 
(5)  Disciplinary actions. Employees on disciplinary suspension without pay may not use compensatory, vacation, or sick leave to recuperate the lost time. 
(6)  Reinstatement. During an employee's approved leave of absence without pay, the employee's vacant position may be filled temporarily or permanently by appointment, promotion or reassignment of an employee. At the expiration of leave without pay, the employee may be reinstated to the position the employee vacated if the position still exists and if the position has not been filled. If the position has been filled, the employee may apply for any vacant position with the city. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.1) 
Sec. 2-155. - Health and safety. 
(a)  Safety. All employees are required as a condition of employment to exercise due care in the course of work. To prevent or minimize injuries to the employee and the employee's coworkers and to protect and conserve city equipment, each employee shall: 
(1)  Obey all safety rules, regulations and policies published in the Employee Safety Handbook. 
(2)  Report to the employee's immediate supervisor all unsafe work conditions. 
(3)  Keep work areas clean and orderly at all times. 
(4)  Report immediately all accidents in which the employee is involved to the employee's immediate supervisor. 
(5)  Operate only machines or equipment that the employee has been authorized to operate. 
Employees who defy safety procedures or display gross negligence which may or may not cause damage to property or injury to others will be subject to disciplinary action. 
(b)  On-the-job injury/accident reporting. Each employee is required to report any and all accidents, no matter how slight, to his supervisor at once. All supervisors are to report such accidents to the personnel office. At the time an accident is reported to the personnel office, an accident report will be completed in full. 
(c)  Worker's compensation. 
(1)  Supervisor responsibility. All on-the-job injuries and illnesses, regardless of how minor, are to be reported on the City of Nacogdoches-Report of Injury form available in each department. The immediate supervisor of the injured employee will complete the form and forward it through the department head to the personnel department the same day the accident occurs. If a job-related disability injury results in lost time, the personnel department should be notified immediately of the date the employee begins losing time. The personnel department should also be notified immediately of the date the employee returns to work. Failure to advise the personnel department of the status of the injured employee may result in a delay of the employee receiving worker's compensation payment. 
(2)  Employee responsibility. An employee who suffers an occupational injury or illness shall report the incident to his immediate supervisor within 24 hours after it occurs. Any employee who is physically able, but does not meet this reporting requirement, shall not be eligible for injured employee compensation during the initial week of disability (see subsection (c)(3)b of this section). 
(3)  Compensation is given in accordance with the following: 
a.  An employee who suffers a disabling lost-time occupational injury or illness is eligible for worker's compensation benefits, in accordance with the provisions of the law. 
b.  An employee authorized to be off duty due to an occupational injury or illness shall be paid injured employee compensation by the city for a maximum of five workdays, at the regular rate of pay, during the first week of disability. To be eligible for injured employee compensation, an employee must: 
1.  If physically able, report the injury to his supervisor within 24 hours. 
2.  Endorse any worker's compensation checks for the initial five workdays to the city. 
c.  After the initial week of disability, an employee is eligible to receive weekly worker's compensation payments subject to minimum and maximum payments. An employee with accrued sick leave may elect to receive sick leave payments which is chargeable against the employee's accrued sick leave and when added to the worker's compensation shall equal the employee's regular pay. 
d.  An employee who remains disabled after using all available sick leave will continue receiving worker's compensation payments in accordance with the provisions of law. 
(4)  An employee authorized to be off duty due to an occupational injury or illness shall continue to earn vacation and sick leave at the regular rate. 
(5)  The attending physician should complete the City of Nacogdoches Doctor's Medical Report at the time of treatment and return the report to the department head of the employee. The department head shall adhere to the physician's instructions in the report and forward the report to the personnel department. 
(6)  The department head shall initiate the Supplemental Report of Injury form and submit it to the personnel department within 24 hours of any action, such as: 
a.  The employee returns to work from lost-time injury. 
b.  The injured employee has not returned to work after 60 consecutive days; and each subsequent 60-day period thereafter. 
c.  The employee loses additional time because of the original injury. 
d.  The injury was initially reported as "no lost time," but subsequent to that report the employee begins to lose time because of the injury. 
(7)  An employee authorized to be off duty due to an occupational injury and who violates the following shall be subject to disciplinary action, including dismissal, if the employee: 
a.  Is found to be working part time or full time either for pay or otherwise, for himself or another employer; 
b.  Falsifies or misrepresents his physical condition or disability as worse than it in fact is; 
c.  Consistently fails or refuses to follow the instructions of the treating physician; or 
d.  Refuses to return to regular duty or perform light duty when authorized by the treating physician and offered such duty by the department head. 
(d)  Controlled substance and alcohol abuse. The city acknowledges that its success now, as well as in the future, is dependent upon the physical and psychological well-being of its employees. Accordingly, it is the city's right, obligation and intent to maintain a safe working environment for all of its employees; to protect city property, equipment and operations; and to fulfill its obligation to the general public. The policy, purpose and procedures for controlled substance and alcohol abuse are as follows: 
(1)  Policy. The manufacture, distribution, use or possession by an employee of an intoxicating liquor, controlled substance, drug not medically authorized, or any other substance which may impair job performance or pose a hazard or serious risk to the safety and welfare of the employee, fellow employees, the city or general public, whether on or off the job, shall constitute cause for disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
(2)  Scope. This policy applies to all employees of the city. This policy also applies to all applicants for employment with the city. 
(3)  Purpose. The manufacture, distribution, possession, use, or consumption of controlled substances or alcohol or being under the influence of controlled substances or alcohol may create serious risk for the involved employee, fellow employees, the city, and the general public. This policy is to assist in the reduction of such risks. 
(4)  Testing of employees. Current employees may be tested for controlled substances or alcohol use under the following circumstances: 
a.  If an accident occurs on the job or on city property. 
b.  When an employee's behavior or work performance gives reasonable cause to believe the employee is affected by the use or ingestion of controlled substances or alcohol. 
c.  To comply with local, state, federal government laws, ordinances, or regulations. 
(5)  Failure of test. A current employee failing a controlled substance and alcohol screen required in accordance with this policy is subject to disciplinary action up to and including discharge. 
(6)  Refusal of consent. An employee who refuses to undergo a controlled substance and/or alcohol screening in accordance with this policy shall be treated as if the employee failed the required test. 
(e)  Employee assistance for alcohol or drug dependency. It is the city's desire to provide assistance to those employees who voluntarily request assistance with a personal alcohol or drug dependency problem. Employees are responsible for acknowledging their substance abuse problem and for seeking and accepting counseling or rehabilitation assistance before it impairs their performance or conduct and jeopardizes their employment. Employees who need to enter into a substance abuse treatment program will be allowed to enter a city-approved program one time without endangering their jobs provided they follow all prescribed treatment programs. Time off without pay may be authorized in accordance with the city's personnel policy on leaves of absence, if needed, up to 30 days. In most cases, participating employees will be returned to their former or comparable position if feasible when treatment is successfully completed. Some of the costs of the treatment may be covered by the city's health insurance plan. 
Continued employment is contingent on the employee's participating in any nonwork followup counseling or aftercare treatment programs. The personnel director will be the employee assistance program representative and should be contacted in regard to an employee's participation in an approved treatment program. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.2) 
Sec. 2-156. - Use of city tools, equipment and property. 
(a)  The city attempts to provide each employee with adequate tools, equipment, and vehicles for the city job being performed, and expects each employee to observe safe work practices and safe and courteous operation of vehicles and equipment in compliance with all municipal, county and state regulations. 
(b)  Employees who are assigned tools or equipment or vehicles by their departments are responsible for them and for their proper use. No personal use of any city property, materials, supplies, tools, equipment, or vehicles is permitted, unless authorized by the department head or city manager. 
(c)  If an employee is found to have used any city vehicle or equipment in a negligent manner and such vehicle or equipment becomes destroyed or damaged, the employee may be subject to disciplinary action. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.3) 
Sec. 2-157. - Discipline. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of discipline is to produce a change in the behavior of an employee so that the individual's future conduct complies with city policies and supports the attainment of the organization's objectives. Discipline should be used to correct unsatisfactory behavior and to encourage more effective performance. In disciplining employees, emphasis will be placed on correction-not on punishment for the sake of punishment. 
(b)  Grounds. Disciplinary action may be taken against an employee for just cause. The following list is by way of example only and is not exhaustive of what actions constitute just cause: 
(1)  Illegal, unethical, abusive, or unsafe acts. 
(2)  Violation of city or departmental rules, regulations, policies, or procedures. 
(3)  Insubordination. 
(4)  Neglect or abandonment of duties. 
(5)  Abuse of illness, injury, disability, or other benefits. 
(6)  Tardiness or absence without leave. 
(7)  Falsification of official documents or records. 
(8)  Using or being under the influence of drugs or intoxicating beverages on the job. 
(9)  Waste, damage, or unauthorized use of city property or supplies. 
(10)  Unauthorized use or disclosure of official information. 
(11)  Unauthorized or improper use of official authority. 
(12)  Inability to get along with fellow workers. 
(13)  Discourtesy to the public. 
(14)  Acceptance of any gratuity or gift for the performance or nonperformance of official duties. 
(15)  Engaging in horseplay or scuffling on the job. 
(16)  Fighting or provoking or instigating a fight, on city property. 
(17)  Sleeping on the job during working hours. 
(18)  An accumulation of infractions. 
(19)  Poor work performance. 
(20)  Any other conduct the city manager, department head, or a supervisor believes to be inappropriate. 
(c)  Disciplinary action. Violations of the city's rules and procedures or any other misconduct will result in appropriate disciplinary action. Appropriate disciplinary action will depend upon the circumstances, and may include such things as oral warnings, written reprimands, suspensions, probation, or discharge. 
(d)  Responsibility. Department heads are responsible for enforcing and maintaining proper standards of discipline and personal conduct among their employees. In implementing the disciplinary procedures, a department head/supervisor should consider such factors as the type and severity of the offense, the employee's performance record, and any mitigating circumstances surrounding the offense. All regular employees have the right to appeal a disciplinary action through the grievance process. 
(e)  Documentation. Department heads shall submit documentation of any disciplinary actions and the surrounding circumstances to the personnel director for the inclusion in the official personnel files of the employee involved. Any disciplinary action taken should be documented in writing indicating: 
(1)  The cause of discipline. 
(2)  The specific reason supporting the cause. 
(3)  The discipline to be imposed. 
(4)  The effective date. 
(5)  The employee's right to appeal. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.4) 
Sec. 2-158. - Separations. 
(a)  Resignation. The policy and procedures for resignation from the city are as follow: 
(1)  Policy. To resign in good standing, an employee shall submit a resignation, preferably in writing, to the department head two weeks before the effective date of the resignation. 
(2)  Procedure. A brief signed statement identifying the effective date of the resignation is adequate. An employee may give reasons for resigning, but it is not necessary. The city manager may waive any portion of the notice period. 
Unauthorized absence from work for a period of three working days shall be considered as a resignation. 
(3)  Benefits. 
a.  Employees who leave the city's employment after serving six months will be paid for their unused vacation time. Employees terminating prior to six months' service will not be paid for vacation time. 
b.  Employees will be paid for 25 percent of accumulated sick leave, a maximum of 30 days paid, if the employee has a minimum of two years of service upon termination of employment and separates in good standing. 
(b)  Layoff policy. An employee may be laid off because of changes in duties of the organization or for lack of work or funds. Whenever possible, an employee laid off from one city department shall be transferred to a suitable position elsewhere. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.5) 
Sec. 2-159. - Complaints; grievances. 
(a)  Disciplinary and termination policy. The city's disciplinary and termination policy is as follows: 
(1)  It is the intent of the disciplinary and termination procedure to safeguard the rights of all employees, to ensure that all employees are judged by fair and equitable standards, and to require that all rules are applied on an equitable basis. 
(2)  In the interest of good discipline and efficiency, a department head may demote an employee, suspend an employee without pay, or terminate an employee. All demotions, suspensions or terminations shall be approved by the personnel director prior to action being taken. 
(3)  Before an employee may be reclassified with a reduction in pay, suspended from employment, or terminated, the employee shall be notified in writing of the reason for the action and given an opportunity for a hearing before the department head and personnel director. At the hearing, the employee is entitled to examine evidence, cross examine witnesses or present proof. 
(4)  When an employee receives written notice of reduction in pay, suspension from employment, or termination, the employee may request a hearing with the department head and personnel director within three working days of receipt of the written notice. If a hearing is requested a date and time will be set by the personnel director. Failure of the employee to request a hearing by the specified time shall waive the rights to determination of any employment dispute and shall constitute consent to any employment action proposed or indicated in the original notice letter. 
(5)  At the conclusion of the hearing or as soon as possible thereafter, the personnel director and department head shall make a determination and shall make a written report of the hearing and determination. 
(6)  The employee may appeal the determination made by the personnel director and department head by delivering a signed written notice within five working days of receipt of the decision to the personnel director. A date and time shall be set for the appeal to be heard by the city manager. The city manager may request the presence of the personnel director, department head, and any other persons with knowledge or witness to the cause for action. The decision of the city manager will be final. 
(7)  An employee may be suspended during an investigation of misconduct in accordance with the following: 
a.  A regular employee may be suspended with pay, subject to reinstatement where applicable, where the department head determines that the risk of loss to the city of his continued employment, or the critical necessity of public confidence in his integrity, requires such suspension. 
b.  The conclusion of any investigation and termination or reinstatement of any employee shall take place within 60 days of any suspension, unless the employee consents, directly or by implication, to a longer period of suspension. 
(b)  Termination processing. Procedures for termination are as follows: 
(1)  It will be the responsibility of the terminating department to ensure that all city property (i.e., keys, tools, equipment, etc.) has been turned in prior to submitting the exit checklist to the personnel office. 
(2)  Terminating employees are responsible for completing an exit interview form prior to their last date of employment. This form may be obtained in the personnel office. Employees wishing to talk with the personnel director, prior to their effective date of termination, may do so by calling the personnel office to schedule an appointment. 
(c)  Grievance policy. The grievance policy is as follows: 
(1)  A grievance is defined as something that causes distress or gives reason to complain. Grievances relate to working conditions and situations which the employee feels are unfair. 
(2)  Employees are encouraged to handle all differences of opinion at their department level by bringing the matter to their supervisor immediately. If the discussion with the immediate supervisor produces unsatisfactory results, the employee may submit a written grievance to the department head if the employee is still unsatisfied. If the decision of the department head is not satisfactory, the employee shall, within five working days of receiving a written decision, request from the personnel director a hearing before the city grievance committee. 
(3)  The city grievance committee will consist of three staff members selected by the personnel director. The grievant, for good cause, may request substitution of one of the three chosen committee members. The decision to substitute any member shall be at the discretion of the personnel director. 
(4)  The grievance committee shall hold an informal meeting at which all parties shall have the opportunity to present their case to ascertain the facts surrounding the grievance. The committee shall make a written report and render a recommendation to the city manager within five working days of the hearing. The city manager shall review the recommendations of the grievance committee and provide a final written response to the grievant. The decision of the city manager shall be final. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.6) 
Sec. 2-160. - Performance evaluations. 
(a)  Purpose. The performance appraisals are designed to help supervisory personnel and employees measure how well city work is being performed and to provide a tool for management decisions regarding training, assignment, promotion, salary adjustment and retention of city employees. 
(b)  Evaluation. The work performance of each employee shall be evaluated in accordance with procedures developed by the personnel department. Special evaluations may be made if requested by the department head, and in those departments where applicable, performance appraisals should be administered twice annually. All performance appraisals shall be completed on standardized forms provided by the personnel department. 
(c)  Counseling. An employee should sign copies of the employee's own performance appraisal reports. Evaluators shall individually discuss the reports with the employee and shall counsel the employee regarding the job performance, and any improvements in such performance which appear desirable or necessary. 
(d)  Reconsideration. An employee dissatisfied with the performance appraisal may seek reconsideration through the chain of command to the employee's department head. 
(e)  Records. All performance appraisals shall become a permanent part of the employee's personnel file maintained in the personnel department. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.7) 
Sec. 2-161. - Employee records. 
(a)  Official personnel file. The personnel department shall maintain the official personnel file for all city employees. It is the responsibility of supervisors to ensure that all necessary documentation is forwarded to the personnel department for inclusion in the employee's file. The personnel director is responsible for ensuring documents of an evaluative or negative nature clearly indicate the employee is aware of the document prior to placement in the employee's file. The personnel director shall determine the appropriateness of placement of documents in an employee's personnel file. 
(b)  Employee privacy. The director of personnel shall establish procedures necessary to preserve the privacy of employee information as required by applicable state and federal legislation. Access to privileged or confidential employee records shall be based on the need to know as determined by the personnel director. 
The Texas Open Records Act permits an employee or official of a governmental body to dictate whether the public shall have access to the employee's home address and telephone number by submitting a written notice to the personnel director. No employee's home address and telephone number may be disclosed to the public if the employee or city official requests that the items be closed. 
(c)  Personnel file review. An employee at all times has a right to inspect any and all inclusions made a part of the employee's personnel records and may at any time submit personal work-related information that may be included into his official records. 
(d)  Currency of records. Employees shall notify their supervisor who shall notify the personnel department, on the appropriate forms, of any change in the following: 
(1)  Address. 
(2)  Telephone number. 
(3)  Person to notify in case of accident or illness. 
(4)  Name-through marriage or otherwise. 
(5)  Marital status. 
(6)  Number of dependents. 
(7)  Insurance beneficiary. 
(8)  Military status. 
(9)  Expiration of licenses and/or certificates necessary to do the job. 
(Code 1971, § 2-35.8) 
Secs. 2-162-2-200. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARDS, COMMITTEES AND COMMISSIONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Airport advisory board, § 10-56 et seq.; floodplain management board of appeals, § 42-91 et seq.; historic landmark preservation committee, § 50-61 et seq.; Nacogdoches public library advisory board, § 62-86 et seq.; parks and recreation advisory board, § 74-26 et seq.; planning and zoning commission, § 118-66 et seq.; zoning board of appeals, § 118-96 et seq. 

Sec. 2-201. - Appointment and terms of board and commission members.
