(a)  All city board and commission members shall be appointed by a majority of the members of the city council. Appointments are made in open session. 
(b)  All board and commission members shall serve either a full term on the designated board or commission or the unexpired term of a member to fill a vacancy. All members shall serve at the will of the city council. 
(c)  Board and commission terms are set by the city council. However, no member of an appointed board or commission shall serve more than six consecutive years on the same board or commission. 
(d)  The city council reserves the right to waive the six-year rule. A waiver of the six-year consecutive service limit shall require the concurring vote of four-fifths of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1534-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Chapter 6 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1495-7-08, adopted July 15, 2008, repealed the former Ch. 6, Art. I, §§ 6-1, 6-2, Art. II, Div. 1, §§ 6-3-6-11, Art. II, Div. 2, §§ 6-12, 6-13, Art. II, Div. 3, §§ 6-14-6-24, and enacted a new Ch. 6 as set out herein. The former Ch. 6 pertained to animals and derived from Ord. No. 1409-3-06, 3-21-2006. 
Cross reference- Kennels and pet shops, § 18-296 et seq.; animals prohibited in cemeteries, § 22-1; environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 46; livestock and motorized sport vehicles in parks, § 74-63; collection of small dead animals, § 82-99; collection of large dead animals, § 82-100; horse-drawn carriages, § 110-306 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(a)  Prevent hazards to the physical and mental health of the public caused by animals; 
(b)  Prevent cruelty to animals; 
(c)  Decrease the number of unwanted and stray dogs and cats in the city; 
(d)  Encourage responsible animal ownership; 
(e)  Place the responsibility of complying with its requirements upon an animal's owner. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-2. - Definitions. 
    Abandon means the act of leaving an animal: 
(1)  Without food, water or care for 24 hours or more; or 
(2)  In a situation where conditions present an immediate, direct, and serious threat to the life, safety, or health of the animal. 
    Altered means incapable of reproduction; synonym of sterilized, neutered or spayed. 
    Animal means any warm or cold-blooded vertebrate. 
    Animal control officer means the person designated by the city manager to represent and act for the city in the impoundment of animals, controlling of animals running at large and as otherwise provided and required in this chapter; as well as that person's subordinates and designees. 
    Animal shelter means a facility designated or recognized by the city for the purpose of impounding and caring for animals. 
    At large means to be free of physical restraint beyond the boundaries of owner's premises. 
    Companion animal means dogs and cats. 
    Dangerous dog means any dog that: 
(1)  Makes an un provoked attack on a person that causes bodily injury and occurs in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own; or 
(2)  Commits unprovoked acts in a place other than an enclosure in which the dog was being kept and that was reasonably certain to prevent the dog from leaving the enclosure on its own and those acts cause a person to reasonably believe that the dog will attach and cause bodily injury to that person. 
    Domestic animal includes livestock and normal household pets, such as but not limited to dogs, cats, cockatiels, ferrets, hamsters, guinea pigs, gerbils, rabbits, fish or small, non poisonous reptiles or nonpoisonous snakes. 
    Dumping means to knowingly desert, forsake or absolutely give up any dog, cat or other companion animal in any public place including the right-of-way of any public highway, road or street or on the property of another. 
    Euthanasia means the humane destruction of a companion, domestic or exotic animal by a method, which causes immediate unconsciousness without visible evidence of distress on the part of the animal. 
    Exotic animal means any animal not defined as a companion animal or a domestic animal. 
    Feral cat means a cat too unsocialized to be handled or placed in a typical pet home. 
    Guard dog or attack dog means any dog intended to attack intruders. 
    Harboring means the act of keeping and caring for an animal or providing premises to which the animal returns for all or part of three consecutive days. 
    Inhumane treatment of animals means any treatment of an animal prohibited by any provision of law, including federal, state and local laws, ordinances or rules. 
    Kennel means any place or premises wherein any person boards, breeds, buys, lets for hire, trains for a fee, trades or sells dogs or cats; does not include veterinary hospitals or humane societies. 
    Limited breeder means any person that breeds or allows his or her animal, whether purebred or mixed breed, to produce offspring. 
    Livestock means domestic animals generally used or raised on a farm for profit, work, or pleasure, including, but not limited to, cattle, cows, sheep, pigs, bulls, stallions, mare gelding, jack, jennies, hogs, goats, llamas, ostriches and emus. 
    Managed feral cat colony means a colony of feral cats in which TTVAR-M (trap, test, vaccinate, alter, return, monitor/manage) is being performed. Cats are altered, vaccinated for rabies and ear-tipped before return to the original location. 
    Multiple pet owners mean a person who keeps or harbors more than five dogs or five cats or any combination of five cats and dogs. One litter of puppies or kittens under four months of age may be excluded from the count. 
    Owner means any person who has a right of property over an animal, keeps or harbors an animal, has an animal in his/her care, acts as custodian of an animal, or permits an animal to remain on or about his/her premises. 
    Restraint an animal shall be considered under restraint if it is confined to its owner's premises by a physical fence in a manner that will isolate the animal from the public and from other animals except for animals owned or under the control of the owner; or is secure by a leash and properly fitted collar; or is otherwise under the physical control of the owner or of another responsible person. 
    Secure enclosure shall mean a fenced area or structure that is: 
(1)  Locked; 
(2)  Capable of preventing the release or escape of an animal; 
(3)  Capable of preventing the entry of the general public, including children; 
(4)  Clearly marked as containing a dangerous animal by posting signs bearing letters not less than two inches high on all sides of the enclosure; 
(5)  Is tall enough or covered so that the animal cannot climb out; and 
(6)  Has a perimeter structure which prevents the animal from digging out or going under the side fence or wall. 
    Serious bodily injury means an injury characterized by severe bite wounds or severe ripping and tearing of muscle that would cause a reasonably prudent person to seek treatment from a medical professional and which would require hospitalization without regard to whether the person actually sought medical treatment. 
    Shelter means a structure that protects animals from the elements. It must be enclosed on at least three sides and have a roof and a floor. 
    Unprovoked attack means an attack or act by an animal, which took place even though the person or animal attacked did nothing to cause or encourage the attack or act. 
    Vaccination means an injection of rabies vaccine approved by the United States Department of Agriculture and administered in accordance with state law. 
    Wild animal means those animals of wild nature or disposition so as to require to be reclaimed and made tame by art, industry, or education, or else must be kept in confinement to be brought within the immediate control of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008; Ord. No. 1626-5-13, 5-7-2013) 
DIVISION 2. - ENFORCEMENT, IMPOUNDMENT 

Sec. 6-3. - Authority generally. 
    It shall be the duty of the animal control authority or duly licensed peace officer to carry out all applicable provisions of this chapter and to pick up and impound all animals found to be in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-4. - Authority to use tranquilizer equipment. 
    In the performance of his/her duties, the animal control officers shall have authority to employ tranquilizer equipment and all other animal control devices commonly used by other animal control agencies located within the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-5. - Interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, hinder, or molest any animal control officer in the performance of any duty delegated under this chapter, or seek to release any animal taken and held in custody under provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-6. - Notice of impoundment. 
    The animal control officer shall at once notify the owner, if known, of any animal currently in impound pursuant to this chapter. The notice shall give a description of the animal impounded, including any marks or brands. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-7. - Injured animals. 
    Animals injured on public property may be impounded and given adequate veterinary medical treatment pending notification of the owner. If an injured animal is treated or impounded, the owner of such animal shall be liable for all expenses of treatment and/or impoundment; however, disposition may be made at the discretion of the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-8. - Redemption of impounded animals. 
    The owner of any impounded animal may reclaim the animal by signing any citations issued for alleged violations of this chapter and paying all impoundment fees, fines and other accrued expenses, under following conditions: 
(1)  If the owner of any impounded animal pursuant to this chapter shall appear to claim the animal within three business days of notice of impoundment, the animal control officer shall, if he/she reasonably believes that such person is the true owner, turn such animal over to such person upon payment to the animal control officer of a fee for each day that such animal has been impounded. The fees shall be collected by the animal control officer and remitted to the city finance department. 
(2)  The animal control officer shall, upon impoundment, attempt to call the owner of any impounded dog or cat that is identified by a collar or harness with the city's registration tag attached or by an implanted microchip. 
(3)  If the impounded animal is a dog or cat that is not identified by wearing a collar with a valid license tag attached or by a duly registered implanted microchip, the owner of the dog or cat must present a certificate showing that the dog or cat has been vaccinated in accordance with state law from that date or shall have the dog or cat vaccinated prior to its release from impoundment and must provide or secure a valid license for such dog or cat. The license tag is to be attached to the dog or cat's collar. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-9. - Disposal of unredeemed, impounded animals. 
    The animal control officer shall have authority to dispose of in accordance with state law all animals impounded in animal shelter. 
(1)  Any person wishing to adopt an impounded animal shall pay appropriate fees. The prospective owner shall be required to have any dog or cat altered, properly vaccinated and licensed at his/her own expense. 
(2)  The animal control officer may sell the animal impounded and remit the proceeds to city finance department. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-10. - Destruction of impounded animals. 
    If no purchaser or owner can be found for any animal impounded pursuant to this section, the animal control officer is authorized to humanely destroy such animal and to have the carcass destroyed. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-11. - Records and reports of animal control officer. 
    The animal control officer shall record a description of all animals impounded by him/her pursuant to this chapter. record shall show date of impoundment, return to owner, or of sale; the name of owner, if known; and name of purchaser or adopter. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
DIVISION 3. - RABIES CONTROL 

Sec. 6-12. - Suspicion of rabies when person bitten. 
(a)  If any dog or other animal has bitten any person, the owner of the animal shall immediately, and in any event not later than 24 hours after such biting, notify an animal control officer of such biting and have the dog or other animal quarantined according to the discretion of an animal control officer: in the city animal shelter or a veterinary hospital in the city or in the home of the owner for a period ten days. No such animal so held for observation shall be released from impoundment without authorization from the animal control department. Such impoundment shall be at the expense of the owner of the animal. 
(b)  If, however, at the time of the biting the dog or other animal was duly licensed, properly identified and was lawfully restrained as required by article III of this chapter, expense of confinement shall be against the person so bitten. If such person is on the premises with express or implied consent of the owner, such as delivery persons, guests, post office personnel, utility meter readers, etc., cost of confinement shall be at owner's expense. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-13. - Suspicion of rabies when animal bitten. 
(a)  The owner of any dog or other animal suffering a bite from a rabid animal or suspected or believed to have been bitten by a rabid animal shall, within 24 hours from the time of such biting, notify an animal control officer and have the dog or other animal administered proper treatment or destroyed. 
(b)  When the owner desires to have proper treatment administered to the animal, confinement shall be under the direction and supervision of an animal control officer, who shall direct the manner and means by which the dog or other animal shall be confined, confinement to be for a period of at least ten days and at owner's expense. 
(c)  Such dog or other animal shall be released only by order of an animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
ARTICLE II. - CARE OF ANIMALS 

Sec. 6-14. - Proper care. 
    Every owner or other person having care and control of any animal shall provide following for each animal under his or her care and control: 
(1)  Sufficient nutritious and wholesome food, served to the animal in clean containers, to maintain the animal in good health; 
(2)  Clean potable water, served to the animal in a clean container, such water to be available to the animal at all times; 
(3)  Adequate shelter and protection from weather at all times; 
(4)  Veterinary care as needed to prevent suffering. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-15. - Inhumane treatment in general prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to treat any animal in any manner that causes or permits unjustified or unwarranted pain or suffering, including torturing an animal, beating an animal, or overworking an animal. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-16. - Abandonment. 
    It is a violation of this chapter for any person to dump or abandon any animal on any property, whether public or private, within the City of Nacogdoches. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-17. - Animals in vehicles. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to leave an animal in a vehicle under such conditions or for such period of time as may endanger the health or well-being of such animal due to heat, cold, lack of food or water, or such other circumstances as may reasonably be expected to cause suffering, disability or death. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to transport or convey any animal in an open vehicle without making provisions to prevent said animal from jumping from or being thrown from said vehicle or conveyance, or being otherwise injured. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-18. - Tethering; restrictions and requirements. 
(a)  No unattended animal shall be tethered by any means on any public property such as city parks or utility easements, or public access private property without property owner's consent. 
(b)  Any tethered animal in an enclosure shall have continuous access to shade and water, and have unrestricted access to a wind and moisture proof shelter. 
(c)  Any tethered animal shall be arranged so that the tethering device cannot become entangled in such a way as to prevent access to shade, water and shelter. 
(d)  The tether used must be at least ten feet in length or five times the length of the dog, as measured from the tip of the dog's nose to the base of the dog's tail, whichever is greater; it must be attached to a running line, pulley or trolley system, and equipped with swivel ends, positioned in such a manner as to prevent the animal from becoming entangled with any obstruction, from partially or totally jumping any fence, or from leaving any part of its owner's property, and must be secured to the animal using a properly fitted collar or harness. 
(e)  Choke type, pinch type or prong type collars may not be used to tether the animal. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
State Law reference- V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 821.076 et seq. 
Sec. 6-19. - Fighting, fighting paraphernalia prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful to cause any animal to fight with another. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, or use, or in any way be connected with, or interested in the management of any place used for the purpose of fighting animals. It shall be unlawful for any person to receive money for the admission of any person to any place kept or used for the purpose of fighting animals, or to permit or suffer any place belonging to or under his control to be so kept or used. It shall be unlawful for any person to aid, encourage, assist or arrange for an animal to fight, or to issue a challenge for the purpose of bringing about an animal fight. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to have on their person or property any paraphernalia used in fighting. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to raise, breed, maintain, or harbor any animal, which is used or intended to be used for fighting. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-20. - Trapping. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or set any trap or to trap any animal by any form of trap other than a humane live cage trap as specifically authorized by the animal control department. 
    Any trap placed or set in violation of this chapter shall be impounded by the animal control officer or the police. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-21. - Tripping of horses prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to trip a horse. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-22. - Sanitation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any pen, enclosure, pound or area for any animal in a manner that is a nuisance or threat to the health or safely of the public. 
(b)  The keeper of any pen shall be responsible for pickup and disposal of all animal feces found in such pen. Feces must be removed often enough so that there is no odor or fly attraction which would disturb a person of normal sensibilities or to constitute a health hazard to humans or animals. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-23. - Running at large. 
(a)  No animal shall be allowed to run at large and cause a nuisance. The owner of every animal shall be held responsible for every behavior of such animal under provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  An animal shall be considered a nuisance if it damages, soils, defiles or defecates on private property other than the owner's or on public walks and recreation areas unless such waste is immediately removed and properly disposed of by the owner; causes unsanitary, dangerous or offensive conditions; causes a disturbance by excessive barking or other noisemaking; or chases vehicles, or molests, attacks or interferes with persons or other domestic animals on public property or private property other than that of the owner. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-24. - Animal in heat. 
    Any person who owns, harbors or keeps any female dog or cat shall, during the period such animal is in heat, keep such dog or cat in a secured area and in such a manner as to prevent a male dog or cat from having access to such female except for controlled breeding permitted by the owner of the female. Additionally, the female dog or cat shall not be restrained in a manner that prevents her from defending herself or from avoiding a male. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Secs. 6-25-6-29. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS AND CATS 

Sec. 6-30. - Dogs and unaltered cats under restraint. 
    Dogs and unaltered cats must be under restraint at all times. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-31. - Rabies vaccination required. 
    Every owner of a dog or cat four months of age or older shall have such animal vaccinated against rabies in accordance with state law. Any person moving into the city from a location outside the city shall comply with this chapter within ten days after having moved into the city. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-32. - License required. 
    Every resident that owns or harbors a dog or cat within the corporate limits shall obtain a license for the animal from the city. 
    Participating veterinarians may issue city license upon administering rabies vaccine. Veterinarians may retain $1.00 for each city license issued and shall remit said license fees to the city on a monthly basis providing description and name of the animal, license number, name of animal owner, address and phone number. 
(1)  Dog and cat licenses shall be issued by the city upon payment of the license fee, and presentation of a properly completed application for license and a certificate from a licensed veterinarian showing that the dog or cat has been vaccinated for rabies and that the vaccination is current according to state law. Animals less than four months and 30 days or age are exempt. The application for dog or cat licenses shall be upon printed forms furnished by the city for such purpose and shall require: 
a.  Name, address, phone number and email address, if available, of the owner; and 
b.  Name, breed and sex of the dog or cat; and 
c.  The number of any implanted microchip. 
For a dog or cat that is not registered or reregistered within ten days from the expiration date of the license or when otherwise required, a penalty, may be assessed in addition to the licensing fee. 
(2)  Members of managed feral cat colonies are considered licensed. 
(3)  Term. Dog and cat licenses shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of issuance. 
(4)  Tag. Upon compliance by the owner of a dog or cat with registration and licensing requirements of this chapter, the owner shall be issued a license certificate and a metallic tag for each dog or cat so licensed. 
(5)  Duplicates. If a dog or cat tag is lost or destroyed, a duplicate will be issued by the city upon presentation of a receipt showing payment of the license fee for current time, presentation of a certificate showing that the dog or cat has been vaccinated within one year of date thereof, and the payment of a fee for such duplicate. 
(6)  Transferability refunds. Dog or cat tags shall not be transferable from one dog or cat to another, and no refunds shall be made on any dog or cat license fee because of the death of a dog or cat or the owner's leaving the city before expiration of the license period. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-33. - Identification required. 
(a)  Dogs and pet cats. The owner of a dog or cat shall see that such dog or cat has proper identification: 
(1)  A collar or harness to which the license tag required by this chapter shall be affixed, worn by the dog or cat at all times; and/or 
(2)  An implanted microchip. 
(b)  Members of managed feral cat colonies are identified by ear-tipping. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-34. - Limitation on number of dogs and cats. 
    No person shall keep or harbor more than five dogs or five cats or any combination of five dogs and cats without obtaining a permit to maintain a multiple pet household or to operate a kennel. For purposes of this section, a maximum of one litter of puppies or kittens less than four months of age may be excluded from the count. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-35. - Multi-pet household. 
    Any person wishing to keep more than five dogs or five cats or five dogs and cats in any combination, and who does not possess a commercial business permit, may apply for a multi-pet permit. The multi-pet permit will be issued only if the applicant meets all provisions of this chapter. The permit shall be valid for one year from date of issuance. Upon inspection of premises, the permit shall be issued if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  All animals over four months of age must be altered; 
(2)  The facility must be adequate for number and type of animals to be kept. Facility must be of sufficient size as to allow animals to move about freely. This shall apply to each animal kept. Size of facility shall be in proportion to the size of the individual animal's height and weight; 
(3)  The premises must be kept in sanitary condition and free of odor or stench which would be offensive to person of ordinary sensibilities; 
(4)  The animals must be maintained in a manner, which does not pose a danger to the health of animals themselves, or to adjacent animals; 
(5)  The animals must not cause noise, which is offensive or disturbing to person of ordinary sensibilities; 
(6)  The applicant or holder of the permit shall not have been issued citations for violation of this chapter on two separate occasions, or animals covered by or to be covered by permit have not been impounded on two separate occasions. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Secs. 6-36-6-39 - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - LIVESTOCK, SWINE AND WILD ANIMALS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1626-5-13, adopted May 7, 2013, changed the title of Art. IV from "Livestock, swine and other farm animals" to "Livestock, swine and wild animals". 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 6-40. - Registration of livestock. 
    All livestock kept inside the city must be registered with the Nacogdoches Animal Services and Adoption Center. Owner's information, including two contact emergency phone numbers must be provided. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-41. - Pens and structures. 
    All livestock kept under this section shall be provided a stable, shed, pen, or other structure of adequate size for the storage, shelter, and safekeeping of such animals. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-42. - Space required for livestock. 
    Every owner or keeper of any livestock, except swine, shall provide a minimum of 10,000 square feet for each animal. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-43. - Proximity of livestock to buildings. 
    No allowable livestock shall be kept or allowed to be within 150 feet of any inhabited house, public meeting place, or business, except that of the owner or caretaker thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-44. - Riding or leading horse, mule, and cattle on sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to ride or lead any horse, mule or cattle of any kind on any sidewalk or walking path in the city. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-45. - Keeping of swine. 
    No person shall keep any swine, or build or maintain any swine pen within the city. The keeping of any swine within the city constitutes a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
DIVISION 2. - FOWL 

Sec. 6-46. - Operation, maintenance of chicken houses. 
    Operation and maintenance within the city of any broiler house, brooder house or chicken house, for commercial purposes or under crowded and concentrated conditions, is declared to constitute a public nuisance, and any person who shall maintain the nuisance shall be punished. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-47. - Location of pens for fowl. 
    Any chickens or other fowl shall be kept in a pen which is located no closer than 100 feet from any city street. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Secs. 6-48, 6-49. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - WILD ANIMALS 

Sec. 6-50. - Keeping certain animals-Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor or maintain within the city limits the following animals: 
(1)  Bats; 
(2)  Skunks; 
(3)  Any wild animal whose normal mature weight exceeds 40 pounds; 
(4)  Any dangerous wild animal as defined in [V.T.C.A.] chapter 822, health and safety code. 
(Ord. No. 1626-5-13, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 6-51. - Keeping certain animals-Prohibited-Exceptions. 
    The provisions of section 6-50 shall not apply to or prohibit the keeping of wild animals by the following: 
(1)  A publicly- or privately-owned zoo meeting the definition of a zoo as stated in section 118-1. 
(2)  Publicly- or privately-maintained circus, traveling show or rodeo which does not remain in this city for longer than 30 days out of each year. 
(3)  Hospitals, clinics and other premises operated by licensed veterinarians for the care and treatment of animals. 
(Ord. No. 1626-5-13, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 6-52. - Restraint of wild animals. 
    It shall be the duty of each owner of a wild animal in the city to keep the same under restraint at all times. 
(Ord. No. 1626-5-13, 5-7-2013) 
Secs. 6-53-6-59. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - DANGEROUS DOGS 

Sec. 6-60. - General regulations. 
    No person who owns or keeps a dangerous dog shall allow the dog to engage in fierce or dangerous conduct. A dog engages in fierce or dangerous conduct when it threatens to attack or terrorizes a person or other animal on public or private property or in a public place, or has behaved in such a manner that the person who keeps the dog knows, or should reasonably know, that the dog has a known propensity to attack or bite and occurs in a place other than a secure enclosure in which the animal was being kept. This section shall apply subject to the defenses listed in V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § [822.006]. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-61. - Defense. 
    Upon attack by a dangerous dog, the animal control department may defend himself/herself, a complainant or property at the officer's discretion, taking such means as is necessary in that situation. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-62. - Unattended guard dog prohibited. 
    Except for dogs used in law enforcement by law enforcement agencies, it shall be unlawful to place or maintain any dog which is specifically trained to attack in any area for the protection of persons or property unless the dog is physically confined to a secure enclosure, as defined in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-63. - Investigation. 
    Upon receiving a report concerning a dangerous dog, the animal control officer or police officer shall obtain the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the complainant. 
(2)  Date, time and location of incident. 
(3)  Specification of the facts and circumstances of the incident. 
(4)  Description of the animal. 
(5)  A sworn statement describing how the animal behaved in a vicious manner. 
(6)  A description of other aggravating facts or circumstances, if any, relating to the incident. 
After a sworn statement has been obtained, the dog shall be investigated by the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-64. - Knowledge of ownership of a dangerous animal. 
    A person learns that he/she is the owner of a dangerous dog when the owner knows of an attack described in the definition of dangerous dog, or the owner is informed by the animal control authority that the dog is dangerous or the owner receives notice that a justice court, county court, or municipal court has found that the dog is a dangerous dog under V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 822.0423. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-65. - Appeal. 
    An owner, no later than the 15th day after the date he/she is notified that an animal owned by him/her is a dangerous animal may appeal the determination of the animal control department to municipal court. An owner may appeal the decision of municipal court in the same manner as appeal for other civil cases. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-66. - Requirements for owner of a dangerous dog. 
    Not later than the 30th day after it has been determined that a person is the owner of a dangerous dog, the person shall comply with all requirements set out in state law V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §§ 822.042 and 822.043. In addition, the following requirement and restrictions shall apply to any dog in the city determined to be a dangerous dog: 
(1)  The dog must be altered within ten days of the determination that the dog is dangerous. 
(2)  If the dog is subsequently responsible for the death of or serious injury to any person or animal, the dog will be destroyed pursuant to this chapter. 
(3)  The owner or person harboring a dangerous dog shall have the animal identified by a numbered tattoo, numbered ear-tipping, or other identifier approved by the animal control authority, and all identifying information shall be provided to the animal control authority immediately. 
(4)  The dog shall at all times wear a collar and attached tag marked with an orange color visible at a minimum distance of 50 feet. 
(5)  The dog, when taken outside the enclosure required in this chapter, must be securely muzzled in a manner that will not cause injury to the dog or impair its vision or respiration, but shall prevent it from biting any person or animal, and must be restrained by a substantial chain or cable leash having a minimum tensile strength of 1,000 pounds and not to exceed six feet in length. 
(6)  The owner or person harboring such a dog shall keep the dog in a secure enclosure, as defined in this chapter. 
(7)  The animal control department may, as a condition of registration for the dog, require of the owner or person harboring the dog, annual attendance of a class on responsible pet ownership conducted by the city animal control department or its designee. 
(8)  The city animal control department may inspect the enclosure in which any dangerous dog is maintained, without notice, at any reasonable hour. 
(9)  The city may charge a reasonable fee for the licensing of dangerous dogs. 
10)  The owner of any dangerous dog must register the animal with the city within ten days of bringing the animal into this jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-67. - Seizure of a dog determined to be dangerous. 
(a)  If a justice court, county court, or municipal court finds that owner of a dangerous dog has failed to comply with the requirements for the owner of a dangerous dog, the court shall order the animal control authority to seize the dog and shall issue a warrant authorizing the seizure. The authority shall seize the dog or order its seizure and shall provide for the impoundment of the dog in secure and humane conditions. 
(b)  The owner shall pay any cost or fee assessed by the municipality or county related to the seizure, acceptance, impoundment, or destruction of the dog. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-68. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - ANIMAL FACILITIES; BREEDERS, KENNELS, PET SHOPS 

Sec. 6-69. - Definitions. 
    Kennel means any place or premises, other than a veterinary hospital or humane society, wherein any person boards, breeds, buys, lets for hire, trains for a fee, trades or sells dogs or cats. Any person, group of persons or business entity that in any calendar year sells more than a single adult dog or cat one year or older or produces and sells more than one litter of puppies or kittens shall be considered as operating a kennel. 
    Limited breeder means any person that breeds or allows his or her animal, whether purebred or mixed breed, to produce offspring. To qualify as a limited breeder, the breeder in any calendar year must sell no more than a single adult dog or cat one year or older, or produce and sell no more than a single litter of dogs or cats. 
    Pet shop means any establishment where dogs and cats are bought, sold or traded. The term includes all establishments selling dogs or cats exclusively or buying, selling or trading dogs or cats along with other animals. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-71. - Kennels and pet shops; permit required. 
    Any person, persons or establishments operating a kennel or operating a pet shop must apply for a permit, subject to the conditions enumerated in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-72. - Revocation or suspension of license. 
    Any breeder, kennel or pet shop found to be in violation of any zoning law, health law or any other applicable city or state ordinance, or if the facility is maintained in such a manner as to be detrimental to the health, safety or peace of mind of persons residing in the immediate vicinity, may have its permit suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 6-73. - Sales permit required. 
    All persons engaged in commercial sale of any animals, domestic or otherwise, including, but not limited to, pet stores and stores in which pets and animals are not the central item of sale within the store such as department stores, drugstores and convenience stores, must apply for a commercial sales permit. The commercial sales permit shall be issued provided the applicant meets all provisions of this chapter. The fee shall be set by the city council and shall be valid for one year from the date of issuance. Those persons currently engaged in selling animals in the aforementioned manner are required to apply for a commercial sales permit immediately. Any advertising must include [a] permit number. Upon inspection by the animal control officer of the premises where the animals are bred or sold, the permit shall be issued if the following conditions are met: 
(1)  Facilities in which animals are stored or housed must be adequate for number and type of animals kept. Facilities shall be of sufficient size as to allow animals to move about freely. This shall apply to each animal kept. Size of facility shall be in proportion to size of each individual animal's height and weight. 
(2)  Adequate food and water must be provided so that any and all animals kept shall be maintained in good health and free of malnutrition and/or dehydration. 
(3)  Premises shall be kept in sanitary condition and reasonably free of animal waste, parasites, insects and flies that could be harmful to the animal's health and/or to the health of the general public. 
(4)  Animals and facility must be kept free of odor or stench, which is offensive to a person of ordinary sensibilities. 
(5)  Animals must be maintained in a manner, which does not pose a danger to the health of the animals themselves, or adjacent animals. 
(6)  Animals must not cause noise, which is offensive or disturbing to a person of ordinary sensibilities on adjoining, adjacent, or neighboring premises. 
(7)  The applicant for permit has not been issued citations for violation of this chapter on three separate occasions within a one-year period. 
a.  Limited breeders shall be issued a limited breeder disposal permit in order to sell any puppies or kittens on public or private property within the city limits. No private breeder may sell any dog, cat or pet animal in the city limits without such a disposal permit. A licensed veterinarian must verify the basic health of the animal(s) before a permit is issued. Any advertising must include the permit number. 
b.  Any person or group of person offering or advertising for sale or trade a dog or cat within the city, whether or not the person resides within the city, must demonstrate compliance with the conditions for the appropriate sales permit as described in this chapter. Any advertising must include the permit number. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 6-74. - Revocation of sales permit. 
    The commercial sales permit may be revoked by the animal control department if upon investigation, it is determined that the permit holder has failed to adhere to any conditions of this chapter. Once the permit has been revoked, the facility whose permit has been revoked may not reapply for a period of six months and shall not engage in sale of animals as described in this chapter for said period. 
    Upon revocation of the commercial sales permit, the owner of the animals covered in the revoked permit is to remove those animals from the city within ten days and notify the animal control department of the location to which they will be moved. If the owner does not comply with removal of animals within this ten-day period, the animal control department shall have authority to remove the animals for impoundment. 
(Ord. No. 1495-7-08, 7-15-2008)
