ARTICLE III. - AIRPORT ZONING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Zoning, ch. 118. 
State Law reference- Airport zoning act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.001 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-86. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Airport means A. L. Mangham, Jr. Regional Airport. 
    Airport elevation means the established elevation of the highest point on the usable landing area measured in feet from mean sea level. The elevation of A. L. Mangham, Jr. Regional Airport is 355 feet above mean sea level located on the runway centerline at the end of runway 33. 
    Airport hazard means any structure or tree or use of land which obstructs the airspace required for the flight of aircraft or which obstructs or interferes with the control or tracking and/or data acquisition in the landing, taking off or flight at an airport, or at any installation or facility relating to flight, and tracking and/or data acquisition of the flight craft; which is hazardous, interferes with or obstructs such landing, taking off or flight of aircraft or which is hazardous to or interferes with tracking and/or data acquisition pertaining to flight and flight vehicles. 
    Airport hazard area means any area of land or water upon which an airport hazard might be established if not prevented as provided by this article. 
    Airport reference point means the point established as the approximate geographic center of the airport landing area and so designated. The airport reference point (ARP) for A. L. Mangham, Jr. Regional Airport is latitude 31° 34' 36.88? N; longitude 94° 42' 34.02? W. 
    Approach surface means a surface longitudinally centered on the extended runway centerline, extending outward and upward from the end of the primary surface and at the same slope as the approach zone height limitation slope set forth in section 10-92. In plan the perimeter of the approach surface coincides with the perimeter of the approach zone. 
    Approach, transitional, horizontal, and conical zones mean the zones set forth in section 10-91. 
    Board of adjustment means a board consisting of five members appointed by the city council as provided by V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.032. 
    Conical surface means a surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of the horizontal surface at a slope of 20:1 for a horizontal distance of 4,000 feet. 
    Hazard to air navigation means an obstruction determined to have a substantial adverse effect on the safe and efficient utilization of the navigable airspace. 
    Height. For the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this article and shown on the zoning map, the datum shall be mean sea level elevation. 
    Horizontal surface means a horizontal plane 150 feet above established airport elevation, the perimeter of which in plan coincides with the perimeter of the horizontal zone. 
    Joint airport zoning board means a board consisting of seven members, two members appointed by the city council, two members appointed by the commissioners court of Nacogdoches County, Texas, and two members appointed by the commissioners court of Angelina County, Texas. The six members so appointed shall elect a seventh member who shall serve as chair of the Nacogdoches-Nacogdoches County-Angelina County Joint Airport Zoning Board. 
    Landing area means the surface area of the airport used for the landing, takeoff or taxiing of aircraft. 
    Nonconforming use means any preexisting structure, object of natural growth, or use of land which is inconsistent with this article or an amendment to this article. 
    Nonprecision instrument runway means a runway having an existing instrument approach procedure utilizing air navigation facilities with only horizontal guidance, or area-type navigation equipment, for which a straight-in nonprecision instrument approach procedure has been approved or planned. 
    Obstruction means any structure, growth, or other object, including a mobile object, which exceeds a limiting height set forth in section 10-92. 
    Person means an individual, firm, partnership, corporation, company, association, joint stock association, or body politic, and includes a trustee, receiver, assignee, administrator, executor, guardian, or other representative. 
    Precision instrument runway means a runway having an existing instrument approach procedure utilizing an instrument landing system (ILS), a microwave instrument landing system (MLS), or a precision approach radar (PAR). It also means a runway for which a precision approach system is planned and is so indicated on an approved airport layout plan (ALP) or any other planning document. 
    Primary surface means a surface longitudinally centered on a runway. When the runway has a specially prepared hard surface, the primary surface extends 200 feet beyond each end of that runway; but when the runway has no specially prepared hard surface or planned hard surface, the primary surface ends at each end of that runway. The width of the primary surface of a runway will be that width prescribed in part 77 of the Federal Aviation Regulations (FAR) for the most precise approach existing or planned for either end of that runway. The elevation of any point on the primary surface is the same as the elevation of the nearest point on the runway centerline. The width of the primary surface for other than utility runways is as follows: 
(1)  For nonprecision instrument runways having visibility minimums greater than three-fourths of a statute mile, 500 feet. 
(2)  For nonprecision instrument runways with visibility minimums as low as three-fourths of a statute mile, and for precision instrument runways, 1,000 feet. 
    Runway means a defined area on an airport prepared for landing and takeoff of aircraft along its length. 
    Structure means an object, including a mobile object, constructed or installed by man, including but not limited to buildings, towers, cranes, smokestacks, earth formations, and overhead transmission lines. 
    Transitional surfaces means the surfaces extending outward at 90-degree angles to the runway centerline and the runway centerline extended at a slope of seven feet horizontally for each foot vertically from the sides of the primary and approach surfaces to where they intersect the horizontal surface. 
    Tree means any object of natural growth. 
(Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-87. - Enforcement; applications for permits and variances. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the city planner to administer and enforce the regulations prescribed in this article. 
(b)  Applications for permits shall be made to the city planner upon forms published for that purpose. 
(c)  Applications required by this article to be submitted to the city planner shall be promptly considered and granted or denied. 
(d)  Applications for variances shall be made to the board of adjustment by first filing the application for variance with the city planner, who shall forthwith transmit the application to the board of adjustment for determination. 
Sec. 10-88. - Enforcement remedies. 
    The city council may institute in any court of competent jurisdiction an action to prevent, restrain, correct or abate any violation of this article or of any order or ruling made in connection with its administration or enforcement, including but not limited to an action for injunctive relief as provided by the airport zoning act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.044. 
(Ord. No. 1534-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-89. - Penalties for violations. 
    Each violation of this article or of any regulation, order, or ruling promulgated under this article shall, upon conviction, be punishable by a fine as provided in section 1-14. 
Sec. 10-90. - Conflicting regulations. 
    Where there exists a conflict between any of the regulations or limitations prescribed in this article and any other regulations applicable to the same area, whether the conflict is with respect to the height of structures or trees, the use of land, or any other matter, the more stringent limitation or requirement shall govern and prevail as provided by the airport zoning act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.901. 
Sec. 10-91. - Zones. 
    In order to carry out this article, there are created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying beneath the approach surfaces, transition surfaces, horizontal surface and conical surface as they apply to the airport. Such zones are shown on the hazard zoning map consisting of one sheet, prepared by the state department of aviation and dated August 30, 1991, which is incorporated by reference in this article and made a part of this article. An area located in more than one of the following zones is considered to be only in the zone with the more restrictive height limitation. The various zones are established and defined as follows: 
(1)  Approach zones. Approach zones shall be as follow: 
a.  Runway 36. The approach zone is established beneath the approach surface at the end of runway 36 on the airport for precision instrument landings and takeoffs. The inner edge of the approach zone shall have a width of 1,000 feet which coincides with the width of the primary surface at a distance of 200 feet beyond the end of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 16,000 feet at a horizontal distance of 50,000 feet beyond the end of the primary surface, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
b.  Runway 18. The approach zone is established beneath the approach surface at the end of runway 18 on the airport for nonprecision instrument landings and takeoffs with visibility minimums greater than three-fourths of a statute mile. The inner edge of the approach zone shall have a width of 1,000 feet which coincides with the width of the primary surface at the end of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 3,500 feet at a horizontal distance of 10,000 feet beyond the end of the primary surface, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway. 
c.  Runway 15-33. The approach zone is established beneath the approach surfaces at the ends of runway 15-33 on the airport for nonprecision instrument landings and takeoffs with visibility minimums greater than three-fourths of a statute mile. The inner edge of the approach zones shall have a width of 500 feet which coincides with the width of the primary surface at the ends of the runway, widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 3,500 feet at a horizontal distance of 10,000 feet beyond the ends of the primary surface, its centerline being the continuation of the centerline on the runway. 
(2)  Transition zones. Transition zones are established beneath the transition surfaces adjacent to each runway and approach surfaces as indicated on the zoning map. Transition surfaces, symmetrically located on either side of the runways, have variable widths as shown on the zoning map. Transitional surfaces extend outward and upward at right angles to the runway centerline and the runway centerline extended at a slope of 7:1 from the sides of the primary surface and from the sides of the approach surfaces. 
(3)  Horizontal zone. The horizontal zone is the area beneath a horizontal plane 150 feet above the established airport elevation, the perimeter of which is constructed by swinging arcs of 10,000 feet radii from the center of each end of the primary surface of runway 18-36 and connecting the adjacent arcs by lines tangent to those arcs. 
(4)  Conical zone. The conical zone is the area beneath the conical surface extending outward and upward from the periphery of the horizontal surface at a slope of 20:1 for a horizontal distance of 4,000 feet. 
Sec. 10-92. - Height limitations. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, no structure shall be erected, altered, or maintained, and no tree shall be allowed to grow in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the applicable height limit established in this section for such a zone. Such applicable height limitations are established for each of the zones in question as follows: 
(1)  Approach zones. Height limits for approach zones are as follow: 
a.  Runway 36. The height limits are one foot in height for each 50 feet in horizontal distance beginning at the end of and at the elevation of the primary surface and extending to a point 10,000 feet from the end of the primary surface, then rising one foot in height for each 40 feet in horizontal distance for an additional 40,000 feet. 
b.  Runway 18. The height limits are one foot in height for each 34 feet in horizontal distance beginning at the end of and at the elevation of the primary surface and extending to a point 10,000 feet from the end of the primary surface. 
c.  Runway 15-33. The height limits are one foot in height for each 34 feet in horizontal distance beginning at the end of and at the elevation of the primary surface and extending to a point 10,000 feet from the end of the primary surface. 
(2)  Transition zone. The transition zone slopes seven feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the primary surface and the approach surface and extending to a height of 150 feet above the airport elevation, which is 355 feet above mean sea level. In addition, there are established height limits sloping seven feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface and extending to where they intersect the horizontal and conical surface. Where the precision instrument runway approach zone projects beyond the conical zone, there are established height limits sloping seven feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the sides of and at the same elevation as the approach surface and extending a horizontal distance of 5,000 feet measured at 90-degree angles to the extended runway centerline. 
(3)  Horizontal zone. The horizontal zone is established at 150 feet above the airport elevation, or a height of 505 feet above mean sea level. 
(4)  Conical zone. The conical zone slopes 20 feet outward for each foot upward beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zone and at 150 feet above the airport elevation and extending to a height of 350 feet above the airport elevation, which is 705 feet above mean sea level. 
(b)  Excepted height limitations. Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the growth, construction or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height up to 50 feet above the surface of the land. 
Sec. 10-93. - Land use restrictions. 
    Notwithstanding any other section of this article, no use may be made of land or water within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to: 
(1)  Create electrical interference with navigational signals or radio communication between the airport and aircraft; 
(2)  Make it difficult for pilots to distinguish between airport lights and others; 
(3)  Result in glare in the eyes of pilots using the airport; 
(4)  Impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport; 
(5)  Create bird strike hazards; or 
(6)  Otherwise in any way endanger or interfere with the landing, taking off, or maneuvering of aircraft intending to use the airport. 
Secs. 10-94-10-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 10-121. - Obstruction marking and lighting. 
    Any permit or variance granted pursuant to this article may, if such action is deemed advisable by the city planner or the board of adjustment to effectuate the purpose of this article and be reasonable in the circumstances, be so conditioned as to require the owner of the structure or tree in question to allow the city planner to install, operate, and maintain, at the expense of the city, such markings and lights as may be necessary. 
Secs. 10-122-10-145. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Board of Adjustment 

Sec. 10-146. - Created; powers. 
    There is created a board of adjustment to have and exercise the power to: 
(1)  Hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the city planner in the enforcement of this article. 
(2)  Hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this article upon which such board of adjustment under such regulations may be required to pass. 
(3)  Hear and decide specific variances. 
Sec. 10-147. - Composition; terms; removal. 
    The board of adjustment shall consist of five members appointed by the city council. Each member shall serve for a term of two years and shall be removable for cause by the city council upon written charges, after a public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 1534-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 10-148. - Rules of procedure. 
(a)  The board of adjustment shall adopt rules for its governance and procedure in harmony with this article. 
(b)  Meetings of the board of adjustment shall be held at the call of the chair and at such times as the board of adjustment may determine. 
(c)  The chair or, in his absence, the acting chair may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. 
(d)  All hearings of the board of adjustment shall be public. 
(e)  The board of adjustment shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question or, if absent or falling to vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions, all of which shall immediately be filed in the office of the city secretary and shall be public records. 
Sec. 10-149. - Decisions. 
(a)  The board of adjustment shall make written findings of fact and conclusions of law stating the facts upon which it relied when making its legal conclusions in reversing, affirming, or modifying any order, requirement, decision, or determination which comes before it under this article. 
(b)  The concurring vote of four members of the board of adjustment shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision, or determination of the city planner or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under this article or to effect any variation in this article as provided in V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.032(d). 
Sec. 10-150. - Appeals. 
(a)  Any person aggrieved or any taxpayer affected by any decision of the city planner made in his administration of this article, if of the opinion that a decision of the city planner is an improper application of this article, may appeal to the board of adjustment. 
(b)  All appeals under this article must be taken within a reasonable time, as provided by the rules of the board of adjustment, by filing with the city planner a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof. The city planner shall forthwith transmit to the board of adjustment all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken. 
(c)  An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the city planner certifies to the board of adjustment, after the notice of appeal has been filed with it, that because of the facts stated in the certificate, a stay would, in the opinion of the city planner, cause imminent peril to life or property. In such case, proceedings shall not be stayed except by order of the board of adjustment on notice to the city planner and on due cause shown. 
(d)  The board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for hearing appeals, shall give public notice and due notice to the parties in interest, and shall decide the appeal within a reasonable time. Upon hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney. 
(e)  The board of adjustment may, in conformity with this article, reverse or affirm, in whole or in part, or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision or determination, as may be appropriate under the circumstances. 
Sec. 10-151. - Judicial review. 
    Any person aggrieved or any taxpayer affected by any decision of the board of adjustment may appeal to a court of competent jurisdiction, as provided by the airport zoning act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 241.041. 
Secs. 10-152-10-175. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Permits 

Sec. 10-176. - Future uses 
(a)  Except as specifically provided in subsection (b) of this section, no material change shall be made in the use of land that would create a hazardous condition as described in section 10-93, no structure shall be erected or otherwise established, and no tree shall be permitted to grow in any zone created in this article in excess of the excepted height limitation allowed in subsection 10-92(b), unless a permit thereafter shall have been applied for and granted. Each application for a permit shall indicate the purpose for which the permit is desired, with sufficient particularity to permit it to be determined whether the resulting use, structure, or tree would conform to the regulations prescribed in this article. If such determination is in the affirmative, the permit shall be granted. No permit for a use inconsistent with this article shall be granted unless a variance has been approved in accordance with section 10-206. 
(b)  Exceptions to subsection (a) of this section are as follow: 
(1)  In the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and conical zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 75 feet of vertical height above the ground, except when, because of terrain, land contour, or topographic features, such tree or structure would extend above the height limits prescribed for such zones. 
(2)  In areas lying within the limits of the approach zones, but at a horizontal distance of not less than 4,200 feet from each end of the runways, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 75 feet of vertical height above the ground, except when such tree or structure would extend above the height limit prescribed for such approach zones. 
(3)  In the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zone, no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 75 feet above the ground, except when such tree or structure, because of land contour or topographic features, would extend above the height limit prescribed for such transition zone. 
(c)  Nothing contained in any of the exceptions in subsection (b) of this section shall be construed as permitting or intending to permit any construction or alteration of any structure or growth of any tree in excess of any height limits established by this article, except as set forth in subsection 10-92(b). 
Sec. 10-177. - Existing uses. 
    No permit shall be granted that would allow the establishment or creation of any airport hazard or permit a nonconforming use, structure, or tree to be made or become higher or become a greater hazard to air navigation than it was on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives or any amendments to this article or than it is when the application for a permit is made. Except as indicated, each application for such permit shall be granted. 
Sec. 10-178. - Nonconforming uses abandoned or destroyed. 
    Whenever the city planner determines that a nonconforming structure or tree has been abandoned or more than 80 percent torn down, physically deteriorated, or decayed, no permit shall be granted that would allow such structure or tree to exceed the applicable height limit or otherwise deviate from the zoning regulations in this article. 
Secs. 10-179-10-205. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Variances 

Sec. 10-206. - Application; grant or denial. 
(a)  Any person desiring to erect or increase the height of any structure or permit the growth of any tree or use his property in violation of the regulations prescribed in this article may apply to the board of adjustment for a variance of such regulations in question. 
(b)  The application for a variance shall be accompanied by a determination from the Federal Aviation Administration as to the effect of the proposal on the operation of air navigation facilities and the safe, efficient use of navigable airspace. 
(c)  Such variance shall be allowed where it is duly found that a literal application or enforcement of this article will result in unnecessary hardship and the relief granted would not be contrary to the public interest, but do substantial justice, and be in accordance with the spirit of this article. Additionally, no application for variance to this article may be considered by the board of adjustment unless a copy of the application has been furnished to the airport advisory board for advice as to the aeronautical effects of the variance. If the airport advisory board does not respond to the application within 15 days after receipt, the board of adjustment may act on its own to grant or deny the application. 
Secs. 10-207-10-230. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - NONCONFORMING USES 

Sec. 10-231. - Existing structures or trees. 
    The sections of this article shall not be construed to require the removal, lowering, or other change or alteration of any structure or tree not conforming to this article as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives or otherwise interfere with the continuance of any nonconforming use. Nothing contained in this article shall require any change in the construction, alteration, or intended use of any structure, the construction or alteration of which was begun prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article derives and is diligently prosecuted. 
Sec. 10-232. - Marking and lighting. 
    Notwithstanding section 10-231, the owner of any nonconforming structure or tree is required to permit the installation, operation, and maintenance thereon of such markers and lights as shall be deemed necessary by the city planner to indicate to the operators of aircraft in the vicinity of the airport the presence of such airport hazards. Such markers and lights shall be installed, operated, and maintained at the expense of the city. 
Chapter 14 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city relating to building regulations, art. II, § 22[17]. 
Cross reference- Environment, ch. 34; fire protection and prevention, ch. 38; floods, ch. 42; health and sanitation, ch. 46; historic preservation, ch. 50; demolition or removal of historic landmarks, § 50-191 et seq.; manufactured homes, mobile homes and parks, ch. 66; signs, ch. 78; solid waste, ch. 82; collection of building wastes, § 82-98; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 90; utilities, ch. 106; waterways, ch. 114; zoning, ch. 118. 
State Law reference- Authority of city relating to building regulations, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §§ 211.003, 213.001 et seq., 214.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Fire limits established. 
    The fire limits, described as "Exhibit A" and attached hereto as reference, shall apply to and be coextensive with the territory within the boundaries designated or which may be established as the fire limits of the City of Nacogdoches, except such provisions as are by special reference made applicable to all the territory within the corporate city limits, and the fire limits shall be on file in the City of Nacogdoches Building Permits Office. 
(Code 1971, § 8-1; Ord. No. 1565-2-11, 2-1-2011) 
Sec. 14-2. - Building standards commission created. 
(a)  Commission created. There is hereby created the Building Standards Commission for the City of Nacogdoches. 
(b)  Membership. The building standards commission shall consist of seven members and two alternates all being appointed by the city council. To the extent possible, members of the commission should be qualified in one or more of the fields of fire prevention, building construction, sanitation, plumbing, electricity, mechanical systems, engineering, architecture or public health. Failure of a person to be qualified in any of such fields shall not prevent or disqualify that person from sitting on the commission. 
(c)  Officers. The board shall select from its membership a chair, vice chair and secretary. The chairperson of the commission may designate an alternate to serve in the event of the absence or resignation of a regular member. Neither members nor alternates shall be employees of the city. 
(d)  Terms of service. All such members and alternates shall hold office for a period of two (2) years or until their successors are appointed and qualified as required by law. Vacancies which occur for any reason shall be filled for the length of the unexpired term in the same manner in which appointments are required to be made. 
(e)  Functions. The functions, purpose, and responsibilities of the board shall include the following: 
(1)  The commission shall serve as the board of appeals for Building, Mechanical, Electrical, Plumbing, Energy Conservation, Fire and Fuel Gas codes as may from time to time be adopted by the city council and shall be the venue for appeals based on claims that the intent of these codes or rules legally adopted related to these codes have been incorrectly interpreted or that the provisions of these codes do not fully apply. The commission shall periodically review the construction and fire codes and to make recommendations to the city council pertaining to the minimum construction and fire code safety standards and amendments. 
(2)  The commission shall have the authority to suspend building trades licenses issued by the city for due cause. 
(3)  The commission shall have such powers, duties and responsibilities as shall be from time to time provided for and delegated to the city by the legislature of the State of Texas, it being the intent of the city to fully implement Subchapter C of Chapter 54 of the Local Government Code and to further provide to the building standards commission, as well as any other commission, officer or legal authority as provided for under the provisions of state law, such powers, privileges and rights as may be from time to time provided for by the legislature of the State of Texas without restriction or limitation. 
(4)  In addition to the purposes established above, the building standards commission shall be the successor to all authority, responsibility, and functions, as set out in any and all ordinances of the City of Nacogdoches, previously exercised by the building code board of adjustments and appeals, the plumbing appeals and advisory board, the heating/air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration board, the board of electrical examiners, the fire prevention board, and the urban standards board of adjustment and appeals. Any reference in any city ordinance to the building code board of adjustments and appeals, the plumbing appeals and advisory board, the heating/air conditioning and mechanical refrigeration board, the board of electrical examiners, the fire prevention board and the urban standards board of adjustments and appeals, or a member of same, shall hereafter be interpreted to mean and said ordinances are hereby amended to refer to the building standards commission and the members thereof. 
(f)  Meetings. The board shall meet at such frequency as its chair or at other times the members of the board shall determine. All meetings shall be conducted as open meetings following timely postings of notice and agenda in conformity with the Texas Open Meetings Law, save and except as such meetings are to be conducted in closed session as permitted under said law. In addition to any meetings set by the board, the chairman or the housing official may call meetings. Four members shall constitute a quorum. To take official action, affirmative votes of the majority of members present shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 1540-4-10, § 1, 4-20-2010) 
Secs. 14-3-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 14-31. - Adopted. 
    There is hereby adopted by the city for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, repair, removal, demolition, equipment, use and occupancy of buildings and structures, including permits and penalties, that certain building codes known as the International Building Code, 2009 edition and International Residential Code for One and Two-Family Dwellings, 2009 edition with appendixes and amendments thereto, save and except such portions as are hereinafter amended or deleted, of which one copy with all amendments notes therein shall be on file in the office of the city secretary, available to all persons for inspection, and the same are hereby adopted as the building code(s) of the city as fully as if set out at length herein and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1971, § 8-13; Ord. No. 1265-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1430-7-06, 7-18-2006; Ord. No. 1617-2-13, 2-5-2013) 
Sec. 14-32. - Definitions. 
(a)  Whenever the term "municipality" is used in the building code adopted in section 14-31, it shall be held to mean the City of Nacogdoches, Texas. 
(b)  Whenever the term "corporation counsel" is used in the building code adopted in section 14-31, it shall be held to mean the city attorney of the City of Nacogdoches. 
(Code 1971, § 8-14) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-33. - Amendments. 
    The building code adopted in section 14-31 is amended or altered in the following respects: 
Section 104.5 Contractor's License and Bond Required shall be amended to read as follows: 
(a) Every contractor or builder who shall make contracts for the erection, construction, demolition, renovation or repair of buildings, structures or improvements for which a permit is required by the City of Nacogdoches and every contractor or builder making such contracts and subletting or assigning the same or any part thereof shall apply to the building official of the City of Nacogdoches for a license for such occupation and possession of such license shall be prerequisite to the exercise of the occupation described in this sentence. 
(b) It shall be the duty of every contractor or building, who shall make contracts for the erection, construction, demolition, renovation, repair or improvements of structures or buildings for which a permit is required by the City of Nacogdoches, and very contractor or builder making such contracts and subletting the same, or any part thereof, to pay an annual license fee to the City of Nacogdoches in the amount of $25.00, with no proration of said fee, which shall be due and payable in October of each year. 
(c) The building official shall register the name of each contractor or builder in a book provided for that purpose, giving the name, residence, and place of business; and in case of change of residence or place of business, the building official shall make a corresponding change in said register upon notice of such change. It shall be the duty of such contractor or builder to notify the building official of such changes. 
(d) It shall be the duty of every contractor or builder to give good and sufficient surety bond in the amount of $5,000.00, as reasonably required and approved by the city attorney, conditioned to conform to the building regulations of this building code, and all other ordinances and laws of the City of Nacogdoches and State of Texas. 
(e) Persons erecting, constructing, or repairing buildings on their own homesteads, as reflected by public records, are exempt from the licensing and bonding provisions hereof; provided that such erection, construction or repair is performed only by the person owning the homestead, that a permit as provided shall have first been obtained by such person, and such person shall have complied with all other requirements of this code except the licensing and bonding provisions. 
Section 104.5.1 Revocation of Contractor's License shall be added to read as follows: 
A contractor's license issued pursuant to section 104.5 of this code may be revoked by the building official for the following reasons: 
(a)  It has been determined that the applicant knowingly gave false or misleading information on the application for a contractor's license. 
(b)  The contractor or builder holding a license has been finally convicted in any court of the State of Texas or of any state of the United States of any charge of theft, robbery, fraud, unfair or deceptive business practices, or any other offense involving or constituting an act or acts of moral turpitude. 
(c)  The contractor or builder holding a license has been finally convicted of a violation of this code. 
Section 104.5.2 Appeal of License Revocation shall be added to read as follows: 
(a) A decision of the building official to revoke a contractor's license may be appealed to the building code advisory board by giving written notice of intent to appeal said decision within ten calendar days from the date the contractor or builder is notified of the revocation of the license. Such notice shall contain the reason or reasons why the board should change the decision of the building official. Failure to state the reason(s) shall result in the termination of the appeal. 
(b) Upon receipt of said notice of intent to appeal, the building official shall schedule a meeting of the building code advisory committee to consider such appeal. Such meeting shall be held within ten calendar days of the building official's receipt of the notice of intent to appeal, unless the contractor or builder requests a longer period of time, whereupon the building official shall schedule a meeting within 30 calendar days of the building official's receipt of the notice of intent to appeal. 
(c) At the hearing for such appeal, the building code advisory committee shall receive evidence submitted by the appellant concerning the reason or reasons for license suspension and shall also receive evidence from the building official as to why the license revocation should be sustained. The committee shall render a decision sustaining, amending, or reversing the decision of the building official based upon the evidence presented at the hearing. 
Section 110 Violations and Penalties shall be amended to read as follows: 
Any person, firm, corporation or agent who shall violate or cause to be violated a provision of this code, or fail to comply therewith, or with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall erect, construct, alter, demolish, or move any structure in violation of a detailed statement or drawing submitted and approved thereunder, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of the code is committed or continued, and upon conviction of any such violation, such person shall be punished within the limits and as provided by section 1-14 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Nacogdoches. 
Section 903.2.7 Group M. 
An automatic sprinkler system shall be provided throughout buildings containing a Group M occupancy where one of the following conditions exists: 
1.  A Group M fire area exceeds 12,000 square feet (1115 m 2 ). 
2.  A Group M fire area is located more than three stories above grade plane. 
3.  The combined area of all Group M fire areas on all floors, including any mezzanines, exceeds 24,000 square feet (2230 m 2 ). 
Section 1505.1 is amended to add a subsection to read as follows: 
1505.1.1 Wood Shingles and Shakes. Where Permitted. Outside the fire district only buildings of single-family resident occupancy (detached) may be roofed with grade labeled no. 1 or no. 2 wood shingles and no. 1 shakes with minimum butt thickness of one-half inch, securely fastened with rust-resistant nails. 
Section 3108.4.4 is amended to add a subsection to read as follows: 
3108.4.4.6 Signs Projecting Over Public Property. Signs projecting from a building or extending over public property shall maintain a clear height of nine feet above the sidewalk, and all such signs shall not extend more than 18 inches behind the curbline. All signs constructed and maintained upon any street within the city that is designated a federal highway, state highway or farm to market road shall be so constructed and maintained to comply with the provisions of the respective authorities controlling them. 
Appendix B Recommends Schedule of Permit Fees is amended to provide that the fees are on file in the city building permit office and the city secretary's office. 
Exemption of fees, the City Manager of Nacogdoches may waive fees for the development of low-income single-family dwellings when all the following criteria are met. 
(1)  The dwelling is/or will be occupied by the low-income owner of the dwelling and property. 
(2)  Is permitted by licensed and insured contractors as required by the State of Texas or City of Nacogdoches. 
(3)  Is sponsored by an organization meeting a charitable organization status or the City of Nacogdoches as can be verified by the City of Nacogdoches through federal or state tax exempt forms on file with that exempt government. 
Fees that may be waived are; plan review fees, inspection fees, building permit fees, electrical permit fees, mechanical permit fees, plumbing permit fees, demolition permit fees, house move off lot fees, sewer tap fees, water tap fees, zoning fees, board of adjustment fees, planned development fees, driveway access fees and any other fees the City of Nacogdoches could levee and finds appropriate to the successful completion of the structure. 
Fee waivers are not available for, owners with outstanding Housing Code, Zoning Code, or Environmental Health Code violations or on units or projects on which they are affiliated with the owning entity as a sponsor, partner, or partial owner. 
A denial of a fee waiver request by the city manager may be appealed to the city council. All fee waver requests that have been denied by the city manager shall be appealed to the city council in writing within 21 calendar days of the initial denial. 
(Code 1971, § 8-15; Ord. No. 1362-5-05, 5-3-2005; Ord. No. 1388-9-05, 10-1-2005; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1637-6-13, 6-18-2013) 
Sec. 14-34. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1540-4-10, § 2, adopted April 20, 2010, repealed § 14-34 in its entirety. The former § 14-34 pertained to construction code board of adjustment and appeals and derived from Ord. No. 1360-4-04, adopted April 6, 2004; and Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, adopted Nov. 17, 2009. 
Sec. 14-35. - Energy Conservation Code-Code adopted. 
    The International Energy Conservation Code, 2009 edition with its amendments and appendixes, are hereby adopted as the energy conservation code for the City of Nacogdoches, except for such exceptions and additions as are set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1430-7-06, 7-18-2006; Ord. No. 1617-2-13, 2-5-2013) 
Secs. 14-36-14-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICITY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 106. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-61. - Code adopted. 
    The National Electrical Code, 2011 edition with its amendments and appendixes, are hereby adopted as the electrical code for the City of Nacogdoches, except for such exceptions and additions as are set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 11-1; Ord. No. 1296-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1356-3-05, 3-15-2005; Ord. No. 1617-2-13, 2-5-2013) 
Sec. 14-62. - Definition of electric wiring and apparatus. 
    The term "electric wiring and apparatus" as used in this article shall be construed to include all materials, devices, machinery, appliances, appurtenances or conductors used in connection with the production or transmission of electric light, heat or power or the transmission of electrical signals, except where specifically limited to one or more of these materials, devices, machinery, appliances, appurtenances or conductors, and then only as specifically limited. 
(Code 1971, § 11-2) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 14-63. - Building official to decide questions not covered. 
    The building official shall decide all questions not provided for in this article or in the electrical code adopted in this article pertaining to the installation, operation or maintenance of electric wiring and apparatus. 
(Code 1971, § 11-33) 
Sec. 14-64. - Wires interfering with fire protection. 
(a)  No wire shall be installed, operated or maintained over any street; vehicle parking lot, both public and private; alley; sidewalk; or building in the city which may seriously interfere with the work of the fire department in the use of its ladders or other apparatus or which shall obstruct or render hazardous the use of fire escapes. On complaint of the fire official, such obstructing, interfering or hazardous wires shall be removed or properly rearranged. 
(b)  The chief of the fire department, fire official or electrical inspector shall have the power to cause the removal of all wires or the turning off of all electric current where the circuits interfere with the work of the fire department during the progress of a fire. 
(Code 1971, § 11-3) 
Sec. 14-65. - Liability for damages. 
    This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any person installing, operating or controlling any electrical wiring or apparatus for damage to anyone injured thereby, nor shall the city be held as assuming any liability because of the inspection authorized in this article or any certificate or permit issued pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1971, § 11-4) 
Sec. 14-66. - Special wiring for commercial business. 
(a)  Commercial structures in the fire limits as established in section 14-1 shall be wired in raceways as defined in the electrical code adopted in this article. 
(b)  For commercial structures outside of the fire district with less than 2,000 square feet of floor area or under roof, raceways shall be used in all accessible areas. Nonmetallic, sheathed cable may be used in inaccessible wall, floor and ceiling assemblies. Commercial structures with more than 2,000 square feet of floor area or under roof shall be wired in raceways. 
(Code 1971, § 11-5) 
Sec. 14-67. - Commercial electrical installations. 
(a)  A government entity or private business which employs a full-time, city-licensed electrician shall be responsible for ensuring that all electrical maintenance, renovation and alteration on its property or equipment be installed in accordance to the guidelines of the current electrical code as adopted and amended by the city in this article. 
(b)  Every government entity or private business which does not employ a full-time, city-licensed electrician must meet all applicable sections of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 11-41) 
Secs. 14-68-14-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESERVED[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1360-4-04, adopted Apr. 6, 2004, repealed Div. 2, board of electrical examiners, § 14-96, which pertained to established; composition; quorum; appointment and derived from Code 1971, § 11-59. 

Secs. 14-96-14-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 14-126. - Required. 
    No electric wiring and apparatus shall be installed, altered, or changed within the city limits unless a permit has first been obtained therefor from the authority having jurisdiction. However, this section shall not apply to minor repair work, such as the repair of flush and snap switches; replacing fuses; changing lamp sockets and receptacles; taping bare joints; and repairing drop cords, plug-in appliances or devices with a disconnect. Any master electrician shall be permitted to make repairs replacing a device with a like device and shall have the privilege of making any minor repair or alteration when the labor and materials do not exceed $20.00. 
(Code 1971, § 11-19) 
Sec. 14-127. - Applications generally. 
(a)  Every applicant for a permit to install, alter or change any electric wiring and/or apparatus shall first file an application therefor with the authority having jurisdiction describing the proposed installation, alteration or change, including the apparatus and materials to be used. The permit application shall be initiated by a licensed master electrician employed to do such installation, alteration or change, on forms furnished by the city, and shall contain a description of all electrical work to be done along with the street address and/or city lot and block number of the property, name of the owner of the property, the owner's agent or any person employed to do the work. 
(b)  On all electrical project sites, a master or journeyman electrician currently licensed by the city shall be present and responsible for all the electrical system installations, deletions or changes while work is being performed. 
(c)  Where work for which a permit is required by this division is commenced prior to obtaining the permit, the fees specified shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any person from fully complying with the requirements of the currently adopted electrical code or all other sections of this article in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed in this article or in laws. 
(Code 1971, § 11-20) 
Sec. 14-128. - Fees. 
    The fees to be charged for electrical permits and inspection of electrical work shall be $25.00, and shall be paid at the office of inspection services before the work is commenced. 
(Code 1971, § 11-21; Ord. No. 1388-9-05, 10-1-2005) 
Sec. 14-129. - Deviations from application. 
    No deviation shall be made in the details for electrical wiring or apparatus as shown on the permit application required by this division without first obtaining permission from the authority having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1971, § 11-22) 
Sec. 14-130. - Suspension or revocation; right of appeal. 
    Any permit issued pursuant to this division shall be suspended for any misrepresentation in the permit application. If the authority having jurisdiction determines that any misrepresentation or material error is intentional, the permit shall be revoked. Any person whose permit has been suspended or revoked by the authority having jurisdiction pursuant to this section shall have the right to appeal this decision to the building official and then, if necessary, to the city-appointed electrical board. 
(Code 1971, § 11-23) 
Secs. 14-131-14-155. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - INSPECTIONS 

Sec. 14-156. - Office of inspector created. 
    The office of electrical inspector is created in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 11-15) 
Sec. 14-157. - Appointment of inspector. 
    The electrical inspector shall be appointed by the city manager with the approval of the city council. 
(Code 1971, § 11-17; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 14-158. - Assistant inspectors. 
    The city manager, with the consent of the city council, shall have the power to appoint one or more assistant electrical inspectors. Each one of such assistants shall be competent to discharge the duties of the electrical inspector, and the rights and privileges conferred upon the electrical inspector are conferred upon each such assistant. 
(Code 1971, § 11-16; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 14-159. - Qualifications of inspector. 
    The electrical inspector shall be of good moral character; shall possess such executive ability, training and experience as is required for the performance of his duties; and shall be well-versed in the rules and requirements of the electrical code adopted in this article. The electrical inspector should be a journeyman or master electrician or should possess or be able to attain the SBCCI Electrical Inspector certification within one year of employment. 
(Code 1971, § 11-18) 
Sec. 14-160. - Right of entry of inspector. 
    The authority having jurisdiction shall designate and direct an electrical inspector, who shall have the right during reasonable hours to enter any building, public or private, manhole or subway in the discharge of his official duties or for the purpose of making any test of the electrical apparatus or appliances therein contained. For that purpose he shall be given prompt access to such buildings, manholes and subways upon notice to the person owning or in control of any such building, manhole or subway. The designated inspector shall have the right to enter during an emergency without notice if the owner or responsible person cannot be located in a reasonable amount of time. 
(Code 1971, § 11-31) 
Sec. 14-161. - Noncompliance with order, notice of inspector. 
    Any person neglecting or refusing to comply with any order or notice of the electrical inspector of the authority having jurisdiction made pursuant to this article shall be punished as provided by section 1-14. 
(Code 1971, § 11-34) 
Sec. 14-162. - Interference with duties of inspector. 
    No person shall interfere with the designated electrical inspector or any competent person lawfully deputized to assist him while in the performance of his duty. 
(Code 1971, § 11-35) 
Sec. 14-163. - Records, reports by inspector. 
    The designated electrical inspector shall keep a full and complete record of all work done, permits issued, examinations made, or other official work performed as required by this article and shall annually make a full and detailed report thereof to the city. Such record shall be so arranged as to afford prompt information concerning the condition and general arrangement of any electrical equipment at the time of the electrical inspector's last visit. All such records shall be maintained in the office of inspection services. 
(Code 1971, § 11-32) 
Sec. 14-164. - Authority to turn off current. 
    The authority having jurisdiction is authorized and empowered to cause termination of electric current from all conductors or apparatus which are deemed to be in an unsafe condition or which have not been installed in conformity with the electrical code adopted in this article. 
(Code 1971, § 11-29) 
Sec. 14-165. - Installations, alterations; issuance of certificate. 
    Upon the completion of the installation or alteration of electric wires and apparatus, it shall be the duty of the person doing such work to notify the authority having jurisdiction who shall make necessary inspections as soon as practical. If the installation or alteration is approved by the authority having jurisdiction, posting of such inspection shall be made by the inspector showing the results of the inspection, which shall contain the date and location of the inspection and an outline of the results of such examination, but no certificate or authorization to connect to a utility company shall be issued unless all apparatus, wires, etc., connected therewith are in strict conformity with the rules and regulations set forth in this article and the current electrical code adopted in this article. 
(Code 1971, § 11-24) 
Sec. 14-166. - Certification required for turning on current. 
    No electrical apparatus or wire shall be energized until satisfactory inspections have been made and authorization to connect is made by the authority having jurisdiction. Failure to obtain inspections or authorization to connect the power shall be sufficient cause to have power disconnected by the authority having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1971, § 11-25) 
Sec. 14-167. - Supervision of sign erection. 
    The authority having jurisdiction shall designate and direct an inspector who shall supervise the erection of all electric signs within the city. All sign circuits and conduits must be installed by a licensed electrician. Sign contractors may make the final electrical connection to the sign when the sign circuit is present. 
(Code 1971, § 11-30) 
Cross reference- Signs, ch. 78. 
Sec. 14-168. - Placement of material near wires. 
    Any person desiring to place any pipe, sheetmetal or similar material within six inches of any electric wire installed for use in connection with electric light, heat or power shall, before proceeding with the execution of the work, notify the authority having jurisdiction who shall inspect the work and cause all wires to be placed in a safe and secure condition. However, nothing in this section shall be construed to refer to wires installed in approved metallic conduit (EMT) or armored cable. 
(Code 1971, § 11-26) 
Sec. 14-169. - Concealed wiring, apparatus. 
(a)  No person shall conceal or cause to be concealed any electric wiring or apparatus except with the express permission of the authority having jurisdiction, who is authorized and directed to have such person remove any flooring, drywall, paneling, insulation, lathing or plaster, sheetmetal or other material which might conceal any electric wiring or apparatus contrary to this article or the electrical code currently adopted in this article. 
(b)  Upon completion of the inspection of any electric wiring or apparatus designed to be concealed and found to be in full compliance with the electrical code adopted in this article, the inspector for the authority having jurisdiction shall post a notice to that effect on the construction inspection placard or contact the electrician in person or in writing or by telephone. Such notification shall be considered an express permission to conceal such electric wiring and apparatus, but no concealment shall take place until such notice has been posted by the inspector for the authority having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1971, § 11-27) 
Sec. 14-170. - Dangerous conditions; notice. 
    Whenever the authority having jurisdiction suspects or acting upon a complaint received that any electric wiring or apparatus within the city is in a dangerous or unsafe condition or interferes with the work of the fire department, an inspection of wiring and apparatus shall be made and, if such conditions are found to exist, shall notify the person owning, using or operating the wiring and apparatus to place the wiring and apparatus in a safe, secure and noninterfering condition. When such conditions exist where life or property is in immediate danger, the authority having jurisdiction is authorized to remedy the unsafe condition by whatever means necessary, including termination of electrical service where such unsafe conditions exist. 
(Code 1971, § 11-28) 
Secs. 14-171-14-195. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - ELECTRICIAN'S LICENSE 

Sec. 14-196. - Required. 
(a)  No person shall install, alter or repair electric wiring and apparatus within the city unless such person has first obtained a master electrician license or a journeyman electrician license from the authority having jurisdiction and all permits required under this Code or other city ordinances. 
(b)  No license in effect, issued or renewed under the terms of this division shall be transferable to or used by any person other than the one to whom it is issued, nor shall a holder of a license allow his name or license to be used by any other person to obtain a permit or to perform work under such license. 
(Code 1971, § 11-57) 
Sec. 14-197. - Minimum qualifying experience. 
(a)  Every applicant for a master electrician license shall have passed a master electrical exam approved by electrical examiners board and shall have had at least four years' experience as a journeyman electrician in the electrical construction industry or shall be a graduate of a recognized electrical trade school with a four-year curriculum and shall have had at least two years as a journeyman electrician or shall have graduated after majoring in electrical engineering from an accredited college or university which has not less than a four-year curriculum and shall have had at least one year of practical experience. 
(b)  Every applicant for a journeyman electrician license shall have passed a journeyman electrical exam approved by electrical examiners board and shall have had at least two years' experience in the electrical construction industry or shall be a graduate of a recognized electrical trade school with a four-year curriculum. Journeyman applicants shall provide a notarized certificate of experience. 
(Code 1971, § 11-58) 
Sec. 14-198. - Examination required. 
(a)  All applicants for a master electrician license shall first present proof of passing the Southern Standard Building Code Master Electrical Examination to determine their ability and qualifications to do electrical work within the city as master electricians and to determine their contractual responsibility. 
(b)  All applicants for a journeyman electrician license shall first present proof of passing the Southern Standard Building Code Journeyman Electrical Examination to determine their ability and qualifications to do electrical work within the city as a journeyman electrician. 
(c)  All applicants for a journeyman electrician license must submit a notarized resume stating the time, place and company where electrical experience was obtained. 
(d)  Every applicant for a journeyman electrician license must also submit a letter from a master electrician stating the applicant has had two years' experience in the electrical construction industry and in the master electrician's opinion the applicant is a qualified electrician. 
(e)  Journeymen and masters who have obtained their licenses through an alternate testing agency other than the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc. shall present their information to the board of electrical examiners. The electrical examiners board has the right to examine all information concerning the applicant for a journeyman electrician license or a master electrician license and to grant or reject a license. Only those individuals who have taken an exam that is equal to or exceeds the Southern Standard Building Code Journeyman or Master Electrical Exam shall be considered for a license. 
(Code 1971, § 11-60) 
Sec. 14-199. - Fees. 
(a)  Before any master electrician license is issued, the applicant for the license shall pay a fee, which is on file in the city secretary's office, to the office of inspection services. 
(b)  Before any journeyman electrician license is issued, the applicant for the license shall pay a fee, which is on file in the city secretary's office, to the office of inspection services. 
(Code 1971, § 11-67) 
Sec. 14-200. - Reciprocal licensing. 
(a)  For the purposes of this division, the authority having jurisdiction may continue to honor current reciprocal agreements with cities, however no new cities may be added in lieu of the testing program. 
(b)  An electrician holding a currently valid license or certificate of registration in another reciprocating city may apply for and receive a similar license or certificate of registration in this city without taking an examination, provided the following conditions are complied with: 
(1)  The electrician shall submit evidence satisfactory to a majority of the board of electrical examiners that the electrician's license or certificate of registration was issued under regulations at least as restrictive as those required by the city in this division for issuance of a license and that an electrician holding a license issued by this city would be permitted to apply for and receive a similar certificate of registration or license in such other city under the reciprocal agreement. 
(2)  The electrician shall pay the license fee required and comply with all other requirements of this article. 
(3)  The electrician shall submit a letter from the electrical inspector or the board of electrical examiners of the applicant's home city attesting to the fact that the applicant had successfully passed an appropriate written examination, giving the date the examination was administered and the passing score. Such information will be presented to the building official/inspection services department of the city where application is being made, whereby the information may be presented to the electrical examiners board. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to exclude any individual coming within the provisions of the reciprocal agreement for valid and factual reasons. 
(Code 1971, § 11-74) 
Sec. 14-201. - Issuance generally. 
(a)  The building official shall issue a master electrician license to any person who has passed the Southern Standard Building Code master exam or who has passed an equivalent exam approved by the board of electrical examiners for the license and who has paid the fee required by this division. 
(b)  The building official shall issue a journeyman electrician license to any person who has passed the Southern Standard Building Code journeyman exam or who has passed an equivalent exam approved by the board of electrical examiners and been certified for the license by the board of electrical examiners and who has paid the fee required by this division. 
(Code 1971, § 11-64) 
Sec. 14-202. - Issuance to minors. 
    No master electrician license or journeyman electrician license shall be issued to any minor. 
(Code 1971, § 11-72) 
Sec. 14-203. - Issuance to holders of revoked licenses; appeals. 
    The authority having jurisdiction is authorized to refuse to issue a master electrician license or journeyman electrician license to any previous holder of a license for a period no longer than three years. If the license is revoked, the applicant shall submit to retesting. Any party so refused shall have the right of appeal to the electrical examiners board. 
(Code 1971, § 11-71) 
Sec. 14-204. - Expiration. 
    All licenses issued pursuant to this division shall expire on December 31 of each year and are renewable as of January 1 of each year. A 30-day grace period shall be granted for the purpose of renewal. Any license not properly renewed by February 1 will become invalid on that date and will remain invalid until the office of inspection services receives the renewal application, together with all cumulative renewal fees and the current fee. If a license has been expired for three years or longer, the person may not renew the license. The person may obtain a new license by submitting to reexamination and complying with the requirements and procedures for obtaining a new license. 
(Code 1971, § 11-68) 
Sec. 14-205. - Renewal. 
(a)  Any master electrician license issued pursuant to this division may be renewed annually upon payment of a fee on file in the city secretary's office. 
(b)  Any journeyman electrician license issued pursuant to this division may be renewed annually upon payment of a fee on file in the city secretary's office. 
(Code 1971, § 11-69) 
Sec. 14-206. - Grounds for revocation; forfeiture of bond; disposition of proceeds. 
    Any failure on the part of the holder of a master electrician license or a journeyman electrician license to comply with the provisions of the electrical code adopted in this article or any section of this Code or city ordinance regulating electric wiring and apparatus or to faithfully carry out the conditions of a contract for installing electric wiring and apparatus shall be deemed sufficient cause for the authority having jurisdiction to revoke the license and to cause the forfeiture of the bond filed pursuant to this article. The amount realized upon the forfeiture of the bond over and above the expense involved in its forfeiture shall be expended in making the necessary changes in the electric wiring and apparatus found to be contrary to this article or the electrical code adopted in this article or any contract entered into and covered by the bond, and the unused balance, if any, shall be paid into the city treasury. 
(Code 1971, § 11-70) 
Sec. 14-207. - Appeals generally. 
    If the board of electrical examiners refuses to certify an applicant for any license within the scope of this division, the applicant shall, within ten days therefrom, have the right to appeal to the city council by a letter addressed to the chair of the city council, stating an appeal from the board of electrical examiners is desired to the city council as a whole. Upon receiving the appeal, the city council, as soon as practical thereafter, shall hear the appeal and shall either sustain or reverse the decision of the board of electrical examiners. If no appeal is taken from the action of the board of electrical examiners within the ten days, the finding of the board shall be final. 
(Code 1971, § 11-65; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 14-208. - Insurance required prior to issuance of permit. 
(a)  Before any master electrician is issued an electrical permit, the applicant for the permit shall file with the city proof of general liability insurance coverage in the following amounts: 
(1)  General aggregate ..... $200,000.00 
(2)  Product/completed operations ..... 200,000.00 
(3)  Each occurrence ..... 100,000.00 
(b)  Every master electrician shall notify the city if the aggregate limits of insurance are exhausted during the policy period and shall immediately purchase additional aggregate insurance limits in an amount of no less than $200,000.00. 
(Code 1971, § 11-66) 
Secs. 14-209-14-235. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PLUMBING[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Plumbing standards and licensing, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243-101. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-236. - Adoption of code. 
    The International Plumbing Code, 2009 edition with its amendments and appendixes, are hereby adopted as the plumbing code for the City of Nacogdoches, except for such exceptions and additions as are set forth in this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 22-1; Ord. No. 1265-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1430-7-06, 7-18-2006; Ord. No. 1617-2-13, 2-5-2013) 
State Law reference- Adoption of plumbing standards, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243-101, § 5B. 
Sec. 14-237. - Amendments to plumbing code. 
    The plumbing code adopted in section 14-236 is amended as follows: 
Section 105, Permits is amended by adding the following subsections: 
105.3 Permits required. 
(a) It shall be unlawful to construct, install or cause to be installed any plumbing as defined herein without securing a plumbing permit from the City of Nacogdoches in the amount of $25.00, therefore except as otherwise provided for in paragraph 105.4. 
(b) It shall be unlawful for any person to make any extension to any lines or pipes, using water from city water mains, whether within or without the corporate limits of the city, or to add any pipes or to change any pipes or lines from a water line, apartment, house, premises, or meter without first securing a permit for such changes except as otherwise provided in paragraph 105.4. 
(c) Permits shall be required for the replacement of water heaters. 
105.4 Permits not required. 
No plumbing permit is required to do minor repairs such as the maintenance, repair or replacement in kind of the following: 
(a)  Yard hydrants and sillcocks; 
(b)  Flush valves and float-balls in water closet tanks; 
(c)  Accessible traps on lavatories or sinks; 
(d)  Replacing of plumbing fixtures where no change on "roughing-in" is involved except replacement of water heaters. (See subparagraph 105.3(c).) 
The above examples are representative only and should not be considered as a limitation on the term "minor repairs." 
105.5 Issuance of permit. 
The plumbing inspector or his designated representative shall issue all plumbing permits in accordance with the provisions and requirements of this code. All applications for permits shall give the correct location of the building, name of the owner of such building, and a complete statement of the work and fixtures to be installed. The plumbing inspector may require a complete plan of the work to be performed if considered necessary. 
105.6 Special permits authorized. 
A special permit may be issued, in writing, by the plumbing inspector when plumbing cannot be installed in accordance with all of the provisions of this code, if in his judgment the conditions require it. Application for this type permit shall be made in writing accompanied by a sketch showing the work to be done. Said sketch must be kept on file in the plumbing inspector's office. In other work pertaining to but not specifically covered by this code, the plumbing inspector may prescribe such specifications as may be necessary and shall be consulted before any work is started. 
105.7 Persons who may obtain a permit. 
Permits shall be issued only to the following: 
(a)  Any master plumber licensed by the state board of plumbing examiners. 
(b)  Any property owner for plumbing work to be done by him in a building owned or occupied by him as his home. 
(c)  Any appliance dealer or employee of an appliance dealer who is acting as an appliance installation man or appliance service man in connecting appliances to existing piping installations. 
105.8 Permits not transferable. 
Each permit issued under this code shall be personal to the permittee. No such permit shall be assigned or transferred to another person, and no person shall permit another person to obtain a permit in his name or permit any plumbing or gasfitting work to be performed under his permit by any person other than a person authorized to do the same. If there is any doubt as to whether or not a person is authorized to do such plumbing work for the permittee, evidence of cancelled payroll check may be required. 
105.9 False statement or bad faith. 
Any person who shall willfully make a false statement in order to obtain a permit shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to the penalty herein. Bad faith or unreasonable delay in the performance of plumbing work shall be deemed a sufficient reason for subjecting the plumber so offending to a suspension of the permit, and no further permit shall be issued until such act of bad faith or unreasonable delay has been corrected. 
Section 705.2 Large pipes is amended to read as follows: 
(a) For building sewers six inches and larger, manholes shall be provided and located at each change in direction and at intervals of not more than 500 feet. 
(b) Building drains six inches and larger shall be provided with full size cleanouts. 
Section 1302 is amended by adding the following subsection: 
1302.6 Depth of building sewer. 
Building sewer must be installed with minimum of 12 inches of cover. Where conditions prohibit the required amount of cover, cast iron soil pipe with caulked or approved mechanical joints must be used. 
Appendix H(a), Permit fees is amended to provide that the permit fees are on file in the city inspections department. 
(Code 1971, § 22-3; Ord. No. 1388-9-05, 10-1-2005; Ord. No. 1433-9-06, 9-5-2006) 
Sec. 14-238. - Other regulatory authority. 
    State or federal regulatory agency requirements shall take precedence over the International Plumbing Code adopted in this article and the International Gas Code adopted in section 14-326. 
(Code 1971, § 22-5; Ord. No. 1265-9-01, 9-4-2001) 
Secs. 14-239-14-265. - Reserved.

DIVISION 3. - PLUMBER'S LICENSE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Plumber's license required, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243-101, §§ 3(a)(2), 12. 

Sec. 14-296. - Required. 
(a)  Every person who engages in or works at the actual installation, alteration, repair and renovating of plumbing shall possess either a master or journeyman plumber's license in accordance with the provisions of the Plumbing License Law of 1947, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243-101. 
(b)  An apprentice shall not be permitted to do plumbing work alone. He shall at all times be under the immediate supervision of a journeyman or master plumber. 
(Code 1971, § 22-2(b)(1)) 
Sec. 14-297. - Exemptions. 
    The following acts, work and conduct shall be expressly permitted without a plumber's license: 
(1)  Homeowner. Plumbing work done by a property owner in a building owned or occupied by him as his home. However, a homeowner may do plumbing work only after securing a plumbing permit. No plumbing permit is required to do minor repairs such as the maintenance, repair or replacement in kind of the following: 
a.  Yard hydrants and sillcocks. 
b.  Flush valves and float-balls in water closet tanks. 
c.  Accessible traps on lavatories or sinks. 
d.  Replacing of plumbing fixtures where no change in roughing-in is involved except replacement of water heaters. 
The examples in this subsection are representative only and should not be considered as a limitation on the term "minor repairs." 
(2)  Maintenance, utility and appliance work. Plumbing work done by anyone who is regularly employed as or acting as a maintenance man or maintenance engineer, incidental to and in connection with the business in which he is employed or engaged and who does not engage in the occupation of a plumber for the general public; construction, installation, and maintenance work done upon the premises or equipment of a railroad by an employee thereof who does not engage in the occupation of a plumber for the general public; and plumbing work done by persons engaged by any public service company in the laying, maintenance and operation of its service mains or lines and the installation, alteration, adjustment, repair, removal and renovation of all types of appurtenances, equipment and appliances; appliance installation and service work done by anyone who is an appliance dealer or is employed by an appliance dealer, and acting as an appliance installation person or appliance service person in connecting appliances to existing piping installations. However, all work and service named or referred to in this subsection shall be subject to inspection and approval in accordance with the terms of all local valid city ordinances. 
(Code 1971, § 22-2(b)(2)) 
State Law reference- Acts permitted without a license, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243-101, § 12. 
Sec. 14-298. - Bond or insurance required. 
    Before any person shall engage in the business of plumbing in the city, he shall first obtain the proper license and deposit with the city a good and sufficient bond or certificate of insurance in the sum of $300,000.00, conditioned that the person engaged in the plumbing business will faithfully observe all the laws pertaining to plumbing. The bond or certificate of insurance shall be further conditioned that the city shall be indemnified and saved harmless from all claims arising from accidents and damage of any character whatsoever caused by the negligence of such person engaged in the plumbing business or by any other unfaithful, inadequate work done either by himself or his agents or employees. 
(Code 1971, § 22-2(a)) 
State Law reference- Certificate of insurance for plumbers licensed, Vernon's Ann. Civ. St. art. 6243-101, § 155(c). 
Secs. 14-299-14-325. - Reserved.
