    Temporary overhead street banners ..... $200.00 
    Fees for electronic message center permits will be determined by their valuation and corresponding fee in the current adopted building code. 
(Ord. No. 1361-4-05, 4-5-2005; Ord. No. 1463-8-07, 8-7-2007) 
Chapter 82 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate removal of garbage, refuse and unsanitary vegetation, art. II, § 22[3]; authority of city relating to removal of ice, snow and other debris from sidewalks, art. II, § 22[6]. 
Cross reference- Any ordinance approving or prescribing rates, charges and fees including rates for garbage saved from repeal, § 1-9(11); buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; health and sanitation, ch. 46; manufactured homes, mobile homes and parks, ch. 66; utilities, ch. 106; garbage and trash at Lake Nacogdoches, § 114-34. 
State Law reference- Accumulation and removal of garbage and trash, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.001 et seq.; minimum standards of sanitation, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 341.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article, unless a different meaning appears from the context, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    Building wastes shall mean discarded materials incident to and resulting from the construction or repair of buildings and the clearing of land for new construction, such as, but not limited to, rock, brick, metal, wood, glass, trees, brush and vegetation, when such materials are in greater quantity than can be placed in one container. 
    Dumpster shall mean a container of durable metal or plastic, supplied by the city, approved for commercial collection. 
    Garbage shall mean all putrescible wastes, except sewage and body wastes, including particles of food and meat, vegetable and animal offal, kitchen wastes in general, and tin cans, bottles, paper and other containers, paper or any other materials that contain or have attached thereto any residue of milk, soft drinks, food or other putrescible wastes, but excluding industrial wastes and by-products thereof. 
    Garbage container shall mean a watertight container of durable metal or plastic, of a type supplied by the city. 
    Landfill shall be the current designated sanitary disposal site for the city. 
    Refuse shall mean all other wastes, such as tin cans, metal, wood, glass, bottles, paper, cordage, ashes, household rubbish and any other nonclassified trash or discarded materials. 
    Sharps shall mean any hypodermic needle, syringe with needle, scalpel blade, razor blade and disposable razor. 
    Small dead animals shall mean the carcasses of fowl and animals no larger than a dog, but shall not include livestock or horses. 
    Yard waste shall be organic waste such as leaves, brush and grass clippings generated from residential property 
(Code 1971, § 13-1; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-1, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-0-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 82-2. - Official city sanitary disposal grounds. 
(a)  The official city sanitary disposal grounds are hereby defined as that place or places that are from time to time designated as such by the city council, and the specific description thereof shall be available at the city hall. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of any garbage or refuse in the official city sanitary disposal grounds except at those specified locations designated by the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump garbage or refuse at any place within the city except in the official city sanitary disposal grounds. 
(d)  All garbage, refuse, and waste materials on the official city sanitary disposal grounds are the property of the city, and no person shall separate, collect, carry off, or salvage any such materials unless expressly authorized to do so by the city manager and then only under the direction and supervision of the sanitation department. 
(Code 1971, § 13-19; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-19, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 82-3. - Accumulation of garbage or refuse. 
    The owner or occupant of any premises in the city shall, at his own expense, keep the premises free from the accumulation of garbage or refuse which may in any manner prejudice public health or comfort. 
(Code 1971, § 13-3; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-3, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 82-4. - Permit for hauling. 
    No person, other than employees of the sanitation department, may collect or haul garbage, refuse or other waste materials within the city, with the following exceptions: 
(1)  Any person operating a business, commercial or industrial establishment may haul garbage, refuse or other waste materials originating in his own establishment to the official city landfill if his means of conveyance is approved by the city as being sanitary and of a type that will prevent the spilling or leakage of its contents and the emanation of disagreeable odors. Such a person shall pay an annual fee for the privilege of disposing in said landfill, the amount thereof to be determined by the city by any practicable method prescribed by the city manager, but in no case shall such annual fee be less than $24.00. Each such annual fee shall be paid in advance at the city landfill, after which an account shall be opened that shall not be transferable to any other person, business, commercial or industrial establishment. The term of such annual fee shall run from January 1 to December 31 of each year, and the fee for part of a year ending on December 31 shall be prorated. 
(2)  A person, other than provided in subsection (1) of this section, may collect and haul garbage, refuse or other waste materials where wet garbage or garbage for livestock use is involved from within Nacogdoches County; provided that such person is permitted through TNRCC as a licensed transporter and that all route documentation is delivered to city landfill and approved for acceptance. 
(Code 1971, § 13-18; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-18, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 82-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1665-5-14, adopted May 6, 2014, repealed § 82-5 in its entirety. Former § 82-5 pertained to burning of garbage, refuse, wastes. See the Code Comparative Table for a complete derivation. 
Sec. 82-6. - Acts declared trespasses or nuisances. 
    The following acts by any person are hereby declared to be unlawful as trespasses or public nuisances: 
(1)  Placing, depositing, dumping or throwing, or permitting or causing to be placed, deposited, thrown, or to remain, any garbage, refuse, dead animals, building wastes, or any other discarded materials on any of the following property: 
a.  Public or private property outside of any house, apartment or building in the city, unless the same has been deposited in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
b.  Lots or land, vacant or occupied. 
c.  Any gutter, street, sidewalk, parkway, driveway, curb, alley or any other public property. 
(2)  Permitting any garbage or refuse to remain on private property, or on streets or other property in the vicinity. The person occupying the property shall collect and dispose of any such garbage or refuse that is on the property or on streets or other property in the vicinity of his business, regardless of the means by which such garbage or refuse came to occupy the property. 
(3)  Causing or permitting to be or to remain in or upon any premises, public or private, any garbage, or animal, vegetable, or mineral matter, or any composition or residue thereof, that is in an unsanitary condition or injurious to public health or that emanates offensive or obnoxious odors. 
(4)  Permitting containers, bottles, tires, grass, or other vegetation to grow or to remain on lots or land, vacant or occupied, or upon any abutting sidewalk, curb or street, so as to become offensive or emanate offensive or obnoxious odors, or become a breeding place for flies or insects, or become in any way injurious to the public health. 
(Code 1971, § 13-21; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-21, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
State Law reference- Littering, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 365.001 et seq. 
Secs. 82-7-82-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 82-36. - Use of another person's container to avoid fees. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to utilize any container belonging to another person as a means of avoiding payment of the collection fees levied by this article. 
(Code 1971, § 13-17; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-17, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Secs. 82-37-82-65. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 

Sec. 82-66. - Authority to direct times, places and manner of setting out. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to direct the times, places and manner of setting out containers for collection. 
(Code 1971, § 13-2; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-2, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 82-67. - Designation of location of container. 
    No garbage or refuse shall be collected by any authorized person unless the container thereof is placed as designated by the city manager. Residential containers must be placed at the curb line, out of the roadway or within ten feet of the edge of the roadway on noncurbed roadways, and be free of parked vehicles, trees or other obstructions. 
(Code 1971, § 13-6; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-6, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 82-68. - Service for nonapproved containers. 
    Any container that is set out for collection service which does not meet the requirements of section 82-1 of this article will not be serviced. 
(Code 1971, § 13-7; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-7, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Secs. 82-69-82-95. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COLLECTION 

Sec. 82-96. - Preparation of garbage and refuse. 
(a)  City will not collect waste from dumpsters when waste is above top of the dumpster. The city will not collect waste from outside of dumpster. 
(b)  If the customer needs additional collection, the fee will be based on dumpster size (cubic yardage) times current collection rate or arrangements shall be made through public works for a larger dumpster. 
(c)  All garbage containers shall be kept secure and fastened so that flies and other vectors cannot have access to the contents thereof. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the city to provide containers meeting the requirements of section 82-1 at such times and places as shall be prescribed by the city manager. Additional rollout carts may be obtained through public works upon request, subject to additional collection fees as established in section 82-131. 
(e)  Tree limbs and brush shall be collected from single-family residential units. Limbs and/or brush shall be stacked within three feet to six feet of the curb or driving surface. Stacks shall not exceed six feet in length, four feet in width, four feet in height and stacks shall be limited to three piles, with a maximum limb diameter of 12 inches. 
(Code 1971, § 13-4; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-4, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 82-97. - Schedule. 
(a)  The city, through its sanitation department, shall collect garbage and refuse from all premises, including residential, commercial and industrial, at such times as prescribed by the city manager. 
(b)  Residential containers shall be placed at the curb line or within ten feet of edge of an uncurbed roadway between 6:00 p.m. on the day before collection and 7:00 am on the day of collection. Serviced containers must be removed from curb line on the day of service, no later than 7:00 p.m. 
(c)  Yard waste shall be placed within ten feet of the edge of the roadway for collection on the resident's normal day for garbage collection. Yard waste must be properly bagged. The city will only collect 20 bags per residence per week. 
(d)  Recycles will be collected from single-family residential property on the normal day of garbage collection. Recycles must be placed in city-approved "blue bags" and must be within ten feet of the roadway. 
(e)  Limbs and brush will be collected from single-family residential property on a regular rotation basis. Limbs and brush must meet residential limb collection guidelines. 
(Code 1971, § 13-5; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-5, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 82-98. - Building wastes. 
(a)  The person creating or in possession of building wastes shall be responsible for the disposal of such wastes in such a manner and at such places approved by the city manager. 
(b)  Building wastes shall not be collected as a part of the city's refuse and garbage collection service except as a special collection under subsection 82-131(e), in which event such wastes shall be prepared for collection as required by section 82-96. 
(c)  City-owned roll-off dumpsters may be rented for three days, based on availability, for a rate as set forth in section 82-131. Disposal fee will be per cubic yard of dumpster size times the rate set in section 82-131. No waste will be allowed above the sides of the roll-off dumpster. 
(d)  The city may refuse to collect or dispose of any garbage, refuse, yard waste, or other substance which it reasonably believes to be toxic or hazardous, which requires special handling in pickup or disposal of which the city's landfill is not permitted to handle. No person shall place such materials for pickup by the city in containers furnished by the city. 
(Code 1971, §§ 13-8, 13-9; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, §§ 13-8, 13-9, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14. 
Sec. 82-99. - Small dead animals. 
(a)  The sanitation department, upon being notified, shall pick up all small dead animals from within the city street rights-of-way for appropriate disposal. The city does not pick up dead animals off of private property. 
(b)  Any person having knowledge of the existence of any dead animal shall immediately notify the sanitation department. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place a small dead animal in any garbage or refuse container. 
(Code 1971, §§ 13-10-13-12; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, §§ 13-10-13-12, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 6. 
Sec. 82-100. - Large dead animals. 
    Any person owning or in possession of dead animals other than small dead animals, such as livestock or horses, shall be responsible for their prompt disposal in such a manner as directed by the sanitation department. 
(Code 1971, § 13-13; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-13, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 6. 
Sec. 82-101. - Disposal of sharps. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to improperly place "sharps" into any garbage container; container or garbage bag used for refuse. Proper placement of sharps for pickup by the city sanitation department shall be as follows: Sharps shall be placed in a puncture-resistant (hard plastic) container with a screw-on lid. The lid of the sharps container shall be screwed on tightly when placed in trash container (bag or can) to be picked up by the city sanitation department. Containers holding sharps are not recyclable and shall not be placed in bags or containers for recyclable pickup by the city sanitation department. 
(Code 1971, § 13-22; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-22, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Secs. 82-102-82-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RATES, CHARGES AND BILLING PROCEDURE 

Sec. 82-131. - Service collection and disposal fees and standards. 
(a)  Scope. This section is a schedule and shall not be deemed to require the city to accept any type or volume of waste from any location or source, though it shall serve as a basis and criteria for rejection of waste. 
(b)  Minimum fee. All active water accounts serving commercial, business, institutional, or residential, which are charged for sewer (with the exception of residents utilizing approved septic systems), shall be charged at least the minimum garbage collection fee, plus a fuel adjustment charge per collection, respectively. The fuel adjustment charge shall be calculated by the city manager on a monthly basis, and shall cover the city's monthly fuel cost for the sanitation department. 
(c)  Residential waste collected by city. Minimum fees are established for waste commonly generated from residential units where the waste is collected by the city either at the house side for qualified handicapped citizens, or in approved containers for collection by the city. Curbside collection shall utilize city-supplied containers only. Such charges are per month, per residential unit except where applicable to other established rate schedules, and shall include the cost of collection, hauling and disposal. For the purpose of this rate schedule, a single-family residence shall be one residential unit; a duplex shall be two units; triplex three units; and quadraplex four units. Each unit in an apartment complex above four units that is separately metered for other city utilities, and has approved containerized service, will be considered as a separate residential unit with collection fees to be based on charges established for this customer class. Service collection and disposal fees and standards for residential waste picked up by the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential unit-Curbside collection-One day a week pickup: 
a.  Effective 10/1/2018. 
1.  One container ..... $24.77* per month 
2.  Two containers ..... $41.39* per month 
3.  Three containers ..... $63.08* per month 
Note: *Plus fuel adjustment 
Tax will be charged on all garbage accounts 
(2)  Apartment unit in apartment complex having more than four units and separately metered for other city utilities and having approved dumpster collection - One pickup per week. 
Effective 10/1/2018 ..... $19.89* per month 
(3)  Apartment complexes, mobile homes and manufactured housing parks above four units that have master meter(s) for utility services shall be required to have approved containerized collection service with collection fees to be based on the containerized rate established on a cubic yard basis. 
a.  Apartment complexes, mobile homes or manufactured housing parks metered by a master meter(s) for city utility service shall have approved containerized collection service - $5.04* per cubic yard of waste collected per collection - one to six collections per week. 
b.  Each unit in a mobile home or manufactured housing park separately metered for other city utility services will be classified as a residential unit. 
(4)  A residential customer who can provide a certificate on a city supplied form from a medical doctor stating that he/she is unable to physically carry his/her household waste to the curb and that no one else residing at this residence can carry waste to the curb shall be allowed, upon return of completed form/letter, to receive house side collection service at the curbside collection service rate. Waste must be placed in city-supplied containers (outside garage, fences, etc.). City may require updated disability forms at its discretion. 
(5)  All fees are for the amount and type of waste commonly generated by such residential units. Excessive amounts or unacceptable types of waste shall be subject to additional fees, requirements, or refusal by the city manager. 
(6)  Pilot Program - the city shall reserve the right to charge fees as approved by the City Council and deemed necessary for services provided in the implementation of various programs, such as commercial recycling, etc. 
(d)  Commercial, industrial, institutional and similar nonresidential waste. Service collection and disposal fees and standards for commercial, industrial, institutional and similar nonresidential waste is as follows: 
(1)  The city shall have the right to require any of the classes who generate more than four 96-gallon roll out containers per pickup to have approved containerized collection service. A minimum charge of $28.64* will be assessed for roll out carts. Charges for minimum customers who desire multi-weekly collections will be based on the fee schedule below. Number of collections per week shall be determined by the city manager. 
(2)  Multiple carts/collections. The following rates will be charged for multiple cart collections: 
Effective 10/1/2018 
Carts 1 Day 2 Days 3 Days 4 Days 5 Days 1 $28.64* $57.28* $85.92* $114.56* $143.20* 2 $28.64* $57.28* $85.92* $114.56* $143.20* 3 $44.11* $88.22* $132.33* $176.44* $220.55* 4 $59.67* $119.34* $179.01* $238.68* $298.35*

Tax will be charged on garbage rates 
(3)  The collection rate for dumpster service shall cover only one collection per week. Charges for minimum customers who desire multi-weekly collections will be based on the number of collection times the minimum charge. The number of collections per week shall be determined by the city manager. 
a.  Front load dumpsters - $5.04* per cubic yard of waste collected per collection - One to six collections per week. 
b.  After the city has made two separate attempts to collect waste from sites where dumpster is blocked, customers will be billed as if collection was made. To return and empty dumpster will be classified as an extra collection and appropriate fee charged. 
c.  Roll-off rates - City owned roll-off dumpsters may be rented for three days for a rate of $140.29*. Each additional three-day period, or part of, for an additional $70.15* minimum. Disposal rate will be $13.48** per cubic yard, per dumpster size, per collection. 
Note: **Plus pickup and return fuel adjustment. 
Tax will be charged on garbage rates. 
(4)  Regularly scheduled privately owned roll-off. The collection rate for regular scheduled service shall be $5.04** per cubic yard of non-compacted waste/refuse; or $5.55** per cubic yard of compacted waste/refuse collected, per collection. 
Note: ** Plus pickup and return fuel adjustment on privately owned dumpsters of 20 or more cubic yards. Tax will be charged on garbage rates. 
(5)  Garbage collection service will be provided to tenants and/or commercial enterprises located on city owned property outside the city limits of Nacogdoches at a rate of one and one-half times the rate charged for commercial garbage collection inside the city limits. All such tenants and enterprises shall be considered commercial and shall abide by the collection standards contained in this section. 
(6)  The city manager, shall have the right to set the schedule of frequency of pickup, specify the type of container, location of container, and refuse any waste based on volume, weight, dimension, hazard, state (liquid or solid), or type based on any city ordinance, state or federal law, regulations or permit pertaining to same including refusal based on health, air or water safety concerns. Under no circumstances will the city collect waste/refuse from any enclosed area, fenced yard. 
(7)  Special waste collection fee based on type of waste requested for collection; the following rates shall apply. The city manager shall have the right to determine equipment and personnel needed for collection. 
Personnel 1 man $29.58/hr. 2 men 40.71/hr. Truck with operator Pick-up 20.75/hr. Dump truck 37.51/hr. Loader/backhoe With operator 45.37/hr.  
*Note-All services are charged one-hour minimum. In addition to collection fee, current landfill gate rate disposal fee shall also apply. 
(e)  Waste delivered to city landfill. Disposal standards and fees for the city landfill are as follows: 
(1)  Minimum fees for waste delivered to the city landfill to be deposited in appropriate locations within the landfill according to city landfill rules or at the direction of the city employees on duty at the city landfill have been determined. 
(2)  For purposes of determining fees, the following definitions shall apply: 
a.  City resident. A person who resides within the corporate limits of the City of Nacogdoches. 
b.  Commercial user. A person, corporation, or partnership that engages in a business, service, calling or occupation that generates waste. 
c.  Non-resident. A person who does not reside within the corporate limits of the City of Nacogdoches. 
d.  Special waste. Waste requiring special disposal methods/handling that is not required of other waste. 
(3)  Without regard to residential or commercial use the following fees are set for special items generated within the City of Nacogdoches. The city will not accept dead animals for disposal from outside the city. 
a.  Appliances: 
Large ..... $14.82 
Small ..... $8.25 
b.  Small dead animals no larger than a dog, each. ..... $14.82 
c.  Large dead animals, each ..... $76.43 
d.  Special waste: 
1.  City Resident, cu. yd. ..... $14.82 
2.  Non-resident, cu. yd. ..... $27.08 
e.  Tires will be accepted and fee assessed in accordance with the state tire recycling fee schedule. 
(4)  Household garbage, rubbish, waste and brush: 
a.  City residents - $6.77 per cubic yard non-compacted and $7.44 compacted, with a $14.82 minimum. 
b.  Non-residents - $13.36 per cubic yard non-compacted and $14.65 compacted, with a $29.53 minimum, except that non-residents may not bring brush to the landfill. 
c.  Commercial brush/yard waste - $8.01 per cubic yard, with a $18.03 minimum. 
(5)  Upon proof of residence with a qualifying city water bill, city residents may make one delivery of such waste per month to the landfill free of any charge. 
a.  Proof of resident status shall be by means of a city water bill or water bill receipt no more than one month old, together with other proof of identity and residence such as a drivers license or identification card issued by the State of Texas, or other identification acceptable to the director of public works for the city. Only one delivery shall be allowed on any one water bill per month. Free disposal cannot be accumulated and taken at one time. 
b.  For purposes of this rate schedule, a standard size pickup truck without special sideboards, frames, load extenders or similar methods loaded with acceptable waste shall be considered a load qualifying for one free disposal per month. 
(f)  [Cubic yardage.] Cubic yardage shall be determined by the city employee on duty at the landfill according to the criteria established by the city manager. 
(g)  [Yard waste.] Yard waste generated, cut, trimmed, or felled within the City of Nacogdoches and delivered to the landfill by private resident with a qualifying city water bill, as described in subsection (e)(4) above, may be disposed of at a location designated by the city employee on duty at no charge provided that: no other type waste is mixed with the load; limbs and bags are unloaded in the area designed by the landfill superintendent or his designee; and no trees or limbs are in excess of 12 inches in diameter. Bagged yard waste must be emptied at site. No plastic is allowed to remain within the designated area and shall either be removed from the landfill or disposed of as directed by the city employee on duty. 
(h)  Scope. This is a schedule and shall not be deemed to require the city to accept any type or volume of waste from any location or source, though it shall serve as a basis and criteria for rejection of waste. 
(Code 1971, § 13-14; Ord. No. 1222-9-00, § 13-14, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-14, 9-19-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1417-5-06, 5-16-2006; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006; Ord. No. 1497-9-08, 9-2-2008; Ord. No. 1506-9-08, 9-16-2008; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1627-5-13, 5-7-2013; Ord. No. 1714-8-16 , 8-16-2016; Ord. No. 1743-9-17 , 9-5-2017; Ord. No. 1779-09-18 , 9-18-2018) 
Sec. 82-132. - Billing and payment. 
    For the purpose of convenience, the service fees levied by section 82-131 shall appear on the same bills showing the charges for city water and sewer service, and such fees shall be payable at the city hall. 
(Code 1971, § 13-15; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-15, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006) 
Sec. 82-133. - Suspension of service for nonpayment. 
    Any person who fails or refuses to pay the collection fees prescribed by section 82-131 within ten days from the date the same shall become due and payable shall have his service suspended, and the sanitation department shall take appropriate action in accordance with the laws and ordinances regulating sanitation. 
(Code 1971, § 13-16; Ord. No. 1243-2-01, § 13-16, 2-6-2001; Ord. No. 1264-9-01, 9-4-2001; Ord. No. 1295-9-02, 9-17-2002; Ord. No. 1298-10-02, 10-22-2002; Ord. No. 1335-9-03, 9-16-2003; Ord. No. 1374-9-04, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 1387-9-05, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 1437-9-06, 9-19-2006)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 86-1-86-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC PLACES 

Sec. 86-26. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages in any public place within the city, excluding restaurants, private clubs and those areas indicated in section 74-62. 
(Code 1971, § 19-16(b)) 
Sec. 86-27. - Camping. 
    No overnight camping is permitted on any city-owned property, unless permitted by the city manger or his/her designee. 
(Code 1971, § 7-98; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1695-4-15, § 2, 4-21-2015) 
Sec. 86-28. - Obstructions on sidewalks. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the use by pedestrians of any sidewalk in the city by placing thereon any boxes, material, vehicles, scales or other objects whatever. However, when it may appear to be to the best interest of the general public, the city manager may, by written permission, authorize the placing of certain objects on the city sidewalks. 
(b)  All merchants shall have the right to occupy one-half of a sidewalk when receiving and forwarding goods, wares and merchandise; provided, however, that such space shall not be occupied longer than five minutes at a time. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any merchant doing business in the city to occupy and use any part of a sidewalk for the purpose of exhibiting, displaying or advertising goods, wares or merchandise. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale, at auction or otherwise, any goods, wares or merchandise on a sidewalk. 
(Code 1971, § 25-1) 
Sec. 86-29. - Removal of sand, dirt or gravel from streets. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, without the permission of the city manager, to take, remove or carry away any sand, dirt or gravel from or out of any city street. 
(Code 1971, § 25-2) 
Sec. 86-30. - Destroying or damaging public facilities. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or wilfully destroy or damage any bridge, culvert, drain, sewer, ditch, sidewalk, signboard or tile or anything of like character placed upon any street or sidewalk for the benefit of the public. 
(Code 1971, § 25-3) 
Sec. 86-31. - Playing ball. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in playing ball in or on any street or sidewalk within the city. 
(Code 1971, § 25-5) 
Charter reference- Authority of city to prohibit amusements in streets and sidewalks, art. II, § 22[10]. 
Secs. 86-32-86-60. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 86-61. - Excavation and grading code adopted. 
(a)  The Standard Excavation and Grading Code, 1975 edition, published by the Southern Building Code Congress International, Inc., with amendments, is adopted and enacted as the excavation and grading code for the city. One copy shall be on file in the office of the city secretary, available to all persons for inspection. The excavation and grading code is adopted as fully as if set out at length in this article, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporate city limits. 
(b)  Any or all additions or amendments to such code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the city council to make the amendment a part of such code, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such code and shall be understood and intended as additions and amendments to such code. 
(Code 1971, § 25-15; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 86-62. - Supervision of work. 
    The holder of any permit issued pursuant to this article shall make any opening in any street, sidewalk or driveway or break any curb or gutter or make any repairs thereof under the direction of the city manager, with due regard for the safety of the public and the preservation of such streets, sidewalks, driveways, curbs or gutters. 
(Code 1971, § 25-27) 
Sec. 86-63. - Indemnification of city. 
    Any person who makes an opening in any street, sidewalk or driveway or who breaks any curb or gutter within the city shall indemnify the city and all of its officers, agents and employees from all suits, actions or claims of any character, name and description brought for or on account of any injuries or damages received or sustained by any person or person's property on account of any negligent act or fault of the indemnifier, his agents or employees. 
(Code 1971, § 25-28) 
Sec. 86-64. - Notice to police and fire departments. 
    The police and fire departments shall, except for emergency repairs, be contacted at least 24 hours before any street is cut pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1971, § 25-25) 
Sec. 86-65. - Safety devices required. 
    Any person desiring to make any opening in any street, sidewalk or driveway or to break any curb or gutter within the city shall provide such machinery guards, safe walkways, ladders, bridges, gangplanks, flares and other safety devices as may be needed to protect the public from accidents. 
(Code 1971, § 25-26) 
Secs. 86-66-86-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 86-91. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to make any opening in any street, sidewalk or driveway or to break any curb or gutter within the city without first obtaining a permit from the city manager. 
(Code 1971, § 25-16) 
Sec. 86-92. - Application. 
    Every applicant for a permit within the scope of this division shall submit a written application for the permit to the city manager. Such application shall state the street name and lot and block number in which the opening is to be made, the width of the opening desired, the purpose of the opening and the date on which the breaking is to be commenced. If the application is for a permit to break any curb or gutter, the application shall be signed by the owner of the property affected. 
(Code 1971, § 25-18) 
Sec. 86-93. - Fee. 
    Each applicant for a permit required by this division shall pay a fee of $25.00. 
(Code 1971, § 25-19; Ord. No. 1388-9-05, 10-1-2005) 
Sec. 86-94. - Authority to grant. 
    The city manager shall have the authority to grant a permit required by this division to a person engaged in laying pipe for gas or water or for such other purposes within the public interest, upon application and payment of the fee imposed in this division. 
(Code 1971, § 25-17) 
Secs. 86-95-86-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 86-121. - Specifications for streets. 
    Any person desiring to cut any concrete or asphalt street within the city or replace any portion cut shall comply with the following specifications: 
(1)  Width of concrete cut. All concrete shall be cut back at least six inches from the ditch cut. Such cuts shall be done with a jackhammer or sawed with a concrete saw to a depth of two inches before breaking. 
(2)  Width of ditch. The ditch shall be of sufficient width so select backfill may be tamped or water soaked along each side of the pipe or casing. 
(3)  Backfill. The backfill at street crossings shall be of select material, wetted if required, placed in six-inch layers and thoroughly compacted by mechanical tamping. This compaction shall be required from 18 feet on either side of the curbline of streets to 18 feet of the curbline of such. Also, the compaction shall be continued to the top of the backfill. 
(4)  Alignment and grade. All concrete shall be replaced true in alignment and grade to the removed street. Also, all small concrete sections or slabs adjacent to any open cut on the street shall be removed and replaced and shall be of the same grade and thickness of that removed. 
(5)  Replacement of concrete curb and gutter and flexible base. All concrete shall be class A, and the curb and gutter shall conform to the grade and alignment of the curb and gutter removed. Replaced base shall consist of 12-inch compacted cement stabilized iron ore gravel approved by the city and shall extend a minimum of six inches on each side of the ditch. 
(6)  Replacement of monolithic curb and gutter and rigid base. The concrete, grade and alignment shall be the same as prescribed in subsection (4) of this section. If the original street had concrete wearing surface, the replacement shall be concrete 12 inches thick and poured to conform to the original street grade. If the removed street had a rigid base with an asphalt wearing surface, the replacement shall be 12-inch concrete with 11/2 inches of compacted asphalt wearing surface. The 12-inch concrete base shall extend a minimum of six inches on each side of the ditch. If the open cut crossing of a monolithic curb and gutter concrete street is such as to leave a short section adjacent to the ditch, the section shall be removed and replaced to the end of the section or the radius of the street turnout. 
(7)  Expansion joints. All expansion joints shall be of one-half-inch premoulded or three-quarter-inch cypress or redwood board and shall be placed in accordance with good engineering practice. 
(8)  Concrete curing. When completed, the concrete shall have at least three days of curing of a method approved by the city. Membrane curing compound, which complies with the Standard Specification for Liquid Membrane Forming Compounds for Curing Concrete, ASTM designation C 309 type 2 white pigmented, may be used. 
(Code 1971, § 25-20) 
Sec. 86-122. - Specifications for sidewalks and driveways. 
    Every person shall, in conformity with the lines and grades approved by the city, replace any sidewalk or driveway within the city which he has removed, while excavating, in accordance with the following specifications: 
(1)  Materials. All concrete used in the construction shall consist of Portland cement, fine and coarse aggregate and water, and shall be proportioned to conform to the requirements for class A concrete. Reinforcing steel, if required, shall be deformed bars conforming to the requirements of ASTM designation A 305. 
(2)  Construction methods. Construction methods shall be as follow: 
a.  The subgrade shall be excavated and shaped to line, grade and cross section and, if considered necessary by the city, shall be of select material and mechanically tamped. The subgrade shall be lightly sprinkled before placing concrete thereon. 
b.  All forms shall be of wood or metal, straight, free from warp, and of a depth equal to the thickness of the finished work. They shall be securely staked to line and grade and maintained in a true position during the depositing of concrete. 
c.  All sidewalks shall be 48 inches wide by four inches thick and shall have a one-half-inch premoulded or three-quarter-inch cypress or redwood board expansion joint at least every 32 feet. Where any sidewalk abuts a curb, concrete step retaining wall or another concrete walk from a residence, an approved expansion board of one-inch thickness shall be placed. Similar expansion material shall be placed around all obstructions protruding through sidewalks. 
d.  All concrete shall be placed in the forms to the depth specified, spaded and tamped until thoroughly compacted and the mortar entirely covers the surface. The top surface shall be floated with a wooden float to a gritty texture. The outer edges and joints shall then be rounded with a suitable tool, formed so as to round the edges to a one-half-inch radius. 
e.  All sidewalks shall be marked into separate sections, each four feet in length, by the use of approved jointing tools. 
f.  All commercial driveways shall be replaced with a minimum of six-inch-depth concrete. If the original driveway contains wire or bar reinforcing or is thicker than six inches, the replacement shall be the depth of the original concrete and shall have a minimum of no. 3 reinforcing steel on 12-inch centers. 
g.  When completed, the sidewalks and driveways shall have a curing period of at least three days, of a method approved by the city. Membrane curing compound, which complies with the Standard Specification for Liquid Membrane Forming Compounds for Curing Concrete, ASTM designation C 309 type 2 white pigmented, may be used. 
h.  All sidewalks or driveways removed shall be replaced true to grade and alignment and shall be replaced in as good a condition as the concrete removed. 
(Code 1971, § 25-21) 
Sec. 86-123. - Replacement of concrete lips; enforcement. 
(a)  Any person who is granted a permit to break out any curb or gutter shall reconstruct, where the opening is made, a laid-down concrete lip which shall not be less than 12 inches in width. However, where the adjacent property is lower than the lowest point of the curb, the concrete lip shall be extended in sufficient width to obtain a height equal to the upright curb height adjacent to said opening. 
(b)  The city manager shall take all necessary steps to ensure that any repairs made adjacent to any openings in a curb and gutter conform with good and accepted engineering practices and subsection (a) of this section. 
(Code 1971, § 25-22) 
Sec. 86-124. - Construction defects. 
(a)  All street, sidewalk, driveway, curb or gutter work showing defects in alignment or grade within three years of completion shall be removed and replaced or repaired, as directed by the city, by the person who originally removed and replaced it when such defects can be traceable directly to him. 
(b)  Any person who breaks any water or sewer main or service line shall repair the break and have it inspected by a city inspector before it is covered. If necessary for the city crews to repair the break, the person shall be billed for cost plus ten percent for such repairs. 
(c)  The public utility company, individual, firm, or contractor will assume responsibility for defects in sewer or water lines which can be traced to construction during this project, regardless of when such defects appear. 
(Code 1971, § 25-23) 
Sec. 86-125. - Alteration of utility lines. 
(a)  No person shall alter existing utility lines without written permission from the responsible official of the line affected. 
(b)  Any person who alters any conduit or line to enable the city to furnish sewer or water service to any property shall make such alterations at his own expense and shall take immediate action when requested to do so by the city. 
(Code 1971, § 25-24) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 106. 
Secs. 86-126-86-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CONCRETE CURB AND GUTTER SPECIFICATIONS 

Sec. 86-151. - Described. 
    As used in this division, the term "concrete curb and gutter" shall consist of Portland cement combined curb and gutter without reinforcing steel, constructed on an approved subgrade in accordance with this division and in conformity with lines and grades established by a registered professional engineer. 
(Code 1971, § 25-34) 
Sec. 86-152. - Materials. 
    Portland cement, fine and coarse aggregate and water shall conform to the specifications contained in section 86-153. 
(Code 1971, § 25-35) 
Sec. 86-153. - Mixing and proportions. 
    Concrete materials for a curb and gutter shall be measured by weighing on an approved batch scale. Water shall be measured by an approved measuring device for measuring water by volume which indicates the quantity in gallons and fractions thereof. Four and one-half sacks of cement, 20 to 30 gallons of water, approximately 1,500 pounds fine aggregate, and approximately 1,900 pounds coarse aggregate are required for one cubic yard of workable concrete. 
(Code 1971, § 25-36) 
Sec. 86-154. - Construction methods. 
(a)  Subgrade. The subgrade for the curb and gutter shall be shaped to line, grade and cross section, thoroughly tamped and lightly sprinkled before placing the concrete thereon. 
(b)  Forms. All forms shall be of metal, except short radius forms, and of a section approved by the city engineer, straight, free of warp and of a depth equal to the depth of the curb and gutter. All forms shall be well staked and thoroughly braced so that the tamping of materials will not disturb them or move them out of line. 
(c)  Expansion joint. The curb and gutter shall have a one-half-inch premoulded or three-quarter-inch cypress or redwood board expansion joint every 50 feet and shall be grooved with an approved grooving tool every ten feet if so specified by the city engineer. 
(d)  Finishing. All curb and gutter finishing shall be performed prior to the initial set of concrete. Plaster finish shall not be permitted. Care shall be taken that the curb and gutter shall show no trowel marks, high spots, sags or horizontal deflections, and any section showing such after being finished will be condemned by the city and shall be replaced by the contractor. 
(e)  Curing. The completed curb and gutter shall be cured by a method approved by the city. Liquid membrane curing compound which complies with the Standard Specifications for Liquid Membrane Forming Compounds for Curing Concrete, ASTM C 309 type 2 white pigmented, may be used. 
(Code 1971, § 25-37) 
Sec. 86-155. - Dimensions. 
    Unless a change order letter of authorization is secured by the contractor from the city manager and city engineer, a regular section of curb and gutter shall have the dimensions shown on the following drawing: 
_____ 
Dimensions 
(Code 1971, § 25-38) 
_____
Sec. 86-156. - Access to public streets. 
    There is adopted by the city, for the purpose of establishing regulations for access to all public streets, the regulations for proposed driveways and proposed streets to existing public streets, the following requirements: 
(1)  A permit approved by the city engineer shall be required prior to the installation of any new or modified non-single-family residential driveway access or new or modified street access within the city limits or for a subdivision within the city's extra territorial jurisdiction. A permit approved by the city building official shall be required for any new or modified single-family driveway access. 
(2)  All access shall be in conformance with the city's comprehensive plan, dated July 15, 2003, as such may be amended. 
(3)  The design of all public street access shall be in accordance with "City Standards for the Design and Construction of Public Improvements", dated August 9, 2001, as such may be amended, and good engineering practice. 
(Code 1971, § 25-39; Ord. No. 1372-8-05, §§ 1-3, 8-2-2005) 
Chapter 90 - SUBDIVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city saved from repeal, § 1-9(8); buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; submission of plans and evidence of compliance with article-subdivision plats, § 34-186; floods, ch. 42; manufactured homes, mobile homes and parks, ch. 66; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 106; waterways, ch. 114; zoning, ch. 118. 
State Law reference- Subdivision of land, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 90-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building line means a line within a lot, beyond which a building shall not extend, except as specifically provided in this chapter. 
    Cul-de-sac means a street having but one outlet to another street, and terminated on the opposite end by a vehicular turnaround. 
    Dead-end street means a street, other than a cul-de-sac, having only one outlet to another street. 
    Engineer means a person duly authorized under the provisions of the Texas Engineering Registration Act, as amended, to practice the profession of engineering. 
    Lot means an undivided tract or parcel of land having frontage on a public street which is or in the future may be sold, conveyed, transferred or improved; which is designated as a distinct and separate tract; and which is identified by a tract or lot number or symbol in a duly approved subdivision plat which has been properly filed of record. 
    Shall; may. The term "shall" is always mandatory. The term "may" is merely discretionary. 
    Street means a public right-of-way however designated, which provides primary vehicular access to adjacent land. The term "street" is further defined as follows: 
(1)  Arterial street primarily provides vehicular circulation to various sections of the city. 
(2)  Collector street primarily provides circulation within neighborhoods, to carry traffic from minor streets to arterial streets, or to carry traffic through or adjacent to commercial or industrial areas. 
(3)  Minor street is one used primarily for access to abutting residential property. 
    Subdivider means any person or agent thereof dividing or proposing to divide land so as to constitute a subdivision as that term is defined in this section. In any event, the term "subdivider" is restricted to include only the owner, equitable owner or authorized agent of such owner or equitable owner of land sought to be subdivided. 
    Subdivision means a division of any tract of land situated within the corporate limits or within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city, in two or more parts for the purpose of laying out any subdivision of any tract of land or any addition of any town or city, or for laying out suburban lots or building lots or any lots and streets, alleys or parts or other portions intended for public use or the use of purchasers or owners of lots fronting thereon or adjacent thereto. The term "subdivision" includes resubdivision, but it does not include the division of land for agricultural purposes into parcels or tracts of five acres or more and not involving any new street, alley or access easement. 
    Surveyor means a state licensed land surveyor or a registered public surveyor, as authorized by state statute to practice the profession of surveying. 
    Utility easement means an interest in land granted to the city, the general public, and/or to a private utility corporation, for installing or maintaining utilities across, over or under private land, together with the right to enter thereon with machinery and vehicles necessary for the maintenance of such utilities. 
(b)  Definitions not expressly prescribed in this section are to be construed in accordance with customary usage in municipal planning and engineering practices. 
(Code 1971, § 26-3) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 90-2. - Authority. 
    This chapter is adopted under the authority of the state constitution and laws, including V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.001 et seq., and the provisions of V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 43.021. 
(Code 1971, § 26-1) 
Sec. 90-3. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this chapter is to provide for the orderly, safe and healthful development of the area within the city and within the area surrounding the city and to promote the health, safety and general welfare of the community. The provisions and requirements of this chapter shall apply to all subdivisions within the corporate city limits as well as those within that area delineated as the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city of Nacogdoches as allowed for under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 42.021. 
(Code 1971, § 26-2) 
State Law reference- City's extraterritorial jurisdiction for subdivision purposes, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 42.001 et seq.; subdivisions generally, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.001 et seq. 
Sec. 90-4. - Authority of city council. 
    The city council may promulgate rules, regulations, standards and specifications for the construction, installation, design, location and arrangement of streets, curbs, streetlights, street signs, utility layouts, utility easements, gates for utility easements, sidewalks, water supply and water distribution systems, fire hydrants, sewage disposal systems, septic tanks, water wells, monuments, criteria for drainage easement requirements and drainage facilities. Such rules, regulations, standards and specifications shall be filed with the city secretary 60 days before they become effective. No such rules, regulations, standards, and specifications shall conflict with this chapter or any other city ordinances. All such improvements shall be constructed, installed, designed, located and arranged by the subdivider in accordance with such rules, regulations, standards and specifications. 
(Code 1971, § 26-15; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-5. - Application of chapter to extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(a)  This chapter is extended in its application to include all of the area within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city. The sections of this chapter shall have the same force and effect within the area of extraterritorial jurisdiction as within the corporate city limits, except as provided in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(b)  No violation of any section of this chapter outside the corporate city limits, but within the city's area of extraterritorial jurisdiction, shall constitute a misdemeanor under this chapter, nor shall any fine provided for in this chapter be applicable to a violation within such area of extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(c)  If any section of the subdivision chapter dated July 1, 1969, is violated within the area of the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction and outside its corporate limits, the city may institute any appropriate action of proceedings in the district court to enjoin the violation of such chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 26-16) 
Sec. 90-6. - Enforcement actions. 
    In behalf of the city, the city attorney shall, when directed by the city council, institute appropriate action in a court of competent jurisdiction to enforce this chapter or the standards referred to in this chapter with respect to any violation thereof which occurs within the city, within the extraterritorial jurisdiction of the city as such jurisdiction is determined under the Municipal Annexation Act, or within any area subject to all or part of this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 26-4(E); Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-7. - Subdivider's responsibility. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to familiarize himself with the procedures, specifications, and standards required by this chapter for the subdivision of land. 
(Code 1971, § 26-6) 
Sec. 90-8. - Variances. 
    The planning and zoning commission may authorize a variance from this chapter when, in its opinion, undue hardship will result from requiring strict compliance. In granting a variance, the planning and zoning commission shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to, or desirable in, the public interest. In making the findings required in this section, the planning and zoning commission shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of the land involved; existing uses of land in the vicinity; the number of persons who will reside or work in the proposed subdivision; and the probable effect of such variance upon traffic conditions and upon the public health, safety, convenience and welfare in the vicinity. No variance shall be granted unless the planning and zoning commission finds that: 
(1)  There are special circumstances or conditions affecting the land involved such that the strict application of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land; 
(2)  The variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the applicant; 
(3)  The granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare or injurious to other property in the area; and 
(4)  The granting of the variance will not have the effect of preventing the orderly subdivision of other land in the area in accordance with this chapter. Such findings of the planning and zoning commission, together with the specific facts upon which such findings are based, shall be incorporated into the official minutes of the planning and zoning commission meeting at which such variance is granted. Variances may be granted only when in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this chapter, so that the public health, safety and welfare may be secured and substantial justice done. Pecuniary hardship to the subdivider, standing alone, shall not be deemed to constitute undue hardship. 
(Code 1971, § 26-5) 
Secs. 90-9-90-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PLATS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Requirements for plats, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.004. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-36. - Subdivision of large tracts. 
    Where the proposed subdivision constitutes a unit of a larger tract owned by the subdivider which is intended to be subsequently subdivided as additional units of the same subdivision, the preliminary and final plat shall be accompanied by a layout of the entire area showing the tentative proposed layout of streets and land usage. The overall layout, if approved by the planning and zoning commission, shall be attached to and filed with a copy of the approved subdivision plat in the permanent files of the planning and zoning commission. Thereafter, plats of subsequent units of such subdivision shall conform to such approved overall layout, unless subsequently changed, and approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
(Code 1971, § 26-12) 
Secs. 90-37-90-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PREREQUISITE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 90-61. - Permits. 
(a)  No permit shall be issued by the city for the installation of septic tanks upon any lot in a subdivision for which a final plat has not been approved and filed for record or upon any lot in a subdivision in which the standards contained in this chapter or referred to in this chapter have not been complied with in full. 
(b)  No permits shall be issued by the building/inspection department for any structure on a lot in a subdivision for which a final plat has not been approved and filed for record. Permits shall not be issued for any structure unless all required city utilities and streets are in place and operational, nor for any structure on a lot within a subdivision in which the standards contained in this chapter or referred to in this chapter have not been complied with in full. 
(Code 1971, § 26-4(A), (B)) 
Sec. 90-62. - Work done by city. 
    The city shall not repair, maintain, install or provide any streets or public utility services in any subdivision for which a final plat has not been approved and filed for record, nor for any structure on a lot within a subdivision in which the standards contained in this chapter or referred to in this chapter have not been complied with in full. 
(Code 1971, § 26-4(C)) 
Sec. 90-63. - Utilities. 
    The city shall not sell or supply any water, gas, electricity, or sewer service within a subdivision for which a final plat has not been approved or filed for record, nor in which the standards contained in this chapter have not been complied with in full. 
(Code 1971, § 26-4(D)) 
Sec. 90-64. - Resolution of noncompliance. 
    If any subdivision exists for which a final plat has not been approved or in which the standards contained in this chapter or referred to in this chapter have not been complied with in full and the city council passes a resolution reciting the fact of such noncompliance or failure to secure final plat approval and reciting the fact that sections 90-61 through 90-63 will apply to the subdivision and the lots therein, the city secretary shall, when directed by the city council, cause a certified copy of such resolution, under the corporate seal of the city, to be filed in the deed records of the county in which such subdivision or part thereof lies. If full compliance and final plat approval are secured after the filling of such resolution, the city secretary shall forthwith file an instrument in the deed records of the county stating that sections 90-61 through 90-63 no longer apply. 
(Code 1971, § 26-4(F); Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 90-65. - Existing residences, streets and utility services. 
    This division shall not be construed to prohibit the issuance of a permit for any lot upon which a residence building exists and was in existence prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives (June 21, 1988), nor to prohibit the repair, maintenance, or installation of any street or public utility services for, to, or abutting any lot, the last recorded conveyance of which, prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives (June 21, 1988), was by metes and bounds, and/or any subdivision or lot therein recorded or unrecorded, which subdivision was in existence prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter derives (June 21, 1988). 
(Code 1971, § 26-4(G)) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 106. 
Secs. 90-66-90-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PRELIMINARY PLAT 

Sec. 90-91. - Preparation and contents. 
(a)  The subdivider shall cause to be prepared a preliminary plat in accordance with this chapter. 
(b)  The preliminary plat shall be drawn to a scale of 100 feet to one inch or larger and shall show the following: 
(1)  Proposed name of the subdivision, which shall not have the same spelling as or be pronounced similarly to the name of any other subdivision located within the city or within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(2)  Description by metes and bounds of the subdivision. 
(3)  Acreage and number of lots within the subdivision. 
(4)  Names and addresses of the subdivider and record owner. 
(5)  Date of preparation, scale of the plat and north arrow. 
(6)  Vicinity sketch or map at a scale of not more than one mile per inch, which shall show the relation of the subdivision to well-known streets, railroads, and watercourses in all directions to a distance of at least one mile. 
(7)  Subdivision boundary lines, indicated by heavy lines. 
(8)  Names of contiguous subdivisions and the owners of contiguous parcels of unsubdivided land and an indication of whether or not contiguous properties are platted. 
(9)  Primary control points or descriptions and ties to such control points to which all dimensions, angles, bearings, block numbers and similar data shall be referred. 
(10)  Location of the city limits line, the outer border of the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction, and zoning district boundaries, if they traverse the subdivision from part of the boundary of the subdivision or are contiguous to such boundary. 
(11)  Topographical information, which shall include contour lines on a basis of five vertical feet in terrain with a slope of two percent or more, and on a basis of two vertical feet in terrain with a slope of less than two percent. 
(12)  Existing sites as follows: 
a.  The location, dimensions, name and description of all existing or recorded streets, alleys, reservations, easements or other public rights-of-way within the subdivision, intersecting or contiguous with its boundaries or forming such boundaries. 
b.  The location, dimensions, description and name of all existing or recorded residential lots, parks, public areas, permanent structures and other sites within or contiguous to the subdivision. 
c.  The location, dimensions, description, and flow line of existing watercourses and drainage structures within the subdivision or on contiguous tracts. 
(13)  The approximate location, dimensions and description of all proposed streets, alleys, drainage structures, parks, other public areas, reservations, easements or other rights-of-way, blocks, lots and other sites within the proposed subdivision. 
(14)  A number or letter to identify each lot or site and each block. 
(15)  Designation of any sites for churches, sewage disposal plants, water plants, business, industry, or other special land uses. If a proposed use is unknown, the use shall be designated as unrestricted. 
(16)  Location of all building lines on all lots and sites within the subdivision. 
(17)  Names of all proposed streets, which shall not have the same spelling or be pronounced similarly to the name of any other street located within the city or within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction, unless such proposed street is an extension of an existing street, in which case it shall be named the same as the existing street. 
(Code 1971, § 26-7) 
Sec. 90-92. - Processing. 
(a)  Formal application for subdivision preliminary plat approval shall be made by the subdivider in writing to the planning and zoning commission at a regularly scheduled meeting. 
(b)  The subdivider shall submit one copy of the preliminary plat to the planning and zoning commission at least ten days prior to the date at which the formal application for preliminary plat approval is made to the planning and zoning commission. 
(c)  Each plat submitted for preliminary and/or final plat approval shall be accompanied by a filing fee on file in the city secretary's office. Minor plats shall have a filing fee on file in the city secretary's office. No action shall be taken by the planning and zoning commission until the filing fee has been paid. The filing fee shall not be refunded if the subdivider fails to make formal application for preliminary and/or final plat approval or if the plat is disapproved. 
(d)  Each plat submitted for preliminary approval shall be accompanied by a certificate or letter from a title guaranty company or title attorney indicating a current search and certifying to at least the following concerning title to the land: 
(1)  A statement of records examined and date of examination. 
(2)  A description of the property in question, including a metes and bounds description of the tract. 
(3)  The name of the fee owner as of the date of examination and the date, file number, volume and page of the recording of the deed involved. 
(4)  The name, file, number, date of filing and volume and page of any lienholders. 
(5)  A general description of any easements or fee strips granted, along with the file number, date of filing, and volume and page of recording. 
(e)  The planning and zoning commission shall review the preliminary plat as to its conformity with the standards and specifications set forth in this chapter or referred to in this chapter. 
(f)  Pertinent copies of the preliminary plat data shall be submitted to the city engineer who shall check the data for conformity with the standards and specifications contained or referred to in this chapter. 
(g)  The city engineer shall return the preliminary plat data to the planning and zoning commission with his suggestions as to modifications, additions or alterations of such plat data. 
(h)  Within 30 days after the preliminary plat is formally filed, the planning and zoning commission shall conditionally approve or disapprove such plat or conditionally approve it with modifications. If it is conditionally disapproved or conditionally approved with modifications, the planning and zoning commission shall inform the subdivider, in writing, of the reasons at the time such action is taken. 
(i)  Conditional approval of a preliminary plat by the planning and zoning commission shall be deemed as expression of approval of the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the preparation of the final or record plat. Conditional approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute automatic approval of the final plat. 
(j)  Conditional approval of a preliminary plat will expire six months from the date of approval by the planning and zoning commission. However, if the subdivider shall apply in writing prior to the end of such six-month period, stating the reasons for needing an extension, this period may be extended for another six months, but not beyond a total of one year. 
(Code 1971, § 26-8) 
Secs. 90-93-90-120. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FINAL PLAT 

Sec. 90-121. - Conformance; contents. 
(a)  The subdivision final plat and accompanying data shall conform to the preliminary plat as conditionally approved by the planning and zoning commission incorporating any and all changes, modifications, alterations, corrections and conditions imposed by the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  The final plat shall be drawn in permanent ink on reproducible film sheets 24 inches wide and 36 inches long, with margins of not less than one inch on all sides. The plat shall be drawn at a scale of 100 feet to one inch or larger. Where more than one sheet is necessary to accommodate the entire area, an index sheet showing the entire subdivision at an appropriate scale shall be attached to the plat. 
(c)  The final plat shall contain all of the features required for preliminary plats in section 90-91. 
(d)  In addition to the various requirements for the preliminary plat, the final plat shall also include the following: 
(1)  The exact location, dimensions, name and description of all existing or recorded streets, alleys, reservations, easements, or other public rights-of-way within the subdivision, intersecting or contiguous with its boundary or forming such boundary, with accurate dimensions, bearing or deflecting angles and radii; area; and central angles, degree of curvature, tangent distance and length of all curves where appropriate. 
(2)  The exact location, dimensions, description and names of all proposed streets, alleys, drainage structures, parks, other public areas, reservations, easements or other rights-of-way, blocks, lots, and other sites within the subdivision with accurate dimensions; bearing or deflecting angles and radii; area; and central angles, degree of curvature, tangent distance and length of all curves where appropriate. 
(e)  The final plat shall also include the following: 
(1)  A certificate of ownership and dedication. 
(2)  The certificate of the registered engineer or licensed surveyor who surveyed and monumented the subdivision. 
(Code 1971, § 26-9) 
Sec. 90-122. - Processing. 
(a)  If desired by the subdivider and approved by the planning and zoning commission, the final plat may constitute only that portion of the approved preliminary plat which he proposes to record and develop. However, such portion shall conform to all the requirements of this chapter. 
(b)  After the subdivider is notified of approval of the preliminary plat, he may submit to the planning and zoning commission, at a regularly scheduled meeting, the final plat of the subdivision or portion thereof. 
(c)  No final plat will be considered unless a preliminary plat has been submitted. However, if an approved plat has been duly recorded and the subdivider wishes to increase the size of the lots by combining two or more lots or by combining one lot with a portion of the adjacent lot in such manner that no portion of a lot remains smaller than the original lots, no preliminary plat will be necessary. 
(d)  A final plat of an approved preliminary plat or a portion thereof shall be submitted to the planning and zoning commission within six months from the date of approval of the preliminary plat; otherwise the approval of the planning and zoning commission shall become null and void, unless an extension of time is applied for and granted by the planning and zoning commission. 
(e)  Formal application for final plat approval shall be made by the subdivider in writing to the planning and zoning commission at a regularly scheduled meeting. 
(f)  The subdivider shall submit the original tracing, one reproducible copy, and formal application for the final plat when application is made to the planning and zoning commission. 
(g)  Each plat submitted for final plat approval shall be accompanied by a supplemental report from a title guaranty company or title attorney in which the letter or title certificate required in subsection 90-92(d) is brought up to current date. 
(h)  Prior to approval of the final plat, the subdivider of any subdivision wherein public streets or easements are shown crossing private easements or fee strips shall, by letter to the planning and zoning commission, assume responsibility for seeing that any adjustments and protection of existing pipelines, electrical transmission lines, or other facilities shall be planned and provided for to the satisfaction of the holder of the private easements or fee strips and the city prior to the filing of the plat for record. 
(i)  The planning and zoning commission shall review the final plat as to its conformity with the standards and specifications set forth in this chapter or referred to in this chapter. A public hearing will be held by the planning and zoning commission on all requests for final approval of plats involving the replatting of a subdivision or part of a subdivision. Public notice of the hearing shall be given in accordance with state law. 
(j)  The planning and zoning commission shall approve the final plat if it conforms to the standards and specifications set forth in this chapter or referred to in this chapter and if all changes, modifications, alterations, corrections and conditions imposed by the planning and zoning commission have been satisfied. 
(k)  The planning and zoning commission shall disapprove the final plat if it does not conform to the standards and specifications set forth in this chapter or referred to in this chapter or if all changes, modifications, alterations, corrections and conditions imposed by the planning and zoning commission have not been satisfied. If the final plat is disapproved, the planning and zoning commission shall inform the subdivider in writing of the reasons at the time such action is taken. 
(l)  If the planning and zoning commission fails to either approve or disapprove the final plat within 30 days from the date of formal application for final plat approval, the plat shall be automatically approved. 
(m)  Administrative plat approval. The approval of minor plats is delegated to the city planner and city engineer. Minor plats are those that involve four or fewer lots which front on an existing street and do not require the creation of any new street or the extension of municipal facilities. The prepared plat shall contain a certificate of approval by the city planner and the city engineer. See exhibit E attached to Ordinance No. 889. The city planner and the city engineer may, for any reason, elect to present the plat to the planning and zoning commission for approval. The city planner and city engineer shall not disapprove a plat and shall be required to refer any plat which is not approved to the planning and zoning commission. The planning and zoning commission must act on the plat within 30 days after the date the plat is submitted for approval. 
(Code 1971, § 26-10) 
State Law reference- Plat approval procedure, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.009. 
Sec. 90-123. - Recording. 
(a)  After the subdivision final plat has been finally approved, the planning and zoning commission shall cause the final plat to be recorded with the county clerk in the county in which the subdivision lies. No plat shall be filed for record without the written consent of the subdivider. If the subdivider fails to give such written consent within 30 days of the date of final approval of the plat, the planning and zoning commission may at any time thereafter cancel such approval.
