(b)  Prior to the recording of the final plat, the subdivider shall meet the following requirements: 
(1)  The subdivider shall submit to the planning and zoning commission a check in the amount of the recordation fee. 
(2)  The subdivider shall obtain from the holder of any private easement or fee strip within the subdivision crossed by proposed streets or other public easements an instrument granting to the public the use of the public streets or easements over and across such private easements or fee strips for construction, operation, and maintenance of those public facilities normally using the type of public streets and easements indicated. This instrument shall be delivered to the planning and zoning commission to be filed for record along with the plat. 
(3)  The subdivider shall furnish the planning and zoning commission a letter from the holder of the private easements or fee strips in question, stating that arrangements for any required adjustments in pipelines, electric transmission lines, or other similar facilities have been made to the satisfaction of the holder of the easement. 
(4)  The subdivider shall provide the planning and zoning commission with a letter from the city engineer stating that arrangements for all matters pertaining to any necessary adjustments have been made to the satisfaction of that department. 
(Code 1971, § 26-11) 
Secs. 90-124-90-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 90-151. - Compliance required. 
    Except as provided in section 90-152, no subdivision preliminary or final plat shall be approved by the planning and zoning commission unless it conforms to the standards and specifications in this article. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13) 
Sec. 90-152. - Exceptions for townhouse subdivisions. 
(a)  The following exceptions to the standards and specifications set forth in this article shall be allowed so as to permit the development of townhouse subdivisions, but such exceptions shall apply only to those developments which fall within the definition of a townhouse subdivision as follows: 
(1)  A townhouse subdivision is a development in which it is proposed to partition land into individual lots and construct townhouses which may be individually owned and where the minimum lot sizes are to be less than required in section 90-218. 
(2)  A townhouse is one of a series of dwelling units, each designed for single-family occupancy, which dwelling units are structurally connected or immediately adjacent to each other without side yards between individual dwelling units, and whose walls between individual dwelling units are either party or lot line walls. In either case, the wall between individual dwelling units shall be a firewall. 
a.  A party wall is a wall used jointly by two parties under easement, erected upon a line separating two parcels of land, each of which is a separate real estate entity. 
b.  A lot line wall is a wall adjoining and parallel to the lot line used by the party upon whose lot the wall is located. Lot line walls may share common foundations. 
c.  A firewall is a wall of noncombustible construction which divides individual dwelling units and is to restrict the spread of fire. 
(3)  Open space is all private property under common ownership designated for recreation area, private park for use of the property owners within the subdivision, play lot area, plaza area, building setbacks other than those normally required, and ornamental areas open to general view and use within the subdivision. Open space does not include streets, utility easements, and required building setbacks. 
(4)  All townhouse subdivisions shall have direct access from at least one dedicated and accessible public street having a right-of-way of at least 50 feet. 
(5)  A building line of not less than 20 feet shall be required on all lots fronting, backing or siding on a street. A building line of not less than 20 feet shall be required on all lots siding upon the subdivision boundary. 
(6)  Lots shall be provided as follows: 
a.  No lot shall contain less than 2,500 square feet in area or be less than 25 feet in width except as provided in subsection (a)(6)b of this section. 
b.  The minimum lot width and area may be reduced under the provision that open space, as defined in this subsection, be dedicated in accordance with the following: 
1.  For every 100 square feet of open space provided, the minimum lot area may be reduced by 200 square feet and the width of the lot by two feet. However, no lot shall be reduced so as to have a lot area of less than 2,000 square feet or a width of less than 20 feet. 
2.  The location and intended use of the open space shall, in all cases, be subject to the approval of the planning and zoning commission. Such open space shall be dedicated to the city or conveyed as a private open space to the trustees of an association or similar organization under a permanent agreement for maintenance and responsibility, which agreement is acceptable to the city council and approved by the city attorney. 
(b)  Townhouse subdivisions shall provide two off-street parking spaces for each dwelling. Such off-street parking space shall be located on the same lot as the dwelling. 
(Code 1971, § 26-14; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 90-153-90-180. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - STREETS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86. 

Sec. 90-181. - General standards. 
(a)  Adequate streets shall be provided by the subdivider, and the arrangement, character, extent, width, grade, and location of each shall conform to the city's comprehensive plan and shall be considered in their relation to existing and planned streets, to topographical conditions, to safety and convenience, and in their appropriate relationship to the proposed uses of land to be served by such streets. The street layout shall be devised for the most advantageous development of the entire neighborhood. 
(b)  Existing streets in adjoining areas shall be continued, and such extensions shall be at least as wide as such existing streets and in alignment therewith. 
(c)  Where adjoining areas are not subdivided, the arrangement of streets in the subdivision shall make provision for the proper projection of streets into such unsubdivided areas. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(A)) 
Sec. 90-182. - Arterial streets. 
(a)  Arterial streets in a subdivision shall have a right-of-way width of at least 80 feet. However, arterial streets having a right-of-way width of less than 100 feet shall be increased to a width of 100 feet for a distance of 150 feet at the approach to a major street intersection, with a transition back to normal right-of-way over a distance of an additional 150 feet. 
(b)  Curves in arterial streets shall have a centerline radius of 2,000 feet or more. Reverse curves shall be separated by a minimum tangent of 100 feet. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(B)) 
Sec. 90-183. - Collector streets. 
(a)  Collector streets in a subdivision shall have a right-of-way of at least 60 feet. 
(b)  Curves in collector streets shall have a centerline radius of 800 feet or more. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(C)) 
Sec. 90-184. - Minor streets. 
(a)  Minor streets in a subdivision shall have a minimum right-of-way width of 50 feet with a minimum width of 32 feet from back of curb to back of curb. 
(b)  Reverse curves in minor streets shall have a centerline radius of 300 feet or more. 
(c)  Minor street offsets, when approved by the planning and zoning commission, must offset a minimum distance of 125 feet on centerline. 
(d)  The minimum design standards for a minor street shall be as follows: 
(1)  Surface: 1.5 inches (compacted) type D HMAC (hot mix asphaltic concrete). 
(2)  Base: six inches (compacted) crushed limestone or iron ore gravel. Iron ore gravel shall meet zero percent retained on the 2.5-inch sieve; 30 to 80 percent on the no. 40; no. 40 material shall have liquid limits (LL) less than 35 and plasticity index (PI) greater than four, less than 12; and California bearing ratio (CBR) greater than 50. 
(3)  Subgrade. If subgrade PI is greater than 20, it shall be lime stabilized to a depth of six inches. 
(4)  Concrete curb and gutter construction shall be in conformance with city standards and specifications. 
(5)  All materials and construction shall meet city and state department of transportation standards and specifications. Plans and specifications for the streets shall be prepared and sealed by a state registered professional engineer. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(D)) 
Sec. 90-185. - Intersections. 
(a)  All streets in a subdivision shall intersect at a 90-degree angle; however, variations may be approved by the planning and zoning commission. 
(b)  Acute angle intersections approved by the planning and zoning commission shall have 25-foot radii at acute corners. 
(c)  Street intersections with or extending to meet an existing street shall be tied to the existing street on centerline with dimensions and bearings to show relationship. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(E)) 
Sec. 90-186. - Culs-de-sac. 
(a)  Culs-de-sac in a subdivision shall not exceed 600 feet in length and shall have a turnaround of not less than 100 feet in diameter in residential areas and not less than 140 feet in diameter in commercial and industrial areas. 
(b)  Temporary turnarounds shall be provided at the end of a street that will be extended in the future where such street exceeds 400 feet in length, but such turnarounds shall not be placed on the final plat. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(F)) 
Sec. 90-187. - Alleys. 
    Alleys shall be prohibited in a subdivision. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(K)) 
Sec. 90-188. - Dead-end streets. 
    Dead-end streets shall be prohibited in a subdivision, except where such a street is required in accordance with subsection 90-181(c). In such case, the dead-end street shall not exceed 400 feet in length. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(G)) 
Sec. 90-189. - Partial or half streets. 
    Partial or half streets shall be prohibited in a subdivision. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(H)) 
Sec. 90-190. - Provisional reserve abutting acreage tracts. 
    A provisional one-foot reserve shall be used along the side or end of streets that abut acreage tracts, as follows: 
One-foot reserve dedicated to the public in fee as a buffer separation between the side or end of streets in subdivision plats where such streets abut adjacent acreage tracts, the condition of such dedication being that when the adjacent property is subdivided in a recorded plat, the one-foot reserve shall thereupon become vested in the public for street right-of-way purpose, and the fee title thereto shall revert to and revest in the dedicator, his heirs, assigns or successors. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(I)) 
Secs. 90-191-90-215. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LOTS AND BLOCKS 

Sec. 90-216. - Blocks. 
    The block length in residential areas in a subdivision shall not exceed 1,200 feet or be less than 600 feet. The block length along an arterial street shall not exceed 1,600 feet. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(J)) 
Sec. 90-217. - Lots generally. 
(a)  All lots shown on the subdivision plat shall be for residential purposes unless otherwise noted. 
(b)  Side lot lines shall be perpendicular or radial to street frontage and the following may be in lieu of bearings: All side lot lines are either perpendicular or radial to street frontage unless otherwise noted. 
(c)  Rear and side driveway access to arterial streets shall be prohibited. 
(d)  Double front lots are prohibited except when backing on arterial streets. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(L)) 
Sec. 90-218. - Minimum lot sizes. 
(a)  No lot in a subdivision shall be less than 75 feet in width or less than 110 feet in depth, unless otherwise provided. 
(b)  Radial lots fronting on the turnaround on a cul-de-sac may have a width of 60 feet at the building line; provided, however, such lots shall contain not less than 10,000 square feet. 
(c)  Corner lots shall have a width of not less than 80 feet. 
(d)  Corner lots siding on an arterial street shall have a width of not less than 95 feet. 
(e)  Lots facing or backing on an arterial street shall have a depth of not less than 120 feet. 
(f)  The minimum depth of lots backing on a natural drainage easement shall be 70 feet, measured between the drainage easement and the front lot line. Lots fronting on a natural drainage easement shall have a depth of not less than 70 feet, measured between the drainage easement and the rear lot line. Lots containing a natural drainage easement shall have a depth of not less than 70 feet, measured between the drainage easement and the front or rear lot line. Where such natural drainage easements are not parallel to the front or rear lot lines, the minimum depth shall be computed as the average of the sum of the distances as measured along the side lot lines. 
(g)  Lots not served by sanitary sewer shall conform to the requirements of the state department of health as to lot area for approved septic tanks. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(M)) 
Sec. 90-219. - Numbering. 
(a)  Blocks in a subdivision shall be numbered consecutively within the overall plat and/or sections of an overall plat as recorded. 
(b)  All lots shall be numbered consecutively within each block. Lot numbering may be cumulative throughout the subdivision if the numbering continues from block to block in a uniform manner that has been approved on an overall preliminary plat. 
(c)  All areas to be used for other than residential purposes shall be labeled as "reserves" and shall be labeled alphabetically rather than numerically. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(P)) 
Secs. 90-220-90-245. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING LINES 

Sec. 90-246. - Residential uses. 
(a)  A building line of not less than 25 feet shall be provided on the front of all lots in a subdivision. A building line of not less than ten feet shall be provided on the side of a corner lot; provided, however, that if the side street has lots facing on the same side of the street as the side of the corner lot, a building line of not less than 25 feet shall be provided on the side of the corner lot. A building line of not less than 20 feet shall be provided on the rear of all lots. Such rear building line shall not prohibit the erection or construction of a detached accessory building closer than 20 feet to the rear lot line. Detached accessory buildings include but are not limited to automobile storage garages, laundry rooms, garden shelters, hobby rooms and mechanical rooms. 
(b)  A building line of not less than 35 feet shall be provided on the front of all lots facing an arterial street. A building line of not less than 20 feet shall be provided on the rear of all lots backing on an arterial street. A building line of not less than 20 feet shall be provided on the side of a lot siding an arterial street; provided, however, that if the arterial street has lots facing on the same side of the street as the side of the corner lot, a building line of not less than 35 feet shall be provided on the side of the corner lot. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(N)(1)) 
Sec. 90-247. - Apartment uses. 
    Areas in a subdivision reserved for apartment use shall provide a building line of at least 20 feet on the front of all lots and 20 feet on the side of all corner lots. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(N)(2)) 
Sec. 90-248. - Other uses. 
(a)  Unless otherwise specified, a building line of not less than ten feet on the front of all lots and on the street side of corner lots shall be provided in a subdivision. 
(b)  When the opposite property has residential lots facing the lot, a front building line of not less than 25 feet shall be provided. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(N)(3)) 
Secs. 90-249-90-275. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - EASEMENTS AND UTILITIES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 106. 

Sec. 90-276. - Easements. 
(a)  Easements for drainage adjacent to lots, tracts or reserves in a subdivision shall be noted: 
"This easement shall be kept clear of fences, buildings, planting and other obstructions to the operations and maintenance of the drainage facility, and abutting property shall not be permitted to drain into this easement except by means of an approved drainage structure." 
(b)  Utility easements shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of the public and private utility companies. The minimum width of easements for city drainage, water and sanitary sewer facilities shall be 20 feet. Larger easements may be required as directed by the city engineer for facilities that cannot be effectively installed or maintained in a 20-foot width. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(O)) 
Sec. 90-277. - Utilities. 
(a)  The developer of a subdivision is required to install all water and sanitary sewer facilities, including pump and lift stations, taps and other appurtenances within the development. Such installation shall be at the developer's expense and shall be in accordance with city and state standards and specifications. 
(b)  Minimum pipe requirements shall be as follows: 
(1)  Water lines shall be ductile iron pipe or C-900, class 150 PVC. 
(2)  Gravity sanitary sewer lines shall be ductile iron pipe or SDR 26 PVC. 
(3)  Pressure sanitary sewer lines shall be ductile iron pipe or C-900, class 100 PVC. 
(c)  All new water and sanitary sewer facilities shall be connected to the city's system. 
(d)  Extensions of water and sanitary sewer facilities beyond the development shall be in accordance with city ordinances, standards and specifications, except that developers of developments outside the city limits shall be responsible for all extension costs. 
(e)  Plans and specifications for the water and sanitary sewer facilities shall be prepared and sealed by a state registered professional engineer. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(R)) 
Sec. 90-278. - Street lighting. 
    The developer is responsible for design and installation of street lighting for the subdivision. Streetlights shall have 100-watt high-pressure sodium lamps and shall be placed at all intersections, at the ends of culs-de-sac and at a spacing of 200 to 300 feet in between. A final street lighting plan shall be submitted to the city engineer for approval at the time of final platting. 
(Code 1971, § 26-13(S)) 
Chapter 94 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligations assumed by the city saved from repeal, § 1-9(1); any ordinance levying or imposing taxes not contained in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-9(5); any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing taxes for such improvements saved from repeal, § 1-9(7); administration, ch. 2; businesses, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Taxation, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 1.01 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 94-1-94-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROPERTY TAX[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Property taxation, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 1.01 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-26. - Delinquent tax subject to interest, penalties. 
(a)  All taxes not paid to the city by the due date shall be classified as delinquent and shall be subject to the payment of interest and penalties after delinquency as provided in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.01 et seq. 
(b)  All taxes that remain delinquent on July 1 of the year in which they become delinquent shall incur an additional penalty to defray costs of collection in an amount of 15 percent of the amount of taxes, penalty, and interest due. 
(c)  The city assessor and collector of taxes shall deliver a notice of delinquency and of the penalty to the property owner at least 30 days and not more than 60 days before July 1. 
(Code 1971, § 27-13) 
State Law reference- Additional penalty for costs of collection, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 33.07. 
Secs. 94-27-94-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FREEPORT GOODS EXEMPTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Authority, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.251. 

Sec. 94-56. - Authorized. 
    Beginning with the 1992 tax year, this section shall provide for the taxation exemption on all goods and inventories commonly referred to as "freeport goods" and exempt under article VIII, section 1-j of the state constitution and V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.251 to all businesses and industries in the city which can legally and properly qualify under the freeport exemption tax laws and criteria that has been or shall be adopted by the county central appraisal district. 
(Code 1971, § 27-16) 
State Law reference- Freeport goods exemption from taxation, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.251. 
Sec. 94-57. - Taxation of tangible personal property in transit. 
(a)  Definitions. The following terms have the same meaning as defined in section 11.253 of the Texas Tax Code, as amended. 
(1)  The terms "dealer's motor vehicle inventory," "dealer's vessel and outboard motor inventory," "dealer's heavy equipment inventory," and "retail manufactured housing inventory" have the meanings assigned by subchapter B, chapter 23 of the Texas Tax Code, as amended. 
(2)  The term "goods-in-transit" is defined to mean tangible personal property that: 
a.  Is acquired in or imported into this state to be forwarded to another location in this state or outside this state; 
b.  Is detained at a location in this state in which the owner of the property does not have a direct or indirect ownership interest for assembling, storing, manufacturing, processing, or fabricating purposes by the person who acquired or imported the property; 
c.  Is transported to another location in this state or outside this state not later than 175 days after the date the person acquired the property in or imported the property into this state; and 
d.  Does not include oil, natural gas, petroleum products, aircraft, dealer's motor vehicle inventory, dealer's vessel and outboard motor inventory, dealer's heavy equipment inventory, or retail manufactured housing inventory. 
(3)  The term "location" means a physical address. 
(4)  The term "petroleum product" means a liquid or gaseous material that is an immediate derivative of the refining of oil or natural gas. 
(b)  A person is not entitled to an exemption from taxation of the appraised value of that portion of the person's property that consists of goods-in-transit. A person's property consisting of goods-in-transit is hereby subject to ad valorem taxation pursuant to section 11.253 of the Texas Tax Code, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1474-11-07, 11-20-2007) 
Secs. 94-58-94-80. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - HOMESTEAD EXEMPTIONS 

Sec. 94-81. - Elderly persons. 
    Upon compliance with all applicable laws and ordinances, $20,000.00 of the assessed value of residence homesteads of persons 65 years of age or older shall be exempt from ad valorem taxes levied by the city. This shall extend to all homeowners 65 years of age and older living in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 27-50) 
State Law reference- Homestead exemptions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13(d)-(f). 
Sec. 94-82. - Disabled persons. 
    There is granted a homestead exemption of $20,000.00 to those homeowners who may be legally qualified and defined as disabled beginning with the 1989 tax year. 
(Code 1971, § 27-61) 
State Law reference- Exemptions authorized, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13(d)-(f). 
Secs. 94-83-94-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SALES AND USE TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- The one-percent sales and use tax was adopted by referendum. 
State Law reference- Sales and use tax authorized, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.001 et seq. 

Sec. 94-111. - Rate. 
    The rate of the tax imposed by this article shall be the rate imposed by the city for all other local sales and use taxes as authorized by the state legislature. 
(Code 1971, § 27-82) 
Sec. 94-112. - Imposed on telecommunications services. 
    A city sales tax is authorized and imposed upon all telecommunications services sold within the city. For purposes of this section, the sale of telecommunications services is consummated at the location of the telephone or other telecommunications device from which the call or other communication originates. If the point of origin cannot be determined, the sale is consummated at the address to which the call or other communication is billed. 
(Code 1971, § 27-81) 
State Law reference- Telecommunications sales, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210(b). 
Secs. 94-113-94-140. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 
State Law reference- Hotel occupancy tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 94-141. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Consideration means the cost of the room in a hotel only if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping, and does not include the cost of any food served or personal services performed by the hotel for the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying of such room for occupancy. 
    Hotel means a building in which members of the public obtain sleeping accommodations for consideration. The term includes a hotel, motel, tourist home, tourist house, tourist court, lodginghouse, inn, roominghouse, or bed and breakfast. The term does not include the following: 
(1)  A hospital, sanitarium, or nursing home; or 
(2)  A dormitory or other housing facility owned or leased and operated by an institution of higher education or a private or independent institution of higher education, as those terms are defined by V.T.C.A., Education Code § 61.003, used by the institution for the purpose of providing sleeping accommodations for persons engaged in an educational program or activity at the institution. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession or the right to the use or possession of any room in a hotel if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping and if the occupant's use, possession, or right to use or possess extends for a period of less than 30 days. 
    Occupant means anyone who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has a right to use or possess any room in a hotel if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping. 
    Person means any individual, company, corporation or association owning or operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
(Code 1971, § 27-33) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code §§ 156.001, 351.001. 
Sec. 94-142. - Penalties. 
    If any person shall fail to collect the tax imposed in this article or shall fail to file a report as required in this article or shall fail to pay to the city secretary the tax imposed in this article when such report or payment is due or shall file a false report, such person shall be punished, upon conviction, by a fine as provided in section 1-14. Such person who fails to collect or remit the tax within the time required or who violates the reporting requirements imposed by this article shall, in addition to the amount of any tax owed under this article, be liable to the city for the city's reasonable attorney fees and a penalty equal to 15 percent of the total amount of the tax owed. Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of 12 percent per annum beginning 60 days from the date due. 
(Code 1971, § 27-38) 
State Law reference- Penalties, V.T.C.A., Tax Code §§ 111.060, 351.004. 
Secs. 94-143-94-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ASSESSMENT AND COLLECTION 

Sec. 94-171. - Levy of tax. 
    There is levied a tax upon the occupancy of any sleeping room furnished by any hotel in the city or within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction, where the cost of occupancy is at the rate of $2.00 or more per day. The tax shall be equal to seven percent of the consideration paid by the occupant of such room to such hotel. 
(Code 1971, § 27-32(a)) 
Sec. 94-172. - Exemption. 
(a)  A United States governmental entity described in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 156.103(a) is exempt from the payment of tax authorized by this division. 
(b)  A state governmental entity described in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 156.103(b) shall pay the tax imposed by this division but is entitled to a refund of the tax paid. 
(c)  A person who is described by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 156.103(d) is exempt from the payment of tax authorized by this division. 
(d)  A person who is described by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 156.103(c) shall pay the tax imposed by this division but the state governmental entity with whom the person is associated is entitled to a refund of the tax paid. 
(e)  To receive a refund of tax paid under this division, the governmental entity entitled to the refund must file a refund claim on a form provided by the city and containing the information required by the city. The state comptroller by rule shall prescribe the form that must be used and the information that must be provided. 
(f)  A governmental entity may file a refund claim with the city under this division only for each calendar quarter for all reimbursements accrued during that quarter. 
(Code 1971, § 27-32(b), (c)) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.006. 
Sec. 94-173. - Collection. 
    Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel within the city or within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction shall collect the tax imposed in section 94-171 for the city. 
(Code 1971, § 27-34) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.0025. 
Sec. 94-174. - Reports. 
    On the last day of the month following each monthly period, every person required in section 94-173 to collect the tax imposed in this division shall file a report with the city secretary showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies in the preceding month, the amount of tax collected on such occupancies and any other information as the city secretary may reasonably require. Such person shall pay the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. The city will receive three percent of all proceeds collected under this division for collection expenses incurred. 
(Code 1971, § 27-35) 
Sec. 94-175. - Rules and regulations. 
    The finance director shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied in this division and shall, upon reasonable notice, have access to books and records necessary to enable him to determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this division and the amount of taxes due under this division. 
(Code 1971, § 27-36) 
Sec. 94-176. - Administration, management and supervision of programs and activities funded by tax. 
    The city council may delegate the administration, management and supervision of programs and activities funded by the tax levied under this division pursuant to V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq. 
(Code 1971, § 27-37; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 94-177. - Duty and liability of hotel or motel purchaser or buyer. 
    Any person purchasing a hotel or motel shall retain out of the purchase price an amount sufficient to cover any hotel or motel tax due the city. If the buyer does not remit to the city such amount or show proof that the hotel or motel is current in remitting its occupancy taxes, the buyer shall become liable for any delinquent hotel or motel occupancy taxes owed on the purchased hotel or motel. 
(Code 1971, § 27-39) 
Sec. 94-178. - Collection by city. 
(a)  The city attorney or other attorney acting for the city may bring suit against a person required to collect the tax imposed by this division and pay the collections over to the city and who has failed to file a tax report or pay the tax when due to collect the tax not paid or to enjoin the person from operating a hotel in the city until the tax is paid or the report filed, as applicable, as provided by the court's order. 
(b)  The remedy provided by this section is in addition to other available remedies. 
(Code 1971, § 27-40) 
State Law reference- Tax collection, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.004. 
Sec. 94-179. - Collection procedures on purchase of hotel. 
(a)  If a person who is liable for the payment of a tax imposed under this division is the owner of a hotel and sells the hotel, the successor to the seller or the seller's assignee shall withhold an amount of the purchase price sufficient to pay the amount due until the seller provides a receipt by a person designated by the city to provide a receipt showing that the amount has been paid or a certificate that no tax is due. 
(b)  The purchaser of a hotel who fails to withhold an amount of the purchase price as required by this section is liable for the amount required to be withheld to the extent of the value of the purchase price. 
(c)  The purchaser of a hotel may request that the person designated by the city to provide a receipt under subsection (a) of this section issue a certificate stating that no tax is due or issue a statement of the amount required to be paid before a certificate may be issued. The person designated by the city shall issue the certificate or a statement not later than the 60th day after the date that the person receives the request. 
(d)  If the person designated by the city to provide a receipt under subsection (a) of this section fails to issue the certificate or statement within the period provided by subsection (c) of this section, the purchaser is released from the obligation to withhold the purchase price or pay the amount due. 
(Code 1971, § 27-41) 
State Law reference- Collection procedures, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.0041. 
Sec. 94-180. - Reimbursement for collection expenses. 
(a)  The city may permit a person who is required to collect and pay over to the city the tax authorized by this division to withhold not more than one percent of the amount collected and required to be reported as reimbursement to the person for the costs in collecting the tax. 
(b)  The city may provide that the reimbursement provided by this section be forfeited because of a failure to pay the tax or to file a report as required by the city. 
(Code 1971, § 27-42) 
State Law reference- Reimbursement for collection expenses, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.005. 
Secs. 94-181-94-205. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ADMINISTRATION OF FUNDS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Use of funds, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.101 et seq. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 94-206. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to delegate and contract for the management and supervision of the following programs and activities funded with the hotel room tax: 
(1)  Funding the establishment, improvement, or maintenance of a visitor information center. 
(2)  The furnishing of the facilities, personnel and materials for the registration of convention delegates or registrants. 
(3)  Advertising and conducting solicitation and promotional programs to attract tourists and convention delegates or registrants to the city or its vicinity. 
(4)  The encouragement, promotion, improvement and application of the arts. 
(5)  Advertising and conducting solicitations and promotional programs to encourage tourists and convention delegates to visit preserved historic sites or museums. 
(Code 1971, § 27-43) 
Secs. 94-207-94-230. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Convention and Visitors Bureau Board 

Sec. 94-231. - Created. 
(a)  The city council shall appoint or remove a seven-member convention and visitors bureau board for the Nacogdoches Convention and Visitors Bureau (referred to as the "CVB") to administer the funds available under this division and to carry on the purpose of this division. Members of the board may be selected from applications received from interested residents and/or members from membership of the following tourism and community groups: 
(1)  One representative from the restaurant industry; 
(2)  Three representatives from retail merchants, including restaurants; 
(3)  One representative from historic interests, restoration, or preservation; 
(4)  One representative from a bed and breakfast providing bed tax revenues; 
(5)  Three representatives from the hotel/motel and or bed and breakfast industry; 
(6)  One representative from university interests; 
(7)  One representative from minority owned business interests; and 
(8)  Two at large community representatives. 
(b)  The city council may, at its sole discretion, consider persons recommended by the current board of directors, accept applications and/or nominations from the public at large or appoint from a membership list of persons who are members of tourism-related groups. The city council shall not be required to accept any recommendations but shall have the authority to appoint any city citizen. 
(Code 1971, § 27-44; Ord. No. 1508-10-08, 10-21-2008; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1689-12-14 , 12-2-14) 
Sec. 94-232. - Terms. 
    The terms of office of the members of the convention and visitors bureau board shall be three years, but appointment to the board shall be arranged so that no more than three members shall complete their full term in any one year. In determining the years of service and eligibility for reappointment, the city council shall follow its board and committee appointments policy. 
(Code 1971, § 27-45; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1689-12-14 , 12-2-14) 
Sec. 94-233. - Duties and responsibilities. 
    There is vested in the convention and visitors bureau board the full, complete and entire management and control of the convention and visitors bureau. 
(Code 1971, § 27-46) 
Sec. 94-234. - Rules of procedure; officers. 
(a)  The convention and visitors bureau board shall adopt such bylaws, rules and regulations as it may deem proper. Bylaws and amendments thereto must be submitted to the city council for consideration and approval prior to implementation. 
(b)  As a minimum, the board shall elect a chair, vice-chair, secretary, and treasurer to the board to keep such minutes and records as the board may deem necessary. 
(Code 1971, § 27-47; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 94-235. - Quorum. 
    Four members of the convention and visitors bureau board shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of business. 
(Code 1971, § 27-48; Ord. No. 1689-12-14 , 12-2-14) 
Sec. 94-236. - Meetings. 
    The place, time, date and location of meetings of the convention and visitors bureau board shall be established by the board. Special meetings of the board may be called by the chair or three members of the board at such place and time as the chair may designate. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49) 
Sec. 94-237. - Open records, open meetings. 
    All meetings of the convention and visitors bureau board and all records of the board are subject to state laws in regard to open meetings and open records legislation. The meeting agenda shall be provided to the city secretary to be posted at least 72 hours prior to any regular meeting. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.1) 
Sec. 94-238. - Budget. 
    The convention and visitors bureau shall submit a budget for annual operations to the city secretary prior to July 15 each year. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.2) 
Sec. 94-239. - Allocation of funds. 
    The city council shall consider budget requests and allocate funds to the convention and visitors bureau board on a quarterly basis. Such amounts shall be paid no later than February 10, May 10, August 10 and November 10 of each fiscal year. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.3; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 94-240. - Reports. 
    The convention and visitors bureau board shall develop a marketing plan and program of work. A progress report of activities and financial operations shall be made to the city following the end of each calendar quarter. Each report shall include income and disbursements for the preceding quarter and the fiscal year to date. The first report each year shall include an annual report of the previous year's activities. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.4) 
Sec. 94-241. - Bank account. 
    The convention and visitors bureau board shall deposit funds received from the city in a separate bank account, established by the board in the depository that maintains all other public funds of the city. The fund shall be titled the "Nacogdoches Convention and Visitors Bureau Fund," and all monies paid by the city from hotel or motel tax for services by the board shall be deposited into designated accounts. The funds shall not be commingled with any other funds of the convention and visitors bureau, and the board shall have custody and responsibility for the funds, the bank account, and all records relating thereto. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.5) 
Sec. 94-242. - Records retention. 
    All original books of entry of the convention and visitors bureau board shall be maintained in perpetuity. All canceled checks and other financial records shall be maintained for a period of six years or in conformance with the state laws regulating records retention. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.6) 
Sec. 94-243. - Audit. 
    All accounting procedures, records and reports of the convention and visitors bureau board shall be available for inspection by a duly authorized city representative. An independent audit of all of the program's financial records or a report on agreed upon procedures by a qualified certified public accountant shall be furnished to the city within 90 days of the close of each fiscal year. The type of report shall be confirmed during the budget adoption process and shall be funded as a line item in the annual convention and visitors bureau budget. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.7) 
Sec. 94-244. - Bond. 
    Convention and visitors bureau board members and/or staff designated to withdraw funds shall be bonded in the amount of $50,000.00. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.8) 
Sec. 94-245. - Compensation and expenditure of funds. 
    All expenditures of the convention and visitors bureau board shall be in accordance with applicable state laws and city ordinances as outlined in V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et seq. and this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.9) 
Sec. 94-246. - Authority to contract. 
(a)  The convention and visitors bureau board is authorized to contract with the Nacogdoches County Chamber of Commerce for joint facility and fixed office costs. The board is also authorized to contract or develop a memorandum of agreement in regard to shared administrative activities of convention and visitors bureau staff and Chamber of Commerce staff. The authority granted in this division is not in limitation of other power or authority of the convention and visitors bureau to contract as allowed under law. 
(b)  The agreement between the city and the convention and visitors bureau shall be in writing and shall be approved by the city council and the board of the convention and visitors bureau. 
(Code 1971, § 27-49.10; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 94-247-94-275. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1652-12-13, adopted Dec. 17, 2013, repealed Art. V in its entirety and enacted a new Art. V to read as set out herein. Former Art. V, §§ 94-276-94-280, 94-282-94-288, pertained to economic development tax abatement and utility extension policy and derived from Ord. No. 1316-2-03, §§ I-V, VII-XIII, adopted Feb. 18, 2003; Ord. No. 1498-9-08, adopted Sept. 2, 2008; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, adopted Nov. 17, 2009; Ord. No. 1608-10-12, adopted Oct. 2, 2012. 
State Law reference- Property redevelopment and tax abatement act, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 312.001 et seq. 

Sec. 94-276. - Definitions. 
    The meaning of terms used in this article shall be as follows: 
    Company means an applicant for sales tax revenue sharing approved by the city council and which enters into an agreement regarding such within the city. 
    Company sales tax revenues means that portion of the gross sales tax revenue derived from the one percent municipal sales tax remitted by company to the state comptroller's office for the benefit of the city, less the two percent administrative charge. 
    Facade means a face of a building, usually the front. 
    Gross sales tax revenues means the city's share received from the state comptroller's office of municipal sales tax, such as that presently in effect pursuant to V.T.C.A., Tax Code §§ 321.101 and 321.103, resulting from sales tax for the city derived from applicable standard industrial classification (SIC) code categories. The state comptroller may withhold up to two percent of the city's one percent municipal tax for auditor expenses and other costs associated with collections and administration of the tax. 
    Infill construction means a new construction on vacant land that is done in a manner as to be compatible with the scale and character of the property, neighborhood or environment. 
    New construction means any new building constructed which may or may not relate architecturally to any of its neighbors on a lot where an existing structure is demolished to accommodate such new building. 
    Rehabilitation means the process of returning a property to a state of utility, through repair or alteration. 
    Restoration means to bring back to a previous condition. In a restoration an earlier appearance of the building is recreated, both in form and detail. Original elements that have been covered are exposed, and missing pieces replaced with new ones that match the original. 
(Ord. No. 1652-12-13, 12-17-2013) 
Sec. 94-277. - General purpose and objectives. 
    The city is committed to promoting high quality development in all parts of the city and to ongoing improvement in the quality of life for its citizens. These objectives are generally served by enhancement, expansion and diversification of the local economy. The purpose of the economic development programs is to promote retention, expansion and recruitment of existing and new industrial and commercial facilities. In accordance with V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 312, in which the city has and does resolve to elect to participate, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 378, Neighborhood Empowerment Zones, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 380, Economic Development Programs, and other available economic development programs which meet the economic goals and objectives of the city, the city may: 
(1)  Under V.T.C.A., Tax Code, ch. 312 or V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 378 grant tax abatement on the value added to particular real and/or personal property by a specific development proposal; 
(2)  Create and adopt a neighborhood empowerment zone thereby and thereafter exercise powers regarding waivers of certain fees, certain sales tax refunding, property tax abatement, and other powers under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, § 378.004; 
(3)  May, under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code, ch. 380 enter into diverse agreements for programs including loans and grants of public money and providing personnel and services of the city; and 
(4)  Participate in any other valid law, code, or program of the State of Texas or United States of America or their agencies for economic development. 
    Economic development programs will not be ordinarily considered for projects, which would develop without such incentives unless it can be demonstrated higher development standards, aesthetic improvements, and/or other development and community goals will be achieved through the use of economic development programs. The benefits of economic development programs are granted to owners of improvements on real property and/or personal property. If an applicant leases a facility to which an application will relate, the agreement shall be executed with owner of the property on which the facility is located as well as the lessee/applicant. 
    Within the context of these goals, the city will, on a case-by-case basis, give consideration to providing economic development incentives as a stimulus for economic development in the city. It is the policy of the city that said consideration will be provided in accordance with procedures and criteria adopted and from time to time changed by the city. Nothing herein shall imply or suggest the city is under obligation to provide an incentive and/or any extension of any incentive given to any applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1652-12-13, 12-17-2013) 
Sec. 94-278. - Criteria for tax abatement. 
    The city shall adopt and readopt criteria for tax abatement every two years and also adopt procedures for creation of reinvestment zones, applications and written agreements for such abatement. 
(Ord. No. 1652-12-13, 12-17-2013) 
Sec. 94-279. - Use of criteria for determining tax abatement and value of incentives. 
    The criteria adopted by the city for tax abatement will be used to determine if it is in the best interest of the city to provide tax abatement to a particular applicant. The terms and conditions of each tax abatement agreement shall be negotiated on an individual basis and meet the requirements of V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 312. 
(Ord. No. 1652-12-13, 12-17-2013) 
Secs. 94-280, 94-281. - Reserved. 
Sec. 94-282. - Sales tax revenue sharing. 
    The city will, on a case-by-case basis, give consideration to providing incentives permitted under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 378 or programs under V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 380 in the form of sales tax revenue sharing, grants, or other commitments as a stimulus for economic development in Nacogdoches. It is the policy of the city that said consideration will be provided in accordance with the procedures and criteria adopted by the city. Nothing herein shall imply or suggest that the city is under obligation to provide any incentive to any applicant. 
(Ord. No. 1652-12-13, 12-17-2013) 
Sec. 94-283. - Criteria for sales tax revenue sharing or grants related to sales tax. 
    Any application for sales tax revenue sharing shall be reviewed by the city, and the proposed project must conform to the general guidelines adopted by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1652-12-13, 12-17-2013) 
Chapter 98 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; utilities, ch. 106; zoning, ch. 118. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 98-1-98-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - USE OF RIGHTS-OF-WAY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 98-26. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article and any permit granted in accordance with this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given in this section, unless otherwise specifically provided in this article, the context clearly indicates otherwise, or such meaning would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council: 
    Cell site means the location of a transmitter/receiver and backhaul network interface which provides telephonic or telecommunications type service to subscribers. The locations include single pole mounted receiver/transmitter units located on new or existing antenna structures and receiver/transmitter units located in buildings and on rooftops. 
    Certificated telecommunications provider means a person who has been issued a certificate of convenience and necessity, certificate of operating authority, or service provider certificate of operating authority by the state public utilities commission to offer local exchange telephone service. 
    Certificated telecommunications provider permit means the nonexclusive privilege granted by the city, consistent with the public ways act, authorizing a certificated telecommunications provider to erect, construct, reconstruct, operate, dismantle, test, use, maintain, repair, rebuild or replace a local exchange telephone system that occupies any public ways. 
    Certificated telecommunications provider permittee means the person or the person's legal successor in interest who is issued a certificated telecommunications provider permit in accordance with this article. 
    Engineering department means the engineering department of the city. 
    Facilities means all equipment used and useful in a telecommunications system. 
    Federal Communications Commission (FCC) means the Federal Communications Commission or its legally appointed successor. 
    Force majeure means acts of God, landslides, earthquakes, lightning, fires, hurricanes, volcanic activity, storms, floods, washouts, droughts, civil disturbances, acts of terrorism or of the public enemy, partial or entire failure of utilities, strikes, explosions, lockouts or other industrial disturbances, insurrections, public riots or other similar events which are not reasonably within the control of the parties involved. 
    Laws means all applicable: 
(1)  City ordinances, resolutions, rules and regulations; 
(2)  State laws and regulations; and 
(3)  Federal laws and regulations, including but not limited to the act, the public ways act, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 283.001 et seq. and the Public Utility Regulatory Act V.T.C.A., Utilities Code § 11.001 et seq. 
    Local access transport area (LATA) means that geographic area and communication system in which the city is located and in which any certificated telecommunications provider is authorized by the state public utilities commission to provide local exchange telephone service. 
    Local exchange telephone service means telecommunications service provided within an exchange to establish connections between customer premises within the exchange, including connections between a customer's premises and a long distance provider serving the exchange; it does not include a private telecommunications system or a wireless telecommunications system. 
    Local exchange telephone system means any system of communications lines, cables, equipment or facilities which are used to provide a local exchange telephone service in the public ways. 
    Penalties means any and all monetary penalties provided for in this article. 
    Permit means any certificated telecommunications provider permit, private telecommunications system permit, or wireless telecommunications system permit granted under this article. 
    Permit fee means a private telecommunications system permit fee or wireless telecommunications system permit fee. 
    Permittee means any certificated telecommunications provider permittee, private telecommunications system permittee, or wireless telecommunications system permittee authorized under this article. 
    Person means an individual, sole proprietorship, corporation, association, partnership, or other form of organization authorized to do business in the state, and includes any natural person. 
    Private telecommunications system means any system of communications lines, cables, equipment or facilities which are used to provide a telephone, video, data, telemetry, intercom or telecommunications service that in any manner occupies public ways. A private telecommunications system does not include a local exchange telephone system; a cable television system; a telephone system franchised by the city; or any part of a federal, state, county or local government-owned communications system. 
    Private telecommunications system permit means the nonexclusive privilege granted by the city authorizing a person to erect, construct, reconstruct, operate, dismantle, test, use, maintain, repair, rebuild or replace a private telecommunications system that occupies any public ways. 
    Private telecommunications system permit fee means the fees that must be paid to the city under subsection 98-88(b)(2) for the right to hold a private telecommunications system permit. 
    Private telecommunications system permit request fee means the fees that must be paid to the city under subsection 98-88(b)(1) to request a private telecommunications system permit. 
    Private telecommunications system permittee means the person or the person's legal successor in interest who is issued a private telecommunications system permit in accordance with this article for the erection, construction, reconstruction, operation, dismantling, testing, use, maintenance, repairing, rebuilding or replacing of a private telecommunications system in the city. 
    Public utilities commission (PUC) means the state public utilities commission or its legally appointed successor. 
    Public ways means the area on, below, or above a public roadway, street, public sidewalk, alley, waterway, or utility easement in which the city has an interest, but does not include the airwaves above a right-of-way with regard to a wireless telecommunications system. No reference in this article to public ways shall be deemed to be a representation or guarantee by the city that its interests or other rights in such property are sufficient to permit its use for the installation and maintenance of a telecommunications system, and the permittee shall be deemed to gain only those rights which the city has the undisputed right and power to give. 
    Quarterly private revenue fee means the fee that must be paid to the city on January 1, April 1, July 1, and September 1, as prescribed in subsection 98-88(b)(4), based on the private telecommunications system permittee's total gross revenues for that quarter. 
    Quarterly wireless revenue fee means the fee that must be paid to the city on January 1, April 1, July 1, and September 1 of each year, as prescribed by subsection 98-88(a)(4), based on the wireless telecommunications system permittee's total gross revenues for that quarter. 
    Regulated permit means a private telecommunications system permit or a wireless telecommunications system permit. 
    Regulated permittee means a private telecommunications system permittee or a wireless telecommunications system permittee. 
    Regulated telecommunications system means a private telecommunications system or a wireless telecommunications system. 
    Revenue fee means a quarterly private telecommunications system revenue fee or a quarterly wireless telecommunications system revenue fee. 
    Telecommunications system means a local exchange telephone system, a private telecommunications system, or a wireless telecommunications system authorized hereunder. 
    Total gross revenues means all cash, credits, property of any kind or nature, or other consideration received directly or indirectly by a regulated permittee, its affiliates, subsidiaries, parent and any person in which the regulated permittee has a financial interest, or from any source whatsoever, arising from or attributable to the sale, lease, rental or exchange of regulated telecommunications system services or equipment by the regulated permittee within the city or in any way derived from the operation of its regulated telecommunications systems, including but not limited to any interconnection between its regulated telecommunications system in the city and any telecommunications system whatsoever. This sum shall be the basis for computing the revenue fee. Such sum shall not include any bad debts; deposits; promotional or vendor discounts or credits; or sales, service occupation or other excise taxes to the extent that such taxes are charged separately from normal service charges and are remitted by the regulated permittee directly to the taxing authority. 
    Wireless telecommunications system means any system capable of providing radio communications that encompasses mobile and ancillary communication services for business and residential subscribers using small cordless telephone devices which communicate using cell sites and occupying the public ways. 
    Wireless telecommunications system permit means the nonexclusive privilege granted by the city authorizing a person to erect, construct, reconstruct, operate, dismantle, test, use, maintain, repair, rebuild or replace a wireless telecommunications system, including all cell sites used in the operation thereof, that occupies any public ways. 
    Wireless telecommunications system permit fee means the fee that must be paid to the city under subsection 98-88(a)(2) for the right to hold a wireless telecommunications system permit. 
    Wireless telecommunications system permit request fee means the fee that must be paid to the city, per cell site, under subsection 98-88(a)(1), to request a wireless telecommunications system permit. 
    Wireless telecommunications system permittee means the person or the person's legal successor in interest who is issued a wireless telecommunications system permit in accordance with this article for the erection, construction, reconstruction, operation, dismantling, testing, use, maintenance, repairing, rebuilding or replacing of a wireless telecommunications system that occupies any public ways in the city. 
(Code 1971, § 281/2-22; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 98-27. - Findings and purpose. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, the city council makes the following findings: 
(1)  It is in the public interest to promote competition in the provision of telecommunications services and to ensure the availability of broadband transmission services to all residences and businesses. 
(2)  It is in the public interest, and consistent with its police powers and with the laws, for the city to exercise its historical right and authority to manage the public ways to ensure the health, safety and welfare of the public and to obtain fair, adequate, and uniform compensation for the use of city property. 
(3)  It is in the public interest to establish nondiscriminatory procedures and requirements to authorize the provision of competitive telecommunications services using the public ways that do not impose administrative burdens upon the city or providers of such services and that are consistent with the laws. 
(4)  This article establishing rules governing the use of the city's public ways is authorized by this article and by other applicable laws. 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to establish a competitively neutral policy for use of public ways to: 
(1)  Permit nondiscriminatory access to the public ways for providers of telecommunications services; 
(2)  Manage the public ways, consistent with the laws, so that the cost to the public of locating facilities within the public ways is minimized; 
(3)  Establish a uniform method of compensating the city for the use of its public ways by providers of telecommunications services; 
(4)  Promote competition among telecommunications service providers and encourage the universal availability of modern telecommunications services to all city residents and businesses; and 
(5)  Minimize congestion, inconvenience, visual blight and other adverse effects on the public ways. 
(Ord. No. 1192-2-00, § 1, 2-1-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 98-28. - Scope. 
(a)  To the extent authorized under the laws, this article is subject to this Code and to general ordinance provisions passed pursuant to this Code affecting matters of general city concern and not merely existing contractual rights in effect or made effective. Nothing in this article shall be deemed to waive the requirements of the various city codes and ordinances regarding permits, fees to be paid or the manner of construction. 
(b)  This article specifically complies with V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 283.001 et seq., Management of Public Right-of-Way used by the telecommunications provider in municipality referred to in this article as the Public Ways Act, which established state-wide uniform standards for authorization and regulation of how certified telecommunications providers use their public ways, including payment of public ways fees to compensate municipalities for allowing such use. 
(c)  Except as forth in the Public Ways Act, this article specifically complies with, and applies to all telecommunications service providers regulated under, titles II and III of the Communications Act of 1934, as amended (47 USC 201 et seq. and 47 USC 301 et seq.) the act, and under the jurisdiction of the PUC. No consent granted under this article authorizes the provision of any services not authorized by titles II and III of the act or by the PUC. Cable service and open video systems, as defined in title IV of the act, and any other content-based services, expressly are excluded from the requirements hereunder. 
(d)  Both the permittee and city shall comply with all applicable laws. 
(e)  If any section, provision or clause of this article challenged by a third party as invalid or unenforceable is held by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid or unenforceable or is preempted by applicable laws, the remainder of this article shall not be affected and shall continue to be enforced by the city. 
(f)  The city council shall be vested with the power and authority to reasonably regulate the exercise of the privileges permitted by this article in the public interest. A permittee shall not be relieved of the obligations to comply with any of the provisions of this article by reason of any failure of the city to enforce prompt compliance, nor does the city waive or limit any of its rights under this article by reason of such failure or neglect. 
(g)  This article does not give the city the right to authorize operations by permittees that otherwise is the right of the FCC or PUC. This article is expressly limited to establishing the requirements for grant of permits to use the public ways. 
(Code 1971, § 281/2-21; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 98-29. - Existing telecommunications systems. 
    Telecommunications systems, which had been constructed or placed in the city's public ways prior to February 10, 2000, may remain within the public ways provided that the permittee of such telecommunications system complies with the sections of this article as they relate thereto. 
(Code 1971, § 281/2-31) 
Secs. 98-30-98-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 98-56. - Administration. 
(a)  Consistent with the public ways act, a permittee shall report information that the city manager requires in the form and manner prescribed by the city manager relating to the use of public ways authorized by a permit granted under this article. 
(b)  The city manager shall report to the city council the city manager's determination that a permittee has failed to comply with this article. 
(c)  If the permittee is wholly or partially unable to carry out the obligations under the permit as a result of force majeure, the permittee shall give the city prompt notice of such force majeure, describing the force majeure in reasonable detail. The permittee's obligations under its permit, other than for the payment of monies due, shall not be deemed in violation or default for the duration of the force majeure. The permittee must use its best efforts to remedy as soon as possible, under the circumstances, the permittee's inability, by reason of force majeure, to carry out the responsibilities and duties under the permit. 
(Code 1971, § 281/2-37; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 98-57. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city manager shall administer this article and enforce compliance with a permit granted under this article. 
(b)  In addition to any other rights set out elsewhere in this article, the city reserves the right to declare a forfeiture of the permit, and all the permittee's rights arising thereunder, if: 
(1)  The permittee violates any material provision of the permit. 
(2)  The permittee is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to have practiced any fraud or deceit upon the city. 
(3)  There is a final determination that the permittee has failed, refused, neglected or is otherwise unable to obtain and/or maintain any permit required by any federal or state regulatory body regarding the permittee's operation of the telecommunications system within the city. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the following are material provisions of this article, allowing the city, without limitation, to exercise its rights under this section or as set forth elsewhere in this article: 
(1)  The invalidation, failure to pay or any suspension of a regulated permittee's payments of permit fees or revenue fees to the city for use of the public ways. 
(2)  Any failure by the regulated permittee to submit timely reports regarding the calculation of its total gross revenues. 
(3)  Any failure by the permittee to maintain the insurance required under this article. 
(4)  Any failure by the permittee to maintain the bonds required under this article. 
(5)  Any failure by the permittee to otherwise fully comply with the requirements of sections 98-29 and 98-86 through 98-98. 
(d)  In addition to any rights set out elsewhere in this article, as well as its rights under this Code, the city reserves the right at its sole option to apply any of the following, alone or in combination: 
(1)  Impose a financial penalty of up to $1,000.00, per violation; or 
(2)  Suspend the permittee's permit rights until the permittee corrects or otherwise remedies the violation. 
(e)  In determining which remedy or remedies are appropriate, the city shall consider the nature of the violation, the persons burdened by the violation, the nature of the remedy required in order to prevent further such violations, and any other matters the city deems appropriate. 
(f)  The city shall give permittee 30 days' prior written notice of its intent to exercise its rights under this section, stating the reasons for such action. If permittee cures the stated reason within the 30-day notice period, or if the permittee initiates efforts satisfactory to the city to remedy the stated reason and the efforts continue in good faith, the city shall not exercise its remedy rights. If permittee fails to cure the stated reason within the 30-day notice period, or if the permittee does not undertake and/or maintain efforts satisfactory to the city to remedy the stated reason, then the city council may, after providing permittee the right to a hearing, impose any or all of the remedies available under this section. However, in no event shall the city exercise its rights under this section if a bona fide, good faith dispute exists between the city and the permittee. 
(Code 1971, § 281/2-38; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 98-58-98-85. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - PERMITS 

Sec. 98-86. - Regulated permits. 
(a)  No person, whether public, private, for profit or not for profit, shall construct, operate or continue to operate a regulated telecommunications system, including any modifications thereto, which occupies the public ways within the city without having been issued an appropriate regulated permit by the city council. 
(b)  Each applicant for a regulated permit shall demonstrate to the city that it is legally, financially and technically qualified to be granted the regulated permit. Evidence to demonstrate such qualifications may include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Experience providing the proposed services; 
(2)  Authorizations to provide such service granted by the Federal Communications Commission, the state public utilities commission, and other states or municipalities; 
(3)  Previous years' audited financial statements for the applicant, individual financial statements for principals or investors, or other such financial information as the city may desire; and 
(4)  Technical and operating characteristics of the proposed telecommunications system and facilities, including the information concerning use of existing utility poles and conduits required under section 98-91. 
(c)  Any modification to a regulated telecommunications system only can be made upon amendment by the city of the applicable regulated permit (referred to as the "permit amendment"). The regulated permittee must apply for such permit amendment. Such application must describe all proposed changes to the regulated telecommunications system and must demonstrate that such changes comply with all requirements under this article. 
(d)  Nothing in this section shall preclude a regulated permittee from entering into a contract for the use of any portion of its regulated telecommunications system with any person or other entity for any services, whether specified in this article or not, provided that such person or entity is another permittee and has assumed responsibility for obtaining any required authority from the city. 
(e)  All regulated permits granted under this division shall be nonexclusive. The city expressly reserves the right to grant regulated permits for the use of the public ways to provide telecommunications services to other persons, as well as the right, in its own name as a municipality, to use the public ways for similar or different purposes allowed regulated permittees under this article, by regulated permit or otherwise. 
(f)  The regulated permittee must maintain a local business office open to the public during normal business hours for the purpose of handling customer service. All books and records required under this division must be maintained in this local office. 
(g)  The act of granting, amending, denying or terminating a regulated permit is a legislative function within the discretion of the city council. A person whose application for a regulated permit is denied, is not considered by the city council on or before the 45th day after the application is submitted with the city secretary, or whose regulated permit is terminated must petition the city council for reconsideration before seeking judicial remedies. 
(Code 1971, § 281/2-23; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 98-87. - Certificated telecommunications provider permit. 
(a)  A certificated telecommunications provider shall be subject to requirements imposed by the city for any person to obtain and maintain a permit to excavate the public ways. The certificated telecommunications provider permittee also shall be subject to any requirements in this article that are not otherwise prohibited under the laws. 
(b)  Consistent with the public ways act, the city may inspect a certificated telecommunications provider permittee's business records to the extent necessary to conduct an authorized review for the purpose of ensuring compliance with all access line reporting requirements, provided that such inspection must commence within 90 days after the filing of the certificated telecommunications provider permittee's access line reports, as required under the public ways act. 
(Code 1971, § 281/2-24) 
Sec. 98-88. - Fees. 
(a)  Wireless telecommunications system permit. Except as provided, it shall be a term and condition of any wireless telecommunications system permit issued in accordance with this division that, as part of the consideration supporting the issuance of such wireless telecommunications system permit and the city's permission thereby to occupy and use its public ways, fees shall be paid as follows: 
(1)  All applicants shall pay the city a wireless telecommunications system permit request fee per cell site that uses the public ways. This fee is on file in the city secretary's office. 
(2)  The wireless telecommunications system permittee shall pay to the city an annual wireless telecommunications system permit fee per cell site that uses the public ways. This fee is on file in the city secretary's office. The city may adjust the annual wireless telecommunications system permit fee each year to the extent allowed under the laws. The minimum adjustment shall be set by the cumulative increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) published by the United States Department of Labor for Urban Wage Earners (1967=100%) since the initial establishment of this wireless telecommunications system permit fee for any and all subsequent increases, and only after a public hearing with at least 20 days' notice to all wireless telecommunications system permittees. 
(3)  The wireless telecommunications system permit fee provided for in subsection (a)(2) of this section shall be payable annually on or before October 1 of each calendar year for the portion of the wireless telecommunications system within the city's public ways on January 1 of that year. A prorated wireless telecommunications system permit fee, based upon the calendar quarter in which the application is filed, shall be paid at the time of the application for a wireless telecommunications system permit for all new portions of the wireless telecommunications system. 
(4)  The wireless telecommunications system permittee shall pay to the city a quarterly wireless revenue fee, which shall be a minimum of five percent, or the maximum percentage allowed under the laws, of all total gross revenues from wireless telecommunications system cell sites that use the public ways. The quarterly wireless revenue fee is due January 1, April 1, July 1, and September 1 of each year. 
(5)  Privately owned lines or cables placed by the wireless telecommunications system permittee to support the backhaul portion of the wireless telecommunications system network constitute a private telecommunications system and are subject to all applicable requirements set forth in this article. 
(b)  Private telecommunications system permit. Except as provided in this article, it shall be a term and condition of any private telecommunications system permit issued in accordance with this article that, as a part of the consideration supporting the issuance of such private telecommunications system permit and the city's permission thereby to occupy and use the public ways, fees shall be paid to the city as follows: 
(1)  All applicants shall pay the city a private telecommunications system permit request fee on file in the city secretary's office. 
(2)  All private telecommunications system permittees shall pay the city an annual private telecommunications system permit fee, on file in the city secretary's office, for the right to operate a private telecommunications system. The city may, at its option, adjust this private telecommunications system permit fee each year to the extent allowed under the laws or by an amount not exceeding the proportional cumulative increase in the CPI since the initial establishment of this private telecommunications system permit fee for any and all subsequent increases, and only after a public hearing and with at least 20 days' notice to all private telecommunications system permittees. 
(3)  The private telecommunications system permit fee provided for in subsection (b)(2) of this section shall be payable to the city annually on or before October 1 of each calendar year for the portion of the private telecommunications system within the public ways on January 1 of that year.
