(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017) 
Sec. 106-755. - Recovery of unpaid fee. 
    Any roadway maintenance fee due hereunder which is not paid when due may be recovered in action at law by the city. In addition to any other remedies or penalties provided by this Ordinance or the Code of Ordinances, City of Nacogdoches, Texas, failure of any utility customer to pay the roadway maintenance fee promptly when due shall subject such utility customer to the discontinuance of utility services provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017) 
Sec. 106-756. - Administration; rules and regulations. 
    The city manager or designee shall be responsible for the administration of this article. The city manager or designee shall be responsible for developing rules, regulations and procedures for the administration of fees and the consideration of petitions for modification and appeals pertaining to the fees charged hereunder; developing maintenance programs; establishing transportation system criteria and standards for the operation and maintenance of the transportation system. 
(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017) 
Sec. 106-757. - Disposition of fees and charges. 
(a)  The roadway maintenance fee shall not be used for the general government proprietary purposes of the city, except to pay for the equitable share of the cost of accounting, management and government thereof. 
(b)  Other than as described above, the roadway maintenance fee shall be used solely to pay for the costs of operation, administration, planning, engineering, development of guidelines and controls, inspection, maintenance, repair, improvement, renewal, replacement and reconstruction of the transportation system and costs incidental thereto. 
(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017) 
Sec. 106-758. - Exemption. 
(a)  The city reserves the right to exempt benefitted properties from provisions of this article through city council action. 
(b)  The following benefitted properties are immediately exempted from the provisions of this article: 
(1)  Benefitted property owned or controlled by the Nacogdoches Independent School District. 
(2)  Benefitted property owned or controlled by Stephen F. Austin State University. 
(3)  Benefitted property owned or controlled by Nacogdoches County. 
(4)  Upon verification of proper governmental status and issuance of written approval by the city manager or city manager's designee, benefitted property owned or controlled by the State of Texas. 
(5)  Upon verification of proper governmental status and issuance of written approval by the city manager or city manager's designee, benefitted property owned or controlled by the Federal Government. 
(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017; Ord. No. 1768-04-18 , § II, 4-17-2018) 
Sec. 106-759. - Appeals. 
(a)  A utility customer may appeal the roadway maintenance fee established herein pursuant to the procedure set forth in this section and as set out in any process developed by the city manager pursuant to section 106-756 herein. 
(b)  An appeal shall be in writing and submitted to the city manager or her/his designee within 14 calendar days after the date of the public utility billing statement containing the matter to be disputed. 
(c)  Appeals may be submitted for the following reasons: 
(1)  The utility customer's exempt property has been assessed a roadway maintenance fee; 
(2)  A roadway maintenance fee for the utility customer's benefitted property is assessed in duplicate on multiple utility accounts; 
(3)  A roadway maintenance fee is assessed to the utility customer's property outside the city limits; 
(4)  A roadway maintenance fee assessed against the utility customer's benefitted property is incorrect due to improper property characterization; or 
(5)  A roadway maintenance fee is assessed for a benefitted property unaffiliated to the utility customer's utility account. 
(d)  The city manager or his designee shall render a written decision on such appeals within a reasonable time after receipt of a timely written notice of appeal from the utility customer. This decision will be final. 
(e)  During all periods of appeal the utility customer shall be responsible for payment of roadway maintenance fee charges in full. 
(f)  A utility customer appealing the roadway maintenance fee may not receive a refund resulting from the appeal except for a road maintenance fee paid within six months of the date of the utility customer's notice of appeal. 
(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017) 
Sec. 106-760. - Determination and amendment of fee. 
    The roadway maintenance fee may be determined and amended by resolution of the city council based upon the costs to provide an efficient, reliable road system within the city limits of the City of Nacogdoches. 
(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017) 
Sec. 106-761. - Liability. 
    This article does not imply that a benefitted property will be free from roadways in need of maintenance and, therefore, does not create additional duties on the part of the city. This chapter does not waive the city's immunity under any law. 
(Ord. No. 1756-12-17 , § III, 12-5-2017) 
Chapter 110 - VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 110-1-110-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION VEHICLES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Charter reference- Authority of city to regulate vehicles for hire, art. II, § 22[13]. 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate vehicles used for carrying passengers for hire, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 215.073. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-26. - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section: 
    Chauffeur's license shall be obtained by each taxicab, limousine or shuttle driver from the chief of police before operation of any taxicab, limousine or shuttle in the city. 
    Chief of police shall refer to the chief of police or his designated officer. 
    Driver shall include every person in actual charge of the operation of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle, whether as owner or agent, servant or employee of the owner. 
    Franchise or license to operate shall mean an authority issued by the city council after a finding that the public convenience and necessity so require it, which may be issued to an owner or owners of taxicab, limousine or shuttle services. The term "franchise" shall apply to an owner or operator of taxicab, limousine or shuttle services which authorizes such owner or operator to engage in the business of transportation by taxicab, limousine or shuttle. The term "license", when used alone, shall apply to the authorization made to the franchise holder, which is a license to operate one or more taxicabs, limousines or shuttles, and although a franchise may be held by an owner and taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator for a designated number of licenses to operate a specified number of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles, an application must be made by the franchise holder for placing more taxicabs, limousines or shuttles within his license to operate. The term "franchise" shall mean the award of a certificate of public convenience and necessity within a franchise is tantamount to an amendment of the franchise by granting additional licenses for additional taxicabs, limousines or shuttles. 
    Limousine shall mean a luxury sedan with a manufacture's rated seating capacity of not more than 15 passengers, used for the transportation of passengers for hire from a location in the city to another location either inside or outside the city, having a driver furnished as part of the service, and which operates on a pre-arranged basis only whereby such pre-arrangement is made not less than one hour in advance of the time transportation is to begin. Expressly excluded from this definition are limousines used exclusively in connection with funeral services and free shuttle services offered by hotels, motels and area attractions. 
    Manifest shall mean a daily record prepared by a taxicab, limousine or shuttle driver of all trips made by said driver showing time and place of origin, designation, number of passengers, driver's name, date, hours of operation, total miles and the amount of fare of each trip. The manifest for taxicab drivers shall also include the taxi number, meter number, paid miles, units, trips and extras. 
    Owner shall mean any person, firm, corporation, association, partnership or society who has the control, direction, maintenance and the benefit of the collection of revenue derived from the operation of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles on or over the streets or public ways of the city, whether as owner or otherwise, except "drivers" as hereinafter defined. 
    Public convenience and necessity shall mean a public convenience which is fitting and suited to public need and a public necessity which embraces a great and urgent public convenience. This term as applied to a proposed service by an applicant shall mean that the applicant is fit, able, and willing to perform transportation by taxicab, limousine or shuttle in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and that public convenience and necessity require the service proposed by such applicant. 
    Taxi stand shall mean and include the taxi depot at which place the taxicabs shall be housed or parked, and at which place the telephone calls and requests for service shall be made, and at which place a dispatcher shall control the movements of the taxicabs to the points of request for such service. This term shall likewise be synonymous with taxi terminal and shall mean and embrace that space and area of land and buildings off of the streets of the city and upon private property, and shall be and constitute the main office of the owner and taxicab operator. 
    Taxicab shall mean every automobile or motor propelled vehicle used for transportation of passengers for hire over the public streets of the city not over a defined or fixed route, and irrespective of whether or not the operations extend beyond the city limits of the city, at rates for distance traveled, or for wait time, or for both, or at rates per hour, per week or per month, which such vehicles is routed to destinations under the direction of such passenger or passengers, or such person or persons hiring the same; provided however, that the term "taxicab" shall not apply to motor buses operated within the city under a franchise from the city over a fixed or definite route, nor shall such term apply to motor buses regularly operated in the city along with fixed routes to and from points outside the incorporated limits of the city, nor shall such term apply to motor vehicles regularly engaged in interstate commerce, nor shall such term apply to limousines or shuttles as defined in this section. 
    Shuttle shall mean a sedan or van with a manufacture's rated seating capacity of not more than 15 passengers, used for the transportation of passengers for hire from a location in the city to another location either inside or outside the city, having a driver furnished as part of the service, and which operates on a pre-arranged basis only whereby such pre-arrangement is made not less than one hour in advance of the time transportation is to begin. Expressly excluded from this definition are shuttles used exclusively in connection with free shuttle services offered by hotels, motels and area attractions. 
    Taximeter shall mean a meter instrument or device attached to a taxicab which measures mechanically/electronically the distance driven and waiting time upon which the fare is based. 
    Taxicab, limousine or shuttle license means the approval under the terms of division 3 of this article of the vehicle to be operated as a taxicab, limousine or shuttle and shall be obtained from the chief of police before operating a taxicab, limousine or shuttle in the city. 
    Waiting time shall mean such time as may be consumed or lost at the special instance and request of a passenger after such passenger has first entered the taxicab to make a trip and before reaching his final destination; and no charge shall be made against a passenger for any other time lost on account of any other delay whatsoever. 
(Code 1971, § 28-1; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1725-12-16 , § 2, 1-17-2017) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 110-27. - Duties of city council generally. 
(a)  To make reasonable orders respecting character, extent, quality and standard of service. 
(b)  To recommend such rates as are not in conflict with the express provisions hereof and to make reasonable orders respecting the same. 
(c)  To prescribe, via original franchise, the number of vehicles to be operated by such grantee, applying thereto the principles of public necessity and convenience. Subsequent requests by grantee for additional vehicles shall be approved by the city manager and are subject to appeal to city council if denied. 
(d)  To require examination and recommend the advisability of the licensing of all drivers or operators of any vehicle operated or maintained by such grantee under the provisions hereof. 
(Code 1971, § 28-6; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1725-12-16 , § 2, 1-17-2017) 
Secs. 110-28-110-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FRANCHISE AND BUSINESS LICENSE AND REGULATIONS[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 18. 

Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 110-56. - Declaration of public convenience and necessity prerequisite for issuance of license. 
    No business license to operate a taxicab, limousine or shuttle and/or franchise shall be issued by the city council, until the city council shall first, after a hearing, declare by certificate that the public convenience and necessity require the proposed service for which application for license or franchise is made; provided, however, that such declaration of public convenience and necessity shall not be necessary in the following instances: 
(1)  For the annual renewal of the same number of licenses in force. 
(2)  For the renewal of licenses to the applicant for the number of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles for which the city council shall have, at any time prior to the application for such renewal, made a declaration of public conveniences and necessity; provided, however, that said taxicabs, limousines or shuttles shall have been duly licensed and operated by such applicant during the previous year for which such renewal is sought. 
(Code 1971, § 28-31; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-57. - Criteria for determination of public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the licensing of taxicab, limousine or shuttle services for which application may be made; the city council shall take into consideration: 
(1)  Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require such proposed taxicab, limousine or shuttle service within the city. 
(2)  Kind and type of equipment or vehicles and color scheme to be used by the applicant. 
(3)  Increased traffic congestion on the streets of the city which may result from licensing taxicabs, limousines or shuttles. 
(4)  Whether the safe use of the streets of the city by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be unduly endangered by the granting of such license. 
(5)  Whether the applicant is fit, able and willing to perform transportation by taxicab, limousine or shuttle. 
(6)  Other relevant facts as the city council may deem advisable or necessary, which may throw light on public necessity and convenience. 
(b)  No application will be granted and no finding shall be made of public convenience and necessity unless and until there is a finding that such applicant is fit, able and willing to perform transportation by taxicab, limousine or shuttle as provided by this chapter and that there is public demand and need for the type of service proposed. 
(c)  A refusal on the part of the holders of franchises to meet public convenience and necessity shall constitute just cause for a finding of additional need of public convenience and necessity and thereby authorize the city council to issue additional franchises and additional certificates of public convenience and necessity, over and above those granted pursuant to the terms of this chapter. 
(Code 1971, § 28-32; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1725-12-16 , § 2, 1-17-2017) 
Sec. 110-58. - Notice to holders of certificates. 
    When an application is filed purporting to reflect fitness, willingness and ability, as well as a need for transportation service by taxicabs, limousines or shuttles in the city, the city secretary shall provide copies to the holders of certificates of public convenience and necessity, being the franchised taxicab, limousine or shuttle operators in the city, giving and granting to the franchised operators of such services an opportunity to reply both on the question of convenience and necessity, prior to and at the hearing to be held by the city council, as provided for in section 110-60. 
(Code 1971, § 28-33; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-59. - Notice of application and hearing. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a taxicab, limousine or shuttle franchise, the city secretary shall cause a notice to be published in the daily newspaper of the city, and the cost of publishing shall be advanced in full by the applicant. Said notice shall set out the facts that an application has been filed for a taxicab, limousine or shuttle service, the name of the applicant, the kind of equipment, and all other pertinent data from such application which the city secretary may deem necessary. Such publication shall constitute a notice to all holders of existing taxicab, limousine or shuttle licenses and to the public that a public hearing will be held by the city council at a public place in the city, and at a designated time given in such notice, which designated time shall not be less than five days nor more than 15 days after the date of the publication of such notice. 
(Code 1971, § 28-34; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-60. - Hearing on application. 
    All holders of existing taxicab, limousine or shuttle franchises or any other citizens shall be entitled to file any complaints or protests that such party may have to the issuance of any taxicab, limousine or shuttle franchise. At the time of the holding of the investigation and hearing, with reference to whether public convenience and necessity require operation of such vehicle or vehicles covered in the application for a taxicab, limousine or shuttle franchise, city council shall consider all complaints and protests and in conducting the hearing shall have the right to call such witnesses as they see fit. In all such hearings, the burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish by clear, cogent and convincing evidence that the public convenience and necessity require such operation of the vehicle or vehicles for which such application has been made and that the applicant is fit, able and willing to perform such transportation of persons and property by taxicab, limousine or shuttle as proposed in such application. 
(Code 1971, § 28-35; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009; Ord. No. 1725-12-16 , § 2, 1-17-2017) 
Sec. 110-61. - Notice to applicants. 
(a)  If the city council finds from the investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity justify the operation of the vehicles for which a taxicab, limousine or shuttle license is desired, they shall notify the applicant thereof of their findings. Within five days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish to the chief of police any and all relevant information which may be required. 
(b)  If the city council finds from such investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity do not justify the operation of the vehicle or vehicles for which a taxicab, limousine or shuttle license is desired, they shall forthwith notify the applicant of their finding. 
(Code 1971, § 28-36; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-62. - Issuance of certificate. 
    If the city council finds that there is a need of transportation by taxicabs, limousines or shuttles that is not being furnished by the franchised operators of such services and the insurance policy required by this article has been filed and deposited with the chief of police and that such vehicle or vehicles comply with and the applicant has complied with all relevant provisions of this Code and relevant ordinances of the city and all of the rules and regulations established by the chief of police to more effectively carry out the purpose and intent of this chapter and such ordinances, they shall issue a written certificate to the city secretary, not more than ten days after their findings have been declared, certifying that the public convenience and necessity require the operation of such taxicab(s), limousine(s) or shuttle(s) or any less number thereof which the applicant desires and proposes to operate, and that the applicant is entitled to have such vehicle or vehicles licensed as taxicabs, limousines or shuttles and franchises to operate taxicabs, limousines or shuttles upon complying with all or other provisions of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 28-37; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-63. - Sale, transfer of certificate. 
    No certificate of public convenience and necessity for a taxicab, limousine or shuttle franchise may be sold and transferred without the written approval of the city expressed by a resolution. No resolution shall be drafted approving the sale and transfer of a certificate of public convenience and necessity for a taxicab, limousine or shuttle franchise without a hearing first held before the city council, followed by a finding of the city council that the person proposing to purchase such franchise is fit, able and willing to carry on the transportation of persons by taxicab, limousine or shuttle in accordance with the terms and provisions of this chapter. In the event that the person seeking to purchase a franchise is a person holding a franchise and a certificate of public convenience and necessity, and being a then licensed operator of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles in the city, then and in that event, the applicant asking authority to purchase shall be deemed to have introduced a prima facie case of fitness, willingness and ability. 
(Code 1971, § 28-38; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-64-110-90. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Franchise 

Sec. 110-91. - Required. 
    No person shall be permitted to engage in the transportation of persons for hire in the operation of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles in the city unless a franchise to permit such operation of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles is first obtained from the city council. 
(Code 1971, § 28-39; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-92. - Applications. 
    It shall be the duty of the city secretary to receive all applications for franchises to operate taxicab, limousine or shuttle services. 
(Code 1971, § 28-40; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-93. - Liability and casualty insurance. 
(a)  No franchise shall be issued under this article, nor shall such franchise be valid after issuance, nor shall any transportation service be operated unless there is at all times in force and effect insurance meeting the requirements of Texas law for automobile liability insurance, providing for payment of damages to property, injury to or death of individuals in accidents resulting from any cause for which the operator and/or vehicle driver would be liable on account of liability imposed by law, regardless of whether the vehicle was being driven by the operator or driver. 
(b)  The maximum amount of recovery in a policy of insurance required by this article shall not be less than the state minimum. 
(c)  Every insurance policy or contract of insurance required under this section shall contain a provision that the liability of the insurer shall not be affected by the insolvency or bankruptcy of the insured, and every such policy shall contain a provision making the city an additional insured under such policy or contract of insurance. 
(d)  Every insurance policy or contract of insurance required under this section shall contain a provision for the insurer to give not less than 30 days' written notice to the city and to the named insured before any cancellation or termination of any such policy or contract of insurance shall automatically revoke and terminate the permit unless another insurance policy complying with the provisions of this section shall be provided and be in effect at the time of such cancellation or termination. 
(e)  A certificate of insurance showing compliance with insurance required under this section shall be filed with the chief of police, and no permit granted under this section shall be valid unless and until such certificate shall have been so tendered. Such certificate shall be replaced when it expires. 
(f)  Any operator shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from and against all liability arising out of the operator's permitted activities hereunder. 
(g)  All policies or contracts of insurance shall be approved by the city and shall be issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the State of Texas. 
(Code 1971, § 28-41; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-94. - Street rental charge. 
    An annual street rental charge is hereby levied upon the owner and operator of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles operating within the city limits in the sum of $25.00 per taxicab, limousine or shuttle for which the franchise is granted or held. The holder of a franchise or the operator of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle shall be required to pay to the city at the office of the city secretary, in lawful money of the United States, such amount or amounts, which remittance shall be made annually on or before the first day of each February, for the preceding calendar year. 
(Code 1971, § 28-42; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-95. - Duration. 
    Any franchise granted to operators of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles shall continue for a period of five years, unless sooner revoked by the city council. 
(Code 1971, § 28-43; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-96. - Organization of business. 
    In the performance of his duties and privilege under this chapter, the grantee of a franchise may provide for the conduct of such taxicab, limousine or shuttle service by operating the same through divisions, or units, under trade names or trademarks, or through operating companies, provided each such operation shall first be approved by the city council by resolution duly adopted, and provided no such operation shall diminish the obligation of the revenue accruing to the city under this grant. 
(Code 1971, § 28-44; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-97. - Assignment, subletting. 
    No person granted a franchise shall assign or sublet his franchise. 
(Code 1971, § 28-45; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-98. - Payment of taxes, levies, etc. 
    Any grantee of a franchise shall promptly pay all lawful ad valorem taxes, and such other levies and assessments, if any, that may be lawfully imposed upon it. 
(Code 1971, § 28-46; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-99. - Amendments. 
    The city expressly reserves the right to modify, amend, alter, change or eliminate any of the provisions of the franchise, during the life of the same, for the following purposes: 
(1)  To eliminate or delete from the same such conditions as then prove obsolete or impractical. 
(2)  To impose such additional conditions upon the grantee as may be just and reasonable, such conditions to be those as may be deemed necessary for the purpose of insuring adequate service to the public. 
(Code 1971, § 28-47; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-100. - Suspension or termination of franchise/business license. 
    The franchise and business license granted under this division shall be subject to suspension and/or termination for: 
(1)  Neglect, failure or refusal of such owner or taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator to comply with the terms of such franchise of this division. 
(2)  Failure of a taxicab franchise owner to operate taxicab(s) at least five days per week. This requirement does not apply to limousine or shuttle operations. 
    In the event of complaint or upon its own motion the city council may set a public hearing, giving the owner or taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator at least seven days' notice of the hearing and the given nature of the complaint or concern. 
    Should the owner or taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator be found at such hearing to have violated the term of this article or its franchise or business license, the city council may, by written notice to the owner or taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator, suspend for a period of time or revoke the rights of the owner or taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator under such franchise or business license or admonish such owner or taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator. 
    Notice shall be effective when sent certified mail return receipt required, properly addressed and postage paid to the recipient. Notice of the decision of the city council upon the hearing shall be sent within five business days of such hearing. Appeal of such suspension, revocation or admonition shall be to the State District Court of Nacogdoches County, Texas. 
(Code 1971, § 28-48; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-101-110-125. - Reserved. 
Subdivision III. - Vehicle License 

Sec. 110-126. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any taxicab, limousine or shuttle within the city limits unless there has been obtained by the owner of such taxicab, limousine or shuttle a vehicle license issued by the chief of police. 
(Code 1971, § 28-54; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-127. - Application. 
    Any applicant, except those provided in subsections 110-56(1) and (2), for a taxicab, limousine or shuttle vehicle license shall make proper application therefore on blanks to be furnished by the chief of police. 
(Code 1971, § 28-55; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-128. - Inspections. 
    Before any taxicab, limousine or shuttle vehicle license is issued by the city, such taxicab, limousine or shuttle shall be inspected by the chief of police to determine that it: 
(1)  Displays a current state vehicle inspection sticker, and 
(2)  Is clean, and 
(3)  That all equipment workings and the like required by this article, the franchise or the operator of such taxicab, limousine or shuttle, and state or federal law is present and in operating condition. 
(Code 1971, § 28-56; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-129. - Inspection fees. 
    An inspection fee of $25.00 shall be charged for the inspection of each vehicle. The payment shall be due at the time of the vehicle inspection. 
(Code 1971, § 28-57; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-130. - Revocation or suspension. 
    Upon complaint filed by any person with the chief of police, or upon his own motion, the chief of police, after five days' notice of the grounds of such complaint to the owner or operator of any taxicab, limousine or shuttle against whom a complaint is made, may hear evidence with reference to such complaint and after such hearing, the chief of police may revoke or suspend the vehicle license of such owner or operator of any particular taxicab, limousine or shuttle service for good cause shown. 
(Code 1971, § 28-58; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-131. - Appeals from revocation or suspension. 
    After the chief of police has heard the complaint for the revocation or suspension of the taxicab, limousine or shuttle vehicle license of any owner or operator of such vehicle, he shall make his findings and declare the same and either the owner or operator of such taxicab, limousine or shuttle or the complainant shall have the right to appeal to the city council within ten days and such appeal shall be perfected by a letter delivered to the city manager, stating that an appeal from the ruling of the chief of police is desired to the city council as a whole. If an appeal from the decision of the chief of police is perfected as above provided, the decision shall be suspended until passed upon by the city council. Upon receiving such appeal, the city council, as soon as practicable thereafter, shall hear such appeal and shall either sustain, modify or reverse the decision of the chief of police. If no appeal is taken from the ruling of the chief of police in the time as provided above, the ruling of the chief of police shall be final. 
(Code 1971, § 28-59; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-132-110-155. - Reserved. 
Subdivision IV. - Regulations 

Sec. 110-156. - Chief of police to recommend regulations to council. 
    The chief of police shall recommend to the city council reasonable rules and regulations as may be reasonably necessary to facilitate the service to be rendered to the public under a franchise, which when approved by the city council by appropriate measures, shall become binding upon the grantee of a franchise. 
(Code 1971, § 28-7; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-157. - Delinquent ad valorem taxes. 
    No operator of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles shall engage in the transportation of persons by taxicab, limousine or shuttle at any time when the ad valorem taxes assessed against such taxi stand, taxicab, limousine, shuttle or such equipment shall be delinquent. 
(Code 1971, § 28-21; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-158. - Persons authorized to operate taxicabs, limousines or shuttles. 
    It shall be unlawful for any taxicab, limousine or shuttle to be driven or operated within the city by a person except the owner of such taxicab, limousine or shuttle, or the authorized agent or employee of the owner. 
(Code 1971, § 28-2; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-159. - Operators to comply with traffic laws. 
    All automobiles or vehicles used in connection with a taxicab, limousine or shuttle service shall be operated in accordance with the laws of the State of Texas, this Code and other ordinances of the city, and such future amendments thereof, relating to or regulating the operation of motor vehicles upon streets or highways. 
(Code 1971, § 28-3; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-160. - Owner, operator responsible for negligence of driver. 
    The owner or operator is responsible for the acts of negligence of any driver of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle who shall drive such taxicab, limousine or shuttle with the knowledge or with the consent of such owner or operator. 
(Code 1971, § 28-4; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-161. - City officers, employees not to accept favors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any officer or employee of the city to accept directly or indirectly any gifts, discounts or gratuities from any holder of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle permit or driver of any taxicab, limousine or shuttle or from any person engaged in the repair of taxicabs, limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-5; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-162. - Taxi stands. 
(a)  Taxi franchise owners with five or fewer taxicabs operating in the city limits are not required to maintain an off-street taxi stand or terminal. If operated as a home occupation, the franchise shall not be operated in such a way as to violate the terms of a home occupation, as defined in section 118-1 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(b)  Taxi franchise owners with more than five taxicabs operating inside the city limits shall maintain within the city limits an off-street taxi stand or terminal of sufficient size to accommodate all of the franchise owner's taxicabs. The franchise owner shall have such taxi stand open to the general public from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Monday through Friday, and shall be available via telephone 24 hours per day. 
(c)  The location and type of building must be in compliance with zoning regulations. The form and type of taxi stand shall be of such a nature as best meets public convenience and necessity and affords a safe, sanitary and lawful operation of transportation by taxicabs. The site, location and type of proposed buildings and the sanitary conditions of the taxi stand shall be reflected in an application to the chief of police. The equipment, site and place of a taxi stand must be found by the chief of police to best meet public convenience and necessity prior to an authorization to a franchise holder to operate such taxi stand. 
(Code 1971, § 28-8; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1725-12-16 , § 2, 1-17-2017) 
Sec. 110-163. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 1725-12-16 , § 2, adopted Jan. 17, 2017, repealed § 110-163 in its entirety. Former § 110-163 pertained to subtaxistands and derived from the Code of 1971, § 28-9; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, adopted Sept. 4, 2004. 
Sec. 110-164. - Receipt and discharge of passengers. 
    No driver of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle shall receive or discharge passengers in the roadway of any street, but shall drive to the right-hand sidewalk, to the extreme right-hand side of the road, and there receive or discharge passengers; provided however, that this section shall not be construed to prohibit such vehicles from so discharging or receiving passengers on the left-hand side of the street or sidewalk where left-hand parking is permitted within the city. 
(Code 1971, § 28-10; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-165. - Transporting undesirables; procuring. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle to knowingly transport any passenger to the abode of a commercialized prostitute or to knowingly transport any known criminal, narcotic peddler, prostitute or bootlegger in the commission of a crime or the infraction of the law in any manner or to act as a contact man for unlawful establishments of any character. 
(Code 1971, § 28-11; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-166. - Disposition of property left in vehicle. 
    It shall be the duty of every taxicab, limousine or shuttle driver to immediately return to the owner, if known, any luggage, merchandise or other property left in his taxicab, limousine or vehicle. If the owner is not know, said driver shall, immediately upon return to his terminal, turn over to the operator of the terminal any property left in his vehicle with a complete report of when it was left in his vehicle. Such articles shall be tagged and if not called for within 72 hours shall be turned over to the chief of police with all available information as to the probable owner. If such articles remain unclaimed, the chief of police shall dispose of such property in accordance with applicable city ordinances and state law. 
(Code 1971, § 28-12; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-167. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It shall be unlawful to transport alcoholic beverages, not owned and in the exclusive possession and control of a fare paying passenger, in the taxicab, limousine or shuttle or for any taxicab, limousine or shuttle driver to have on his person any alcoholic beverage while driving and operating a taxicab, limousine or shuttle. 
(Code 1971, § 28-13; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-168. - Smoking prohibited in taxicabs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any driver or passenger of any taxicab to smoke tobacco products of any kind while the taxicab is occupied. The owner of every taxicab will post in a prominent location in the taxicab, visible to every occupant, a "No Smoking" sign composed of letters of no less than one inch in height. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-14; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-169. - Maximum seating. 
    It shall be unlawful to carry more passengers than any vehicle is equipped to transport. The number of passengers permitted in a taxicab, limousine or shuttle shall be determined by the vehicle make and design. 
(Code 1971, § 28-15; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-170. - Taxicab required to have lighted dome sign on top of same. 
    All taxicabs in the city shall have a lighted dome sign on top thereof just above the windshield, which sign shall have the word "TAXI" thereon. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-16; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-171. - Rates. 
(a)  The rate of fare for one passenger shall be $2.00 for the first .10 mile and $0.175) for each .10 mile or fraction thereof traveled thereafter. The rate for additional passengers shall be $1.00 per passenger, not to exceed the vehicle's maximum seating capacity, with a minimum trip fare of $4.50. 
(b)  For each one minute of waiting time consumed by the taxicab at the instance of the passenger, the rate shall be $0.25. 
(c)  Whenever a taxicab is engaged on an hourly basis, whether for one or more passengers, the rate of fare shall be $25.00 for each hour. For each quarter hour in excess of each completed hour, the rate shall be $6.25 for each quarter hour the taxicab is so engaged. 
(d)  This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-17; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-172. - Display of rates. 
    A card showing the rates charged by a taxicab shall be displayed in a conspicuous place on the inside of each taxicab and on the back of the front seat at all times. 
    This section will not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-18; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-173. - Receipt for fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for the driver of any taxicab upon receiving full payment of a fare to refuse to give a receipt therefore upon request of any passenger making said payment. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-19; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-174. - Refusal to pay fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the legal fare of any taxicab after having hired the same or to hire any taxicab with the intent to defraud the person from whom it is hired. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-20; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-175. - Complaints. 
    All taxicabs, limousines or shuttle franchises operated in the City of Nacogdoches will post in a prominent location in the vehicle, visible to every occupant, a sign composed of letters of no less than one inch in height stating "All complaints regarding the operation of this vehicle shall be directed to the Nacogdoches Police Department." 
(Ord. No. 1371-9-04, § 28-15.1, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-176. - Maximum year model and mileage limit for vehicles. 
    No inspection permit shall be issued for any vehicle older than eight years or with mileage exceeding 300,000 miles. 
(Ord. No. 1371-9-04, § 28-17.1, 9-7-2004) 
Secs. 110-177-110-200. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DRIVERS 
Subdivision I. - In General 

Sec. 110-201. - Qualifications. 
(a)  Every person operating a taxicab, limousine or shuttle business or service in the city shall employ as a driver only persons who are physically and mentally fit and able to operate a motor vehicle for hire, and it shall be the duty of the owner of the taxicab, limousine or shuttle service or business, as well as the driver, to furnish to the chief of police a physician's certificate stating that the driver, who seeks a chauffeur's license to operate a taxicab, limousine or shuttle is physically and mentally fit to operate such taxicab, limousine or shuttle. 
(b)  Every person who driver a taxicab, limousine or shuttle shall be covered either personally or through the franchise owner or operator with automobile liability insurance meeting the minimum requirements of Texas law. 
(c)  It shall be the full responsibility of the taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator to select and employ drivers who are qualified for taxicab, limousine or shuttle service, who can read and write the English language, and who are familiar with the streets and addresses in the city. 
(d)  Every operator of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle business or service is charged with a knowledge of the police and court records of all drivers in his employ and no such operator shall employ or retain in his employ any person, as a taxicab, limousine or shuttle driver, who frequently violates laws governing motor vehicle operations or violates law which directly relate to the occupation of the taxicab, limousine or shuttle driver. 
(Code 1971, § 28-73; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-202. - State license required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a taxicab, limousine or shuttle within the city unless he is duly licensed by the State of Texas for the transportation of passengers, having on his person at all times while operating a taxicab, limousine or shuttle, an appropriate and valid Texas driver's license. 
(Code 1971, § 28-74; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-203. - Maximum hours in day driver may operate. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or operator of any taxicab, limousine or shuttle licensed under this article to permit any driver to operate such taxicab, limousine or shuttle for more than 12 hours within a 24-hour period. 
(Code 1971, § 28-75; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-204. - Driver's daily manifest. 
(a)  Each person or company operating a taxicab, limousine or shuttle business shall provide its drivers with forms for maintaining a daily manifest. The form must include appropriate spaces for recording: 
(1)  Taxi number, driver's name, date, hours of operation, meter number, total miles, paid miles, units, trips and extras; 
(2)  Time, place, origin and destination of each trip; 
(3)  Number of passengers and amount of fare and other charges; and, 
(4)  Other information required by the city council to facilitate the implementation of this article. 
(b)  Each driver shall complete a manifest on a separate form for each tour of duty. The driver shall provide the information required by the form and shall record the information with regard to trips at the end of each trip. The driver shall return completed manifest forms to the owner of the taxicab, limousine or shuttle business upon completion of each tour of duty. 
(c)  The owner or operator of every taxicab, limousine or shuttle business will keep such daily manifest forms in a permanent and orderly fashion and make such records available to the city council or designated city officials at their request, and keep such forms for five years. 
(d)  Limousine and shuttle drivers shall be exempt from having to meeting requirements of subsection (a)(1) of this section. 
(Code 1971, § 28-76; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-205-110-230. - Reserved. 
Subdivision II. - Chauffeur's License 

Sec. 110-231. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any taxicab, limousine or shuttle within the city limits without having first obtained from the chief of police a "City of Nacogdoches chauffeur's license". 
(Code 1971, § 28-77; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-232. - Application. 
    To obtain a chauffeur's license, each person shall make a written application therefore to the chief of police, upon the form provided therefore by the city, which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The full name, age and specific address of the applicant. 
(2)  The full name of the person or owner for whom the applicant proposes to be employed. 
(3)  The length of local residence of the applicant in the city, county, state and the United States and whether or not he/she is a citizen of the United States. 
(4)  Proof of liability insurance either through he applicant or the taxicab, limousine or shuttle operator shall be attached to the application. 
(5)  The experience that applicant has had in rendering such service. 
(6)  Whether applicant has been convicted of a felony, and full information concerning same; likewise, if applicant has a police record with any conviction of a misdemeanor and full information concerning the same. 
(7)  Whether applicant has been convicted of a violation of the law in the operation of motor vehicles, and if so, full information concerning the same. 
(8)  A true photocopy of the front and back of the state driver's license issued to the applicant. 
(9)  Two color passport size photos shall be attached to the application. 
(Code 1971, § 28-78; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-233. - Investigation of applicant. 
    The chief of police shall make or cause to make such investigations of the character, criminal history (only to the extent allowed by law), experience and qualifications of the applicant for a chauffeur's license as may be deemed consistent, judicious and allowed by law. 
(Code 1971, § 28-79; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-234. - Determination of applicant's fitness, appeals. 
(a)  Based on the application and his investigation, and within 30 days of receipt of the complete application and all driver's license and criminal history information required by the chief of police, the chief of police shall determine whether or not any applicant for a chauffeur's license is fit and proper to drive and operate a taxicab, limousine or shuttle within the corporate limits of the city in a manner consistent with the welfare of the citizenry. Falsification, material omission or material misrepresentation of or on the application shall be nonexclusive grounds for denial of such application. 
(b)  If the chief of police has made his decision as to whether or not the applicant for a chauffeur's license is fit and proper to drive a taxicab, limousine or shuttle, and declared same, either the applicant for such license or any citizen of the city, shall have the right to appeal to the city council within ten days, which appeal shall be perfected by delivering in writing five copies of same to the city council, stating that an appeal from the decision of the chief of police is desired. The city council shall, within a period of not more than 15 days after receiving such notice of appeal, grant a hearing thereon, and after the hearing of such appeal shall, within a period of five days, sustain or reverse the decision of the chief of police. If no appeal is taken from the findings made by the chief of police within the time provided above, the decision of the chief of police shall be final; otherwise the decision of the chief of police shall be final. 
(Code 1971, § 28-80; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-235. - Fee. 
    A fee of $10.00 shall be charged for each chauffeur's license issued by the city. No chauffeur's license shall be issued until said fee is paid. 
(Code 1971, § 28-81; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-236. - Issuance. 
    After the applicant for a chauffeur's license has complied with all requirements of the relevant provisions of this article and the approval of the chief of police, a chauffeur's license shall be issued to him. 
(Code 1971, § 28-82; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-237. - Expiration. 
    Any chauffeur's license issued by the city shall expire one year from the date of issuance. 
(Code 1971, § 28-83; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-238. - Renewal. 
    A license under the provisions of this division may be renewed annually without filing a new application by payment of a $5.00 license fee. Renewal may be refused for any reason the original application could have been rejected. 
(Code 1971, § 28-84; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-239. - Nontransferable. 
    Any chauffeur's license that is issued by the city shall not be transferable. 
(Code 1971, § 28-85; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-240. - Identification card. 
(a)  Issuance. Each applicant for a chauffeur's license shall, at the time of the actual issuance of said license, be issued an identification card. 
(b)  Contents. The identification card shall be postcard size, and shall contain the full description, residence address and fingerprints of the applicant. 
(c)  Possession. The identification card shall be carried on the person of the applicant and presented for identification purposes on demand of any passenger or police officer. 
(Code 1971, § 28-86; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-241. - Suspension, appeals. 
    The chief of police, upon making any of the findings justifying a revocation of a chauffeur's license, may temporarily suspend such chauffeur's license. Upon such suspension, the holder of such chauffeur's license shall have the right to appeal to the city council as provided in section 110-131. 
(Code 1971, § 28-87; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-242. - Revocation. 
    Any chauffeur's license may be revoked by the chief of police after a hearing is first held by the chief of police resulting in finding that the driver of the taxicab, limousine or shuttle was guilty of any of the following: 
(1)  Making any false statement or material omission or material misrepresentation in his application for a chauffeur's license. 
(2)  Knowingly engaging in the sale of intoxicating liquors, directly or indirectly. 
(3)  Knowingly engaging in the transportation of any known criminal, narcotic peddler, prostitute, or bootlegger, in the commission of a crime, or in the infraction of the law in any manner. 
(4)  Acting in any manner as a contact man for bootlegging or a contact man for any unlawful establishments of any character. 
(5)  Conviction of a felony or misdemeanor if the crime directly relates to the duties and responsibilities of a taxicab, limousine or shuttle driver as determined under the guidelines adopted by the city for such analysis. 
(Code 1971, § 28-88; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-243. - Appeal of revocation. 
    Upon revocation of any chauffeur's license by the chief of police, the holder of such chauffeur's license shall have the right to appeal such revocation to the city council as provided for in section 110-131. 
(Code 1971, § 28-89; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-244-110-270. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - TAXIMETERS 

Sec. 110-271. - Required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any taxicab to be operated or advertised for public hire in the city unless it is equipped with a taximeter, which taximeter shall be used as provided in this section. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, operating, driving or in charge of any taxicab for hire in the city to drive or operate such taxicab, or to use or advertise in connection therewith the word taxi, taxicab or cab, or in soliciting trade from the public, to represent or exhibit such vehicle as a taxi, taxicab or cab, unless each vehicle be equipped with a taximeter. 
(c)  The taximeter requirements stated herein shall not be applicable to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-23; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-272. - Use in determining fare. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning, operating, driving or in charge of a taxicab to operate or drive such taxicab unless a taximeter is used in determining the fare to be charged, and no other or different fare shall be charged than the fare recorded on the reading face of such taximeter for such trip and no other rates or methods of measuring the distance or time charges shall be allowed except as expressly permitted by this division. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-24; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-273. - Size, design, specifications. 
    Every taxicab shall use a taximeter which shall conform to the following specifications. 
(1)  The taximeter shall be a mechanical/electric instrument or device by which the charge for hire of a taxicab is mechanically/electronically calculated for the distance traveled, for waiting time, if any, and extra passengers, if any, and upon which such charge or charges shall be indicated by means of clearly legible figures which are electrically lighted each time the taximeter flag is thrown from nonearning to earning position. 
(2)  Every taximeter must register upon visual counters the following items: 
a.  Total miles (unless shown by accurate registration on the speedometer tested in good working order on the taxicab). 
b.  Paid miles. 
c.  Number of trips. 
(3)  Each taximeter must be driven from the taxicab transmission to the taximeter head. 
(4)  No taximeter shall be in such condition as to be more than five percent incorrect to the prejudice of any passenger. 
This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-25; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-274. - Case to be sealed; cover and gear intact. 
    No person shall use or permit to be used or driven for hire a taxicab equipped with a taximeter the case of which is unsealed and not having its cover and gear in tact. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-26; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-275. - Tests and inspections generally. 
    All taximeters used in the city shall be kept in good repair and functioning accurately. The city may require each taximeter tested for accuracy by the appropriate responsible state agency and/or by any private company capable of performing such test. Proof of accuracy from such test shall be submitted to the chief of police. The actual cost of the test shall be borne by the owner or operator of the taxicab. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-27; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-276. - Changing flag to vacant position. 
    It shall be the duty of the driver to call to the attention of passengers to the amount registered on the taximeter, and the taximeter flag shall not be changed to vacant position until after the fare is paid. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-28; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-277. - Unauthorized display of signal. 
    No driver of a taxicab equipped with a taximeter, while carrying a passenger or passengers, or while under employment, shall display the signal affixed to such taximeter in such position as to denote the vehicle is not employed, or in such position as to denote that the taxicab is employed at a rate of or different from that which the use of the taxicab legally justified under the provisions of this division. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-29; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Sec. 110-278. - Multiple passengers. 
    The first passenger employing a taxicab shall be entitled to its exclusive use until delivered to his destination by the most practical direct route and no other passenger may be carried unless the passenger or passengers first engaged the taxicab shall consent to additional passengers not with him or her party. 
    This section shall not apply to limousines or shuttles. 
(Code 1971, § 28-30; Ord. No. 1371-9-04, 9-7-2004) 
Secs. 110-279-110-305. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - HORSE-DRAWN CARRIAGES[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Animals, ch. 6. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 110-306. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carriage means a wheeled passenger vehicle pulled by a horse. 
    Carriage horse means any horse or any animal in the horse family which is used by its owner in exchange for a fee. A horse rented or leased by its owner to another for any of the purposes set forth in this article shall be deemed to be a carriage horse for the purpose of this article. 
    Chief of police means the administrative head of the police department or his designee. 
    Code enforcement officer means the representative of the city whose primary duty is to enforce various codes related to property appearance and various nuisances. 
    Franchise or license to operate means an authority issued by the city council after a finding that the public convenience and necessity so require it, which may be issued to an owner of a horse-drawn carriage service. The term "franchise" shall apply to an owner or operator of a horse-drawn carriage service, which authorizes the owner or operator to engage in the business of transportation by horse-drawn carriage. 
    Holder means a person who is granted a permit under this article. 
    Horse-drawn carriage driver means any individual duly licensed as a driver by the state as required by this article and who operates or has been duly employed to operate a horse-drawn carriage by the holder of a horse-drawn carriage permit. 
    Horse-drawn carriage service means a service offered to a passenger as transportation under this article. 
    Operating authority means a permit issued under the provisions of this article. 
    Passenger means an individual, other than the driver, being transported by horse-drawn carriage. 
    Permit means permission granted by the city to operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire within the city for a period of 12 months and renewable under the provisions of this article; provided, however, that the permission granted is neither expired nor revoked. 
    Person means an individual, partnership, corporation, company, association, or a joint stock association owning, driving, controlling, or operating any horse-drawn carriage as defined and regulated by this article. 
    Public convenience and necessity means a public convenience, which is fitting and suited to public need, and a public necessity, which embraces a great and urgent public convenience. This term as applied to a proposed service by an applicant shall mean that the applicant is fit, able, and willing to perform transportation by horse-drawn carriage in accordance with the requirements of this article and that public convenience and necessity require the service proposed by such applicant. 
    Street means and includes any street, alley, avenue, boulevard, drive, public way, or highway commonly used for the purpose of public travel within the corporated limits of the city. 
    Work, as applied to a horse and carriage means the horse is out of its stable and presented to the public as being available for pulling a carriage. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-90, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 110-307. - Violation. 
    It shall be unlawful for a person to knowingly do or perform any act prohibited in this article and it shall be unlawful for a person to knowingly fail to do or perform any act required in this article. Upon conviction of any violation of this article a person shall be subject to punishment as provided by this article. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-91, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-308. - Correction notices. 
(a)  Any officer of the city with power to enforce this article may, when in his judgment and for health and safety reasons, it becomes necessary to protect the passengers, the general public or the horse: 
(1)  Remove a horse from a public street until such time as the horse is reexamined by a veterinarian of this state and the permit holder obtains a certificate from that veterinarian stating the horse has been personally examined by him and such horse is fit to return to work in the horse-drawn carriage business. 
(2)  Remove a carriage from the street when it is not in compliance with the provisions of this article. The carriage shall not be allowed to operate on public streets until a reinspection is performed and the chief of police or his designee certifies it to be in compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(b)  When a horse or carriage is removed from service, an officer with the power to enforce this article shall issue a correction notice to the driver or permit holder. Such notice shall state the specific reason for action taken and that the carriage or horse shall not be allowed to operate until a reinspection is conducted and the carriage or horse is certified to be in compliance. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-158, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-309. - Citations; penalties. 
(a)  All police officers and/or code enforcement officers of the city have the authority and are charged with the responsibility enforcing the provisions of this article. Any police officer of the city may issue a citation for the violation of any provision of this article. 
(b)  The violation of a provision, rule, or regulation under the provisions of this article shall be a class C misdemeanor. Each offense is punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 but not less than $25.00. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-159, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-310. - Declaration of public convenience and necessity prerequisite for issuance. 
    No business license to operate a horse-drawn carriage and/or franchise shall be issued by the city council, until the city council shall first, after a hearing, declare by certificate that the public convenience and necessity require the proposed service for which application for a license or franchise is made. Such declaration of public convenience and necessity shall not be necessary in the following instances: 
(1)  For the annual renewal of the same number of licenses in force. 
(2)  For the renewal of licenses to the applicant for the number of horse-drawn carriages for which the city council shall have, at any time prior to the application for such renewal, made a declaration of public conveniences and necessity; provided, however, that the horse-drawn carriages shall have been duly licensed and operated by such applicant during the year previous to the year for which such renewal is sought. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-95, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-311. - Criteria for determination of public convenience and necessity. 
(a)  In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the licensing of horse-drawn carriage services for which application may be made, the city council shall take into consideration: 
(1)  Whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require such proposed or such additional horse-drawn carriage service within the city. 
(2)  The financial responsibility of the applicant. 
(3)  The number, kind, and type of equipment to be used by the applicant. 
(4)  The increased traffic congestion on the streets of the city which may result from the licensing of additional horse-drawn carriages. 
(5)  Whether the safe use of the streets of the city by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be unduly endangered by the granting of such additional license. 
(6)  Whether the applicant is fit, able, and willing to perform transportation by horse-drawn carriage. 
(7)  Other relevant facts as the city council may deem advisable or necessary which may throw light on public necessity and convenience. 
(b)  No application will be granted and no finding shall be made of public convenience and necessity unless and until there is a finding that such applicant is fit, able, and willing to perform transportation by horse-drawn carriage as provided by this article and that there is public demand and need for the type of service proposed. 
(c)  A refusal on the part of the holders of franchises to meet public convenience and necessity shall constitute just cause for a finding of additional need of public convenience and necessity and thereby authorize the city council to issue additional franchises and additional certificates of public convenience and necessity, over and above those granted pursuant to the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-96, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-312. - Notice to holders of certificates. 
    When an application is filed purporting to reflect the applicant's fitness, willingness, and ability, as well as a need for transportation service by horse-drawn carriage in the city, the person making such application must make additional copies thereof and serve such copies upon the holders of certificates of public convenience and necessity, being the franchised horse-drawn carriage operators in the city, giving and granting to the franchised operators of such services an opportunity to reply on the question of convenience and necessity, both prior to and at the hearing to be held by the city council, as provided for in section 110-314. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-97, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-313. - Notice of application, hearing. 
    Upon the filing of an application for a horse-drawn carriage franchise, the city secretary shall cause a notice to be published in the daily newspaper of the city, and the cost of publishing shall be advanced in full by the applicant. The notice shall set out the facts that an application has been filed for a horse-drawn carriage service, the name of the applicant, the kind of equipment, and all other pertinent data from such application which the city secretary may deem necessary. Such publication shall constitute a notice to all holders of existing horse-drawn carriage licenses and to the public that a public hearing will be held by the city council at a public place in the city, and at a designated time given in such notice, which designated time shall not be less than five days nor more than 15 days after the date of the publication of such notice. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-98, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-314. - Hearing on application. 
    All holders of existing horse-drawn carriage franchises or any other citizens shall be entitled to file any complaints or protests that such party may have to the issuance of any horse-drawn carriage franchise. At the time of the holding of the investigation and hearing, with reference to whether the public convenience and necessity require the operation of such additional vehicles covered in the application for a horse-drawn carriage franchise, the city council shall consider all of the complaints and protests and in conducting the hearing shall have the right to call such witnesses as they shall see fit. In all such hearings, the burden of proof shall be upon the applicant to establish by clear, cogent, and convincing evidence that the public convenience and necessity require such operation of the horse-drawn carriages for which such application has been made and that the applicant is fit, able, and willing to perform such transportation of persons and property by horse-drawn carriage as proposed in such application. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-99, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-315. - Notice to applicants. 
(a)  If the city council finds from the investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity justify the operation of the horse-drawn carriages for which a horse-drawn carriage license is desired, they shall notify the applicant thereof of their findings. Within five days thereafter, the applicant shall furnish to the city manager any and all relevant information which may be required. 
(b)  If the city council finds from such investigation and hearing that the public convenience and necessity do not justify the operation of the vehicles for which a horse-drawn carriage license is desired, the city council shall forthwith notify the applicant of its finding. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-100, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-316. - Issuance of certificate. 
    If the city council finds that there is a need of transportation by horse-drawn carriage that is not being furnished by the franchised operators of such services and the insurance policy required by this article has been filed and deposited with the city manager and that such equipment and animals comply with and the applicant has complied with all relevant provisions of this Code and relevant ordinances of the city and all of the rules and regulations established by the city manager to more effectively carry out the purpose and intent of this article and such ordinances, they shall issue a written certificate to the city secretary, not more than ten days after their findings have been declared, certifying that the public convenience and necessity require the operation of such horse-drawn carriages or any less number thereof which the applicant desires and proposes to operate, and that the applicant is entitled to have such equipment licensed as horse-drawn carriage services and franchises to operate horse-drawn carriages upon complying with all other provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-101, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-317. - Sale, transfer of certificate. 
    No certificate of public convenience and necessity for a horse-drawn carriage franchise may be sold and transferred without the written approval of the city expressed by a resolution. No resolution shall be drafted approving the sale and transfer of a certificate of public convenience and necessity for a horse-drawn carriage franchise without a hearing first held before the city council, followed by a finding of the city council that the person proposing to purchase such franchise is fit, able, and willing to carry on the transportation of persons by horse-drawn carriage in accordance with the terms and provisions of this article. If the person seeking to purchase a franchise is a person holding a franchise and a certificate of public convenience and necessity, and being a then-licensed operator of horse-drawn carriages in the city, then the applicant asking authority to purchase shall be deemed to have introduced a prima facie case of fitness, willingness, and ability. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-102, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-318-110-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FRANCHISE 

Sec. 110-336. - Required. 
    No person shall be permitted to engage in the transportation of persons for hire in the operation of horse-drawn carriages in the city unless a franchise to permit such operation of horse-drawn carriages is first obtained from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-103, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-337. - Application. 
    It shall be the duty of the city secretary to receive all applications for franchises to operate horse-drawn carriages. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-104, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-338. - Liability and casualty insurance. 
(a)  No franchise shall be issued under this article, nor shall such franchise be valid after issuance, nor shall any transportation service be operated unless there is at all times in force and effect insurance meeting the requirements of state law for automobile liability insurance, providing for payment of damages to property and injury to or death of individuals in accidents resulting from any cause for which the operator and/or vehicle driver would be liable on account of liability imposed by law, regardless of whether the vehicle was being driven by the operator or driver. 
(b)  The maximum amount of recovery in a policy of insurance required by this article shall not be less than the state minimum. 
(c)  Every insurance policy or contract of insurance required under this section shall contain a provision that the liability of the insurer shall not be affected by the insolvency or bankruptcy of the insured, and every such policy shall contain a provision making the city an additional insured under such policy or contract of insurance. 
(d)  Every insurance policy or contract of insurance required under this section shall contain a provision for the insurer to give not less than 30 days written notice to the city and to the named insured before any cancellation or termination of any such policy or contract of insurance. Cancellation or termination of any such policy or contract of insurance shall automatically revoke and terminate the permit unless another insurance policy complying with the provisions of this section shall be provided and be in effect at the time of such cancellation or termination. 
(e)  A certificate of insurance showing compliance with insurance required under this section shall be filed with the chief of police, and no permit granted under this article shall be valid unless and until such certificate shall have been so tendered. Such certificate shall be replaced when it expires. 
(f)  Any operator shall indemnify and hold harmless the city from and against all liability arising out of the operator's permitted activities under this article. 
(g)  All policies or contracts of insurance shall be approved by the city and shall be issued by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-105, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-339. - Street rental charge. 
    An annual street rental charge is levied upon the owner and operator of horse-drawn carriages operating within the city limits in the sum on file in the city secretary's office per horse-drawn carriage for which the franchise is granted or held. The holder of a franchise or the operator of a horse-drawn carriage shall be required to pay to the city at the office of the city secretary, in lawful money of the United States, such amount, which remittance shall be made annually on or before each February 1 for the preceding calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-106, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-340. - Duration. 
    Any franchise granted to operators of horse-drawn carriages shall continue for a period of five years, unless sooner revoked by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-107, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-341. - Organization of business. 
    In the performance of his duties and privilege under this article, the grantee of a franchise may provide for the conduct of such business by operating the same through divisions, or units, under trade names or trademarks, or through operating companies, provided each such operation shall first be approved by the city council by resolution duly adopted, and provided no such operation shall diminish the obligation of the revenue accruing to the city under this grant. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-108, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 110-342. - Assignment, subletting. 
    No person granted a franchise under this division shall assign or sublet his franchise.
