(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-109, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-343. - Payment of taxes, levies, etc. 
    Any grantee of a franchise under this division shall promptly pay all lawful ad valorem taxes, and such other levies and assessments, if any, that may be lawfully imposed upon the grantee. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-110, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-344. - Amendments. 
    The city expressly reserves the right to modify, amend, alter, change, or eliminate any of the provisions of the franchise granted pursuant to this division, during the life of the same, for the following purposes: 
(1)  To eliminate or delete from the same such conditions as then prove obsolete or impractical. 
(2)  To impose such additional conditions upon the grantee as may be just and reasonable, such conditions to be those as may be deemed necessary for the purpose of ensuring adequate service to the public. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-111, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-345. - Suspension or termination of franchise and business license. 
(a)  The franchise and business license granted under this article shall be subject to suspension and/or termination for neglect, failure, or refusal of such owner or horse-drawn carriage operator to comply with the terms of such franchise or this article. 
(b)  In the event of complaint or upon its own motion the city council may set a public hearing, giving the owner or carriage operator at least seven days' notice of the hearing and the given nature of the complaint or concern. 
(c)  If the owner or carriage operator should be found at such hearing to have violated the term of this article or its franchise or business license, the city council may, by written notice to the owner or carriage operator, suspend for a period of time or revoke the rights of the owner or carriage operator under such franchise or business license or admonish such owner or carriage operator. 
(d)  Notice shall be effective when sent certified mail, return receipt required, properly addressed and postage paid to the recipient. Notice of the decision of the city council upon the hearing shall be sent within five business days of such hearing. Appeal of such suspension, revocation, or admonition shall be to the state district court of the county. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-112, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-346-110-370. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LICENSES AND PERMITS 

Sec. 110-371. - Authority to operate required. 
(a)  A person shall not operate a horse-drawn carriage service within the city without first securing operating authority granted under this article. 
(b)  A person shall not transport a passenger for hire inside the city limits by carriage unless the driver holds a valid state driver's license. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire on city streets for any purpose except as provided under the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-116, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-372. - Grant or denial; scope. 
    The authority to grant or deny a permit under this division and to renew or deny renewal of a permit, shall be vested exclusively with the city manager. Upon arrival of an application for a permit, the permit holder is authorized to operate horse-drawn carriages carrying passengers for hire on an approved route within the city for a period of 12 months beginning on the date stated on the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-117, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-373. - Application. 
    To obtain a permit pursuant to this division, a person shall make application to the city manager in a manner prescribed by this section. The applicant must be the person who will own, control, or operate the horse-drawn carriage service. The applicant shall file with the city a written, sworn application containing the following: 
(1)  The nature of the service to be performed. 
(2)  Name, address, and verified signature of the applicant. 
(3)  The proposed hours of operation. 
(4)  The name, address, and driver's license number of all horse-drawn carriage drivers. 
(5)  Number and description of the horses and carriages the applicant proposes to use in the operation of the horse-drawn carriage service. 
(6)  An outline and description of the proposed route to be traveled by the horse-drawn carriage, to include proposed area of loading and unloading passengers. Note: All proposed routes are subject to rejection or modification by the chief of police. 
(7)  Proof of liability insurance covering the period of proposed operation of the horse-drawn carriage will be required before a permit to operate is issued. 
(8)  If application is by other than owner of carriages and/or horses, the applicant shall provide the name and address of the actual owner, and the applicant shall provide proof of ownership of the carriages and/or horses. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-118, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-374. - Fees. 
(a)  An applicant under this division shall pay the city a permit fee per year for each carriage authorized by the permit. Such fee is on file in the city secretary's office. 
(b)  Payment of the permit fee shall be made prior to the issuance of the permit. 
(c)  A permit holder shall operate not more than the approved number of carriages authorized by the permit. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-119, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-375. - Suspension of permit. 
(a)  The city manager, the chief of police, or assistant chief of police may temporarily suspend the operation privileges of a permit holder under this division when he finds that the permit holder is in violation of the franchise or regulations as set out in this article and such violation constitutes an imminent danger to the health or safety of the public. 
(b)  Notice will be given to the driver or permit holder to immediately suspend operations, stating the reason for the temporary suspension. The permit holder shall not operate a horse-drawn carriage until the cause for suspension has been corrected and same has been reinspected by the code enforcement officer and the suspension lifted by the city manager. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-120, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-376. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The city manager may revoke a horse-drawn carriage permit where he finds that it is in direct violation of the franchise or regulations set out in this article, and/or where a permit holder or driver has had two or more suspensions pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The city manager shall give written notice to the horse-drawn carriage permit holder of such revocation of privilege to operate. The decision of the city manager to revoke a holder's permit shall be appealable to the city council upon written notice of appeal within seven days of such revocation. Such appeal shall be heard by the city council within 30 days of receipt of the city council of such notice of appeal. The appeal shall use the same criteria as set out in this section. That person may not reapply for a new permit for 90 days. 
(c)  The chief of police, code enforcement officer, or any police officer may petition the city manager to revoke a holder's permit to operate a horse-drawn carriage for the following causes: 
(1)  The holder will permit or has permitted a driver to operate a horse-drawn carriage who does not have a valid state driver's license. 
(2)  Two or more health or safety violations of this article or traffic law convictions during the term of the permit. 
(3)  The consumption of alcoholic beverage or the use of drugs by a carriage driver while on duty. 
(4)  For any material violation of this article or rules and regulations governing horse-drawn carriages or violations of the laws of this state where it is determined revocation of a holder's permit is in the best interest of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-121, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Secs. 110-377-110-395. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - OPERATING AND SERVICE REGULATIONS 

Sec. 110-396. - Compliance by holders. 
    In the operation of a horse-drawn carriage service a holder shall comply with the terms and conditions of the holder's operating authority and shall comply with this article, regulations established under this article, and other law applicable to the operation of a horse-drawn carriage service. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-126, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-397. - Compliance by drivers. 
    While on duty, a driver of a horse-drawn carriage shall comply with this article, regulations established under this article, other law applicable to the operation of a motor vehicle in the state, and orders issued by the holder employing or contracting with the driver in connection with the holder's discharging of its duty under its operating authority and this article. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-127, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-398. - Holder's duty to enforce compliance by drivers. 
(a)  A holder pursuant to this article shall establish policy and take action to discourage, prevent, or correct violations of this article by drivers who are employed or contracted by the holder. 
(b)  A holder shall not permit a driver under his employ to operate a carriage if the holder knows or has reasonable cause to suspect that the driver has failed to comply with this article, the rules and regulations established by the city manager, the chief of police or other applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-128, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-399. - Holder's responsibility for fitness of driver. 
    Every holder pursuant to this article shall ensure that only persons who are physically and mentally fit and able to operate a horse-drawn carriage for hire will drive a horse-drawn carriage under the holder's authority to operate. It shall be the full responsibility of the holder to select and employ drivers who are qualified to operate horse-drawn carriages, and who are familiar with the streets within the city where horse-drawn carriages are allowed to operate. The holder shall submit to the city manager and the chief of police a roster of all drivers prior to operating horse-drawn carriages. The holder shall not permit any person not on that roster to drive a horse-drawn carriage under his control. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-129, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-400. - Conduct of drivers. 
    While on duty, a driver of a horse-drawn carriage shall: 
(1)  Conduct himself/herself in a reasonable, prudent, and courteous manner; 
(2)  Maintain a sanitary and well-groomed appearance; 
(3)  Not consume, nor report to duty within 12 hours after consuming, alcoholic beverages or drugs; 
(4)  Not solicit passengers in a loud or annoying tone of voice or by any manner annoying any person or obstruct the movement of any person for the purpose of soliciting patronage; 
(5)  Not permit any unauthorized person to operate carriages under his control; 
(6)  Not permit persons to ride or sit on horses under his control; 
(7)  Not leave a horse unattended at any time; 
(8)  Not permit a horse to drop excrement from its diaper; 
(9)  Empty diapers of all excrement when half full and at the beginning of each trip; 
(10)  Keep all routes and carriage staging areas clean and free of animal excrement; 
(11)  Walk a horse at a pace not faster than slow trot when transporting passengers; 
(12)  Not allow passengers to stand, hang over the side, or ride on the back of the carriage; 
(13)  Not allow passengers to engage in horseplay while in the carriage; 
(14)  Not permit anyone on the carriage who is intoxicated; 
(15)  Not allow alcoholic beverages to be brought on or consumed on the carriage; 
(16)  Have in his possession his state driver's license when operating a horse-drawn carriage; 
(17)  Comply with state motor vehicle laws governing the operation of a motor vehicle while operating a horse-drawn carriage on a public roadway within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-130, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-401. - Public liability and property damage insurance required. 
(a)  The permit holder pursuant to this article shall provide proof of and maintain, at his own expense, the following type and amount of insurance for the term of the permit: 
(1)  Type. Comprehensive general (public) liability to include, but not be limited to, the following: 
a.  Premises/operation; 
b.  Independent contractors; 
c.  Personal injury; 
d.  Product/completed operations; 
e.  Contractual liability; 
f.  Operation of horse-drawn carriages. 
(2)  Amount. Combined single limit for bodily injury and property damage, $500,000.00. 
(b)  The permittee further agrees that with respect to the required insurance, the city shall be: 
(1)  Named as additional insured; 
(2)  Provided with a waiver of subrogation; 
(3)  Notified immediately, in writing, of cancellation of insurance. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-131, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-402. - Payment of taxes. 
    The permit holder pursuant to this article shall pay all city taxes, fees, or assessments levied on the business or property used in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-132, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-403. - Hours of operation. 
    A person may operate a horse-drawn carriage only during the hours specified on the holder's permit, which shall be determined by the city manager with due regard to the health and safety of the customers and public at large as well as traffic safety and circulation. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-133, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-404. - Routes. 
(a)  A permit holder pursuant to this article shall operate carriage tours only within the areas approved by the chief of police. 
(b)  The carriage driver shall alter his route at the direction of a police officer in an emergency situation. 
(c)  Subject to city manager approval, additional restrictions may be imposed to promote the public safety. Additionally, the police department may impose temporary restrictions during period of heavy traffic congestion resulting from construction, traffic accidents, holiday activities, or other special events. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-134, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-405. - Maintenance of routes and staging areas. 
(a)  A permit holder pursuant to this article shall at his own expense keep routes and staging areas clean and free of all animal excrement and other debris created in the course of operating a horse-drawn carriage. A trash receptacle shall be maintained by the licensee at the loading/unloading site. 
(b)  Disposal of manure shall be the responsibility of the permit holder and must be transported to an approved disposal area. 
(c)  Where excrement has been removed from the route (street) or the staging area, water will be used to thoroughly rinse down those areas. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-135, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-406. - Fares. 
    The permit holder pursuant to this article shall file a schedule of fares with the city manager, subject to his approval. Fares may be adjusted only after filing a request through the city manager and approval granted. Minimum and maximum fares must be visibly posted at all embarkment points. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-136, 9-19-2000) 
Secs. 110-407-110-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MAINTENANCE AND SAFETY REQUIREMENTS FOR HORSES AND EQUIPMENT 

Sec. 110-426. - Identification, health certificate required for horses. 
(a)  No person shall use or offer the use of a horse not described in the application for the permit to operate a horse-drawn carriage service. For the purpose of this article, the use of a horse-drawn carriage service means that a horse is used or offered for use to the public for a fee for the purpose of operating a horse-drawn vehicle for hire. 
(b)  The application shall contain the name and address of the owner of each horse to be used by the holder or his employee for the purpose of pulling a horse-drawn vehicle. The age, sex, color, markings, and any other identifying marks such as brands or tattoos shall be listed in the application. Should there be a need for a horse previously identified on the application to be replaced or should the franchisee or licensee wish to permit additional horses, the city manager shall be provided all necessary information for the health certificate and the animal inspected by the code enforcement officer prior to being put in service. 
(c)  The applicant for a horse-drawn carriage permit shall at the time of application present to the city manager a health certificate for each horse to be used. The holder or applicant shall, at his own expense, have each horse examined by a licensed veterinarian before it is put in service. The health certificate will be valid for a period of 90 days from the date of issuance by the veterinarian. The certificate of health from the veterinarian shall contain a statement certifying the horse is physically sound, is free of disease, and is capable of being used to pull a horse-drawn carriage. The health certificate shall also contain the following information: 
(1)  The examination record of the horse in use; 
(2)  A picture of the horse; 
(3)  Weight of the horse (minimum weight 1,000 pounds); 
(4)  Description and location of any identifying characteristics, marks, brands, and/or tattoos; 
(5)  Description of any mechanical lameness which would not cause pain or suffering to the horse during use; and 
(6)  A record of annual immunization for rabies, Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis, eastern and western equine encephalomyelitis, tetanus, influenza, and annual negative Coggins test. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-141, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-427. - Health and safety requirements for horses. 
(a)  A permit holder pursuant to this article shall ensure that appropriate and sufficient food and drinking water are available for each horse and that, while working, each horse is permitted to eat at reasonable intervals and permitted to have access to drinking water as may be necessary. 
(b)  Permit holders shall not allow a horse to be worked during adverse weather or other dangerous conditions which are a threat to the health or safety of the horse, passengers, or general public. 
(c)  Permit holders and drivers shall ensure that carriage horses are not worked for more than eight hours in a continuous 24-hour period. 
(d)  A carriage horse required to be registered pursuant to this article which is lame or suffers from a physical condition or illness making it unsuitable for work may be ordered to be removed from work by a police officer, the code enforcement officer, or the city manager. A horse for which such order has been issued shall not be returned to work until it has recovered from the condition for which the order was issued. Before returning to work, the permit holder shall submit a statement from a veterinarian certifying that the condition no longer exists and the horse is fit to return to service. 
(e)  The permit holder shall, in the operation of a horse-drawn carriage, use only horses which are geldings or mares, at a minimum of three years old, which weigh at least 1,000 pounds. The horse shall be in such physical condition to perform the task without undue stress and effort. The permit holder shall ensure the horse has the stamina and physical ability to perform the work and duties required. 
(f)  The permit holder will ensure that the horse has been treated for internal parasites within the past four months under the direction of a veterinarian. The permit holder shall treat the horse for external parasites whenever found to be present. 
(g)  The permit holder shall ensure the hooves of the carriage horses are trimmed and their shoes are reset before placing them in service, using caulks or borium to prevent slippage. 
(h)  Permit holders and drivers shall ensure that carriage horses are kept clean at all times, especially those areas in contact with harnesses or other tack. 
(i)  Permit holders and drivers shall ensure that pads and other pieces of padded tack are kept clean and in safe and serviceable condition. 
(j)  The following shall deem a horse unfit for service and be cause for removal from service: 
(1)  Lameness of any kind, except that of a mechanical nature listed on the health certificate. 
(2)  Open sores or wounds caused or likely to be irritated by the bearing surfaces of harness, bridle, girth, or other tack. 
(3)  Obvious signs of emaciation, dehydration, or exhaustion. 
(4)  Loose shoes or unsafe or unserviceable tack. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-142, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-428. - Barns, stables, or other housing required; location. 
    The permit holder pursuant to this article shall be responsible for providing adequate housing for horses and carriages when not in service. Barns, stables, or other housing for horses and carriages shall be situated in areas properly zoned for such use. Horses and carriages shall at no time be stabled in a business or residential area of the city, unless so zoned for such use. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-143, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-429. - Seating capacity of carriages; occupation by minors. 
(a)  Each carriage operated under this article will have the seating capacity listed on the application for each carriage to be operated. The seating capacity of each carriage will be subject to approval of the chief of police. Under no circumstances will the number of passengers exceed the approved capacity. A baby in-arms shall not be deemed to occupy a seat. 
(b)  A parent, guardian, or other adult responsible for that child must accompany children under 12 years of age. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-144, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-430. - Safety and sanitation of carriages. 
(a)  Horse-drawn carriages will be kept clean and free of refuse. Carriages shall be kept in safe operating condition. Carriages and wheels shall not have any visible cracks, broken or, missing parts, or visible damage. All required safety equipment shall be in good and operable condition. Wheels shall be firmly attached to the hub and shall not wobble excessively. Carriages using rubber tires shall meet those standards set forth in the state motor vehicle law for a motor vehicle. All springs, axles, and supporting structures shall be intact without any visible breaks or deflection greater than incurred by a normal load. 
(b)  Unless otherwise provided for in this article, while working, each horse shall wear a properly fitted diaper that prevents excrement from being deposited on the streets. If the city manager determines that such equipment, i.e., diaper, is not readily manufactured and/or available for the horse utilized by the permittee, the city manager may waive such equipment requirement. Such waiver must be in writing signed by the city manager and/or his designee; however, such waiver shall not modify and/or reduce the other obligations imposed upon the permittee by this article. 
(c)  The holder will provide proper cleaning equipment for the removal of excrement from streets and loading areas (shovels, brooms, and adequate water supply). 
(d)  The holder will provide a closed container for the disposal of excrement; containers will be emptied periodically and will not be allowed to cause an offensive odor. Containers will be removed from staging areas at the end of each working day. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-145, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-431. - Inspection and identification of carriages and equipment. 
    The code enforcement officer will inspect horse-drawn carriages and equipment before they are put in service and at his discretion there after. The permit holder is required to identify each carriage listed in the permit by a visible number painted or placed on an attached placard on each carriage. Each carriage in service will have a copy of the permit to operate as a horse-drawn carriage on board. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-146, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-432. - Lighting requirements generally. 
(a)  Lighting requirements for horse-drawn carriages operating in the city limits are established to make carriages as safe as possible for passengers and to enable vehicular traffic to see and avoid collisions with these carriages. A strong consideration for lighting requirements is the fact that carriages have no generators and must rely on battery power for their lights. Because of this, the use of commonly available bulb and lighting fixtures and reflectors are required. 
(b)  To avoid maintenance problems with batteries, it is suggested that operators utilize deep cycle batteries, such as those used in marine or RV applications. These batteries are only a suggestion and are not mandatory, although they will perform more efficiently than a standard automobile battery under the conditions for which they are used. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-147, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-433. - Carriage rear lighting. 
(a)  Two red lights and two red reflectors shall be mounted on and visible from the rear of the horse-drawn carriage. The reflectors shall be at least three inches in diameter or seven square inches in area. The red lamps shall be at least four inches in diameter and shall be mounted as far to either side of the carriage rear as possible. 
(b)  The lamps shall be mounted above the reflectors and no higher than five feet from the ground. The reflectors shall be mounted as far as practical below the lamps on the rear of the carriage, but no lower than two feet from the ground. 
(c)  Bulbs of at least 32 candlepower designated by the trade lamp number 1156 shall be used in the lamp. It is rated at 12 volts and draws two amps when lit. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-148, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-434. - Carriage front lighting. 
(a)  One lamp displaying a white light shall be mounted on and visible from the front of the horse-drawn carriage. This lamp shall be at least four inches in diameter and use a 32-candlepower number 1156 bulb. It shall be placed as far to the left (looking forward) as possible and shall not be obscured from view by the person driving the carriage, passengers, or the animals pulling the carriage. It shall be mounted no less than two feet nor more than five feet from the ground as measured from the center of the lens. 
(b)  All lamps on the horse-drawn carriage shall be in operation during the nighttime hours, from a half-hour after sunset to a half-hour before sunrise, or at any time when weather conditions cause visibility to be reduced from normal daytime visibility. The wiring for all lamps shall be so mounted and maintained so that it is not damaged by persons entering or exiting the carriage, nor create a danger to any passenger. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-149, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-435. - Side reflectors. 
(a)  Each horse-drawn carriage will have six additional reflectors. Two reflectors will be mounted on each side of the carriage as far apart to the front and rear. 
(b)  Also, one reflector will be mounted on each side of the animal pulling the carriage, either attached to the harness of the animal or on the draw bars of the carriage and as far as possible toward the front of the horse. Where more than one horse is used to pull the carriage, each horse will have one reflector mounted on each side. 
(c)  All the reflectors mentioned in this section shall be white, yellow, or amber in color, and shall be at least three inches in diameter or seven square inches in size. 
(d)  White reflectors mounted on the side of a horse or carriage shall not face the rear of the carriage. Reflectors will be visible for a distance of 600 feet when illuminated by the lawful low beams of headlamps. All reflectors will be mounted no less than two feet nor more than five feet off the ground as measured from the center of the lens. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-150, 9-19-2000) 
Sec. 110-436. - Slow-moving vehicles emblem required. 
(a)  Every horse-drawn carriage shall display a slow-moving vehicle emblem on the rear and center of the carriage. The emblem shall be a 133/4-inch fluorescent orange triangle with a one and five-eighths-inch red reflective border, giving a total width of 16 inches by 14 in height. This emblem will meet the current standards adopted by the American Society of Agriculture Engineers and will be visible in daylight or at night when illuminated by the lawful lower beams of headlamps for a distance of not less than 500 feet. It will be mounted base down in the rear center of the carriage, not less than three feet, nor more than five feet from the ground as measured from the base of the emblem. No decoration, trim, or any part of the carriage shall cover or obscure any part of the emblem at any time. 
(b)  All lamps and reflectors and the emblem shall be maintained in a clean, visible condition at all times. The electrical supply to such lamps will be maintained to provide sufficient power so the lamps are visible at night for a distance of at least 1,000 feet. 
(Ord. No. 1217-9-00, § 28-151, 9-19-2000) 
Chapter 114 - WATERWAYS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42; manufactured homes, mobile homes and parks, ch. 66; parks and recreation, ch. 74; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 90; zoning, ch. 118. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 114-1-114-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LAKE NACOGDOCHES RULES AND REGULATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 114-26. - Assumption of risk. 
    The city shall not be liable to any person on account of the loss or damage of any property that may be placed in or upon Lake Nacogdoches, nor shall the city be liable to any person whomsoever on account of personal injuries or loss of life that may be sustained by any person in or upon Lake Nacogdoches. Any person entering in or upon the lake shall do so at his sole risk and shall not be privileged to enter or remain in or upon such reservoir, save and except under the terms of this article that have been or may be adopted by the city council, nor shall the city be responsible or liable in such instances as set out in this section. 
(Code 1971, § 7-19; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 114-27. - Waiver. 
    The city council may, upon application and after hearing, waive for a specified length of time such of the terms, provisions, and conditions of this article that may be deemed appropriate for the accommodation of water carnivals, shows, boat races, educational purposes, exhibitions and other special events as may be permitted from time to time, and subject to such safety measures as the city council may require. 
(Code 1971, § 7-20; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 114-28. - Use of area between elevation 286 and water level. 
(a)  For the purpose of this article, the lake shall be defined as including not only the body of water known as Lake Nacogdoches but also all of that area between the water level, as such may advance or recede, and the elevation of 286 feet above mean sea level (MSL). 
(b)  Owners of record of land contiguous to elevation 286 MSL shall have the joint right with the city to the use of the land between elevation 286 and the water level subject to the city's right, power and duty to make regulations, ordinances, and other requirements deemed necessary by it in the construction, maintenance, and operation of Lake Nacogdoches as a water source. 
(Code 1971, § 7-21) 
Sec. 114-29. - Domesticated animals prohibited. 
    All domesticated animals are prohibited from Lake Nacogdoches, its parks and beaches, except that dogs may be used by persons engaged in the lawful exercise of waterfowl hunting only for the purpose of retrieving dead or wounded waterfowl in Lake Nacogdoches and for the purpose of training dogs for such. Such training and/or retrieval shall take place only north of the electric transmission lines crossing Lake Nacogdoches and from 30 days prior to the beginning of each waterfowl season as set by the state or the United States or their agencies until the end of each waterfowl season. Such dogs shall be kept on a leash and confined within a boat or other motor vehicle while on Lake Nacogdoches south of the electric transmission line, any boatramp, parking area, roadway or other area of lake property and must be transported forthwith and by the most direct route to the area north of the electric transmission line. 
(Code 1971, § 7-22) 
Sec. 114-30. - Glass beverage containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to bring any glass beverage container into the Lake Nacogdoches eastside and westside parks, their beaches and/or parking areas. 
(Code 1971, § 7-23) 
Sec. 114-31. - Swimming area hours. 
    All swimming areas at Lake Nacogdoches shall be closed at sundown, with all other park areas and facilities being closed at 10:00 p.m. with the exception of the boatramps, parking lots, and restrooms. 
(Code 1971, § 7-24) 
Sec. 114-32. - Livestock. 
    No animal pens, corrals, or barns shall be constructed within 500 feet measured horizontally from the 286-foot elevation or at any point from which drainage may run in to Lake Nacogdoches or into any stream which lies within the Lake Nacogdoches watershed. 
(Code 1971, § 7-87) 
Sec. 114-33. - Wells. 
    All wells at Lake Nacogdoches must be driven or bored and properly cased and shall be installed and maintained in such a matter as to meet the requirements of the state health department. 
(Code 1971, § 7-88) 
Sec. 114-34. - Garbage and trash. 
    No garbage, trash, refuse, dead animals, fish, vegetables, food, ashes, offal, fecal matter, cans, bottles, glass, rubbish, or filth of any kind shall be placed or be permitted to be placed in the water of Lake Nacogdoches or situated in such a manner that it will drain toward or reach the water of Lake Nacogdoches. 
(Code 1971, § 7-89) 
Cross reference- Solid waste, ch. 82. 
Sec. 114-35. - Placing of artificial shelters or bait. 
    No artificial shelter, such as willow tops, etc., or any bait of any kind shall be placed in the waters of Lake Nacogdoches without first obtaining permission from the city or lake officer. 
(Code 1971, § 7-90) 
Secs. 114-36-114-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 114-61. - Office of lake officer. 
(a)  There is created the office of lake officer, which shall be filled by the chief of police. The lake officer shall be a licensed peace officer employed by the city police department. In a like manner and subject to the same terms, the lake officer shall have such number of assistants, if any, as the chief of police may see proper to appoint from time to time. Such officer and his assistants shall exercise all of the rights and powers of peace officers as provided by this Code or city ordinances and state statutes and regulations. 
(b)  The lake officer may inspect all boats and other watercraft before the boats and watercraft are permitted to be placed on Lake Nacogdoches under V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code title 4, Water Safety, and any other applicable statute and ordinances. If the officer concludes the watercraft or boat is unsafe or dangerous to life, such watercraft may be removed from the lake. 
(c)  It shall further be the duty of the lake officer to patrol Lake Nacogdoches and the adjoining lands for the purpose of enforcing strict compliance on the part of all persons with the terms, provisions, and conditions of this article and all other state laws, ordinances, rules and regulations relating to such lake and to make arrests upon the violation of any of the sections of this article. 
(Code 1971, §§ 7-16, 7-17) 
Sec. 114-62. - Right to exclude persons from the lake. 
    The lake officer, any police officer or any other authorized city representative shall have the right and authority to exclude from Lake Nacogdoches any person in violation of the sections of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 7-18) 
Secs. 114-63-114-90. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - BOATS AND BOATING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Texas water safety act, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.001 et seq. 

Sec. 114-91. - Boats for rent or hire and commercial concession permits. 
(a)  No person shall rent or let for hire boats on Lake Nacogdoches without first having obtained a commercial permit and paid the license fee as may be set by the city council. 
(b)  No person shall conduct a concession business in areas of city authority without first having obtained a commercial permit and paid the license fee as may be set by the city council. 
(Code 1971, § 7-56; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 114-92. - Inspection of boats. 
    All boats on Lake Nacogdoches shall be subject to inspection as to structural soundness and proper state registration. 
(Code 1971, § 7-28) 
Sec. 114-93. - Launching at authorized points. 
    No person shall launch a boat or other watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches except at points designated and authorized by the city council. However, this section shall not apply to privately owned boatramps being used by the owner or his guests. Any privately owned launching ramp or device shall be constructed and maintained in accordance with the requirements of division 5 of this article relating to docks and other structures. 
(Code 1971, § 7-29; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 114-94. - Traffic rules. 
(a)  The following traffic rules shall be observed by boats and other watercraft operating on Lake Nacogdoches: 
(1)  Passing. When two boats or other watercraft are approaching each other head on or nearly so, so as to involve risk of collision, it shall be the duty of each boat to bear to the right and pass the other boat on its left side. 
(2)  Right-of-way. When boats approach each other obliquely or at right angles, the boat approaching on the right side has the right-of-way. 
(3)  Overtaking. One boat may overtake another on either side but must grant the right-of-way to the overtaken boat. 
(4)  Sailboats. Sailboats have the right-of-way over all other boats. 
(b)  Except as otherwise expressly provided in this article, the water safety act, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.001 et seq., applicable to the operation of small boats is made a part of this article. 
(Code 1971, § 7-31) 
Sec. 114-95. - Reckless driving and speeding. 
(a)  Every operator of a boat or other watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches shall at all times navigate the boat or watercraft in a careful and prudent manner and at such rate of speed as not to endanger the life, limb, or property of any person. 
(b)  Reckless navigation of any boat or watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches shall include operating the boat or watercraft in a manner which unnecessarily interferes with the free and proper use of the water of the lake or unnecessarily endangers other boats and watercraft on the lake or the life and limb of any person. 
(c)  No person shall operate any boat or other watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches at a rate of speed greater than will permit, by the exercise of reasonable care, such boat to be brought to a stop within the assured clear distance ahead. 
(d)  Boat operators in areas adjacent to public ramp launching facilities, whether designated by marker buoys or not, shall limit their motor boats to a no-wake speed (five mph). 
(Code 1971, § 7-32) 
State Law reference- Excessive speed, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.095. 
Sec. 114-96. - Reckless or negligent operation. 
    No person shall operate any motorboat or vessel or manipulate any water skis, aquaplane, or similar device in a willfully or wantonly reckless or negligent manner that endangers the life, limb, or property of any person on Lake Nacogdoches. 
(Code 1971, § 7-33) 
State Law reference- Reckless operation, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.096. 
Sec. 114-97. - Obstruction of boat launching facilities. 
    No person shall anchor a boat or other watercraft for fishing or other purposes on Lake Nacogdoches in such a position as to obstruct the entrances or exits to the public or private boat launching facilities. 
(Code 1971, § 7-34) 
State Law reference- Obstructing passage, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.101. 
Sec. 114-98. - Mooring and buoys. 
    No person shall at any time moor any boat or other watercraft to any buoy, beacon, or sign placed on Lake Nacogdoches, nor shall any person in any manner hang on with a boat to such buoy, beacon, or sign. 
(Code 1971, § 7-35) 
Sec. 114-99. - Anchoring. 
    No person shall leave a boat or any other watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches without having the boat or watercraft dependably fastened to an anchorage either in the water or upon the land, or any such boat or other watercraft must be removed from the water a sufficient distance to ensure that the boat or watercraft will not be caused to float away from its placement because of rising waters. No boat or other watercraft shall be permitted to remain anchored upon land, but can be within a boathouse or dock or entirely removed from the lake. 
(Code 1971, § 7-36) 
Sec. 114-100. - Accidents. 
    If the operator of any boat or watercraft involved in an accident on Lake Nacogdoches resulting in injury or death to any person or in damage to property, he shall, so far as he can do so without danger to his own vessel, crew, and passengers, if any, render to other persons affected by the collision such assistance as may be practicable and give his name, address, full identification of his boat and the name and address of the owner of the boat struck or the operator or occupants of the boats collided with and shall report such accident immediately to the lake officer, the police department, or the state parks and wildlife department. 
(Code 1971, § 7-37) 
State Law reference- Accidents, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.104. 
Sec. 114-101. - Water sports. 
    Skiing, surf boarding, and other comparable water sports shall be governed as follows: 
(1)  The term "skiing," as used in section 2:12 or anywhere else in the rules and regulations of Lake Nacogdoches, shall be defined as the use of any equipment of any kind or character whose purpose is to pull or propel a human body through, on or over the surface of Lake Nacogdoches. It is further specified that sailboats are exempted from this definition. 
(2)  Boats towing people engaged in such activities shall go no nearer than 200 feet of shore, docks, persons swimming, or other boats, except when leaving and returning to the dock. 
(3)  Such activity shall not be engaged in between sunset and sunrise nor shall any person operate a boat for the purpose of towing persons engaged in such activities between sunset and sunrise. 
(4)  No other boat or watercraft shall follow closer than 200 feet behind persons engaged in such activity. 
(5)  Scuba diving is allowed in the lake only in areas within 140 feet of a shoreline, except for emergency rescue or salvage operations or for special events for which exceptions may be granted by the lake officer. Scuba diving in other areas is prohibited. 
(6)  Each diver must be accompanied by at least one other diver. 
(7)  A warning flag reading "diver below" shall be displayed on the water's surface on a buoy or boat in the area where scuba diving is in progress. The sign must be readable from 100 feet and must be removed when the divers return to the boat. 
(8)  Scuba diving will not be carried on where it will interfere with normal boat traffic. 
(9)  A tow boat pulling water skiers must be equipped with a rearview mirror as specified by the state water safety act. 
(10)  Skiing in the northern end of Lake Nacogdoches shall be prohibited in areas marked by buoys. 
(11)  Skiing shall be prohibited on Lake Nacogdoches in all areas north of the existing overhead electrical transmission lines. This area shall be marked with "no-skiing" buoys or signs at such locations as deemed appropriate by the lake officer. 
(12)  Swimming only areas will be designated by marker buoys. 
(Code 1971, § 7-38) 
State Law reference- Personal watercraft, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.106. 
Sec. 114-102. - Lights. 
    No boat shall be operated on Lake Nacogdoches between sunset and sunrise unless the lights required by the state water safety act, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.064, shall be operating and lighted. In addition, all motorboats less than 16 feet in length, regardless of the motor's horsepower, shall have lights as required by the state water safety act for class 1 boats. 
(Code 1971, § 7-39) 
State Law reference- Lights, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.064. 
Sec. 114-103. - Capacity of watercraft. 
    No person owning or operating a boat or other watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches shall permit the boat or watercraft to be occupied by more than the rated capacity of such boat or other watercraft, nor shall any person owning or operating a watercraft on the lake permit the watercraft to be loaded with passengers or cargo beyond its safe capacity, taking into consideration weather and other operating conditions. 
(Code 1971, § 7-40) 
Sec. 114-104. - Life preservers. 
    Every boat or watercraft operating on Lake Nacogdoches must be equipped with one life preserver per person. Life preservers shall be of an approved type, adequate to sustain afloat any occupant of the boat. Children under the age of 13 must wear a life preserver at all times while the boat is in motion on the lake. 
(Code 1971, § 7-41) 
State Law reference- Life preservers, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.066. 
Sec. 114-105. - Flotation devices. 
    No boat or other watercraft shall be operated on Lake Nacogdoches unless it is self-sustained either by patent methods, compartmentation or composition. Inboard power boats shall be exempted from this section. The lake officer may grant, for a period not to exceed 30 days, permission to use a raft or barge on Lake Nacogdoches for constructing, dredging, or other purposes, and nothing contained in this section shall prohibit the city and its authorized representatives from using rafts and barges in the operation and maintenance of Lake Nacogdoches. 
(Code 1971, § 7-42) 
Sec. 114-106. - Muffling devices. 
    It is unlawful to use a boat propelled by gas, gasoline, or naphtha on Lake Nacogdoches unless the boat is provided with a stock factory muffler, underwater exhaust or water exhaust manifold capable of adequately muffling the sound of the engine. The term "adequate muffling" shall mean that the motor's exhaust at all times be so muffled or suppressed as not to create excessive or unusual noise. However, the city council, in its sole discretion, may permit the operation of competition-type motorboats without muffling devices and subject to such restrictions and regulations as the lake officer may direct. 
(Code 1971, § 7-43; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 114-107. - Fire extinguishers. 
    Fire extinguishers are required in all boats as prescribed by the state water safety act, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.067. 
(Code 1971, § 7-44) 
State Law reference- Fire extinguishers, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.067. 
Sec. 114-108. - Carburetors. 
    Carburetors on all engines of motorboats used on Lake Nacogdoches, other than outboard motors, shall be fitted with a U.S. Coast Guard approved device for arresting backfire. 
(Code 1971, § 7-45) 
State Law reference- Flame arrestors, backfire traps, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.068. 
Sec. 114-109. - Ventilators. 
    On Lake Nacogdoches, all inboard motorboats using fuel having a flashpoint of 110 degrees Fahrenheit or less shall have at least two ventilators fitted with cowls or their equivalent for the purpose of properly and efficiently ventilating the bilge of every engine and fuel compartment in order to remove any inflammable or explosive gases. Some motorboats so constructed as to have the greater portion of the bilge under the engine and fuel tanks opened and exposed to the natural atmosphere at all times need not be required to be fitted with such ventilators. 
(Code 1971, § 7-46) 
State Law reference- Ventilators, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.069. 
Sec. 114-110. - Toilet facilities. 
    No boat or other watercraft shall be placed, operated, or kept on Lake Nacogdoches if equipped with toilet facilities. 
(Code 1971, § 7-47) 
Sec. 114-111. - Sirens. 
    No person other than a duly authorized police officer or other person authorized by the city shall equip, own or operate a boat or other watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches which is equipped with a siren. 
(Code 1971, § 7-48) 
State Law reference- Whistles and bells, V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife Code § 31.065. 
Sec. 114-112. - Searchlights. 
    No person other than a duly authorized police officer or other person authorized by the city shall flash searchlights on the bridge of a boat or other watercraft being operated on Lake Nacogdoches. 
(Code 1971, § 7-49) 
Sec. 114-113. - Intoxication. 
    Any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drugs or barbiturates or any person who is a habitual user of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drugs or barbiturates shall not operate or occupy or be in physical control of any boat or other watercraft on Lake Nacogdoches, nor shall the owner of any boat or other watercraft or any person in charge or in control authorize or knowingly permit the boat or watercraft to be operated by any person who is under the influence of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drugs or barbiturates or by any person who is a habitual user of intoxicating liquor, narcotic drugs or barbiturates. 
(Code 1971, § 7-50) 
State Law reference- Operation of a vessel while intoxicated, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 49.06. 
Sec. 114-114. - Houseboats prohibited. 
    No person shall place, operate, or keep any houseboat on Lake Nacogdoches. For the purposes of this section, cabin cruisers or cruiserettes shall not be deemed to be houseboats, but any other watercraft capable of being occupied as living or camping quarters is prohibited. 
(Code 1971, § 7-51) 
Sec. 114-115. - Severe weather warning. 
    When, in the opinion of the lake officer, severe weather is forecast or when weather conditions on Lake Nacogdoches are such as to render boating, fishing, or other activities hazardous, the lake officer shall have the authority to order all persons, boats, and other watercraft to shore, under such terms and conditions that are deemed necessary for the protection of life, limb, and property. 
(Code 1971, § 7-53) 
Sec. 114-116. - Removal of boats. 
(a)  The lake officer may require the removal of any boat or other watercraft from Lake Nacogdoches if such boat or other watercraft is in an unsafe operating condition or if the boat or watercraft or its operator is in violation of any of the applicable sections of this article. 
(b)  Any person refusing to so remove any boat or watercraft under this section shall be deemed guilty in violation. 
(Code 1971, § 7-54) 
Sec. 114-117. - Abandoned boats. 
    Any boat or watercraft found abandoned or adrift on Lake Nacogdoches or any unlicensed boat or other watercraft thereon or any boat or watercraft not in use, found not anchored or grounded in compliance with this division shall be deemed to be derelict and shall be taken up by the lake officer, which shall be done at the owner's risk and without any liability whatsoever on the part of the city, and the city shall have a lien on the boat or watercraft for all unpaid fees. 
(Code 1971, § 7-55) 
Sec. 114-118. - Westside boatramp area. 
    The following shall govern the westside boatramp and that portion of Lake Nacogdoches adjacent to the westside boatramp: 
(1)  There is created a no swimming/no wake zone that extends outward to a 150-foot radius of the boat launching area with a maximum boat or other watercraft speed of five miles per hour. 
(2)  Fishing, boating, skiing, surf boarding, swimming or any other activity shall not be permitted within the no swimming/no wake zone. This shall not apply to boats and personal watercraft having ingress and egress by the most direct route, from the westside loading ramps. 
(3)  The no swimming/no wake zone as designated by this section shall be clearly marked with appropriate buoys. 
(Code 1971, § 7-99) 
Secs. 114-119-114-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - FISHING 

Sec. 114-146. - Applicability of state law. 
    General laws of the state, as enacted or as they may be amended or enacted, save and except as specifically provided through proper regulations passed by the city, will control the taking of fish from Lake Nacogdoches. 
(Code 1971, § 7-63) 
Sec. 114-147. - Fishing methods. 
    The state water safety act and state statues shall govern fishing methods on Lake Nacogdoches. For safety purposes, trotlines will be restricted to that area north of the electric power line on the upper portion of the lake. 
(Code 1971, § 7-64) 
Sec. 114-148. - Fishing tournaments. 
(a)  Fishing tournaments may be held on Lake Nacogdoches upon issuance of a city fishing tournament permit. 
(b)  A city fishing tournament permit may be obtained from and is granted by the city parks and recreation department upon acceptance of an application and payment of a permit fee as may be set from time to time by the parks and recreation department. 
(c)  A permit must be obtained for all tournaments. 
(d)  Activities in noncompliance of the conditions as set out in the application and/or permit will result in automatic revocation of the permit. 
(e)  Revocation of a city fishing tournament permit or any violation of the sections of this article or such rules, regulations, and policies as from time to time may be adopted by the parks and recreation department to monitor or administer fishing tournaments shall be unlawful and shall constitute a misdemeanor. Each day that the violation continues shall constitute a distinct and separate violation offense. 
(f)  Any criminal violation of this section, upon conviction, shall punished by a fine as provided in section 1-14. 
(Code 1971, § 7-65) 
Secs. 114-149-114-175. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - DOCKS AND OTHER STRUCTURES 

Sec. 114-176. - Classification of docks. 
(a)  Private docks. A private dock shall be any boat dock or structure, fixed or floating, placed upon the waters of Lake Nacogdoches for pleasure purposes only and producing no revenue, either direct or indirect to the owner. 
(b)  Commercial docks. A commercial dock shall be any boat, dock, or structure, fixed or floating, place upon the waters of Lake Nacogdoches and used by any person for the purposes of deriving revenue, direct or indirect, from the dock or structure. 
(c)  Public piers. Public piers shall be any structure, fixed or floating, placed on public property, extending into the waters of Lake Nacogdoches, which is available to the general public, for recreational purposes only, and producing no revenue, either direct or indirect, to the owner. 
(Code 1971, § 7-71) 
Sec. 114-177. - Permit required. 
    No dock, wharf, boathouse, or other structure shall be erected on Lake Nacogdoches without a written permit from the building inspection department. 
(Code 1971, § 7-72) 
Sec. 114-178. - Safety devices. 
    All piers, docks, wharves, or other similar fixed structures erected from the shores and into the body of Lake Nacogdoches shall be marked by placement of red reflectors along the side of the structure directly opposite from the shore and the placement of amber reflectors along the flank side of the structure. These reflectors shall be at least three inches in diameter placed at intervals of not more than ten feet between reflectors on all sides of any such pier, dock, wharf, or any similar fixed structure facing the waters of Lake Nacogdoches. 
(Code 1971, § 7-73) 
Sec. 114-179. - Anchoring. 
    Any piers, docks, and wharves not of permanent nature but floating may be anchored by the use of anchor lines running out into Lake Nacogdoches, provided such anchor lines do not extend over onto adjoining boundary lines of lots as protracted into the lake and provided such anchor lines are so located as not to block any canal or slough to less than the 30-foot clearance required in this division. Any floating-type dock, wharf, or pier must be located close enough to the adjoining property as to be connected to it by a walkway. 
(Code 1971, § 7-74) 
Sec. 114-180. - Construction standards. 
(a)  The minimum width of docks, piers, boathouses, and other structures on Lake Nacogdoches shall be four feet, and such shall be constructed in a safe manner. Wooden materials used shall be treated with a wood preservative. Boathouses are structures, as that term is used in the city building code, and persons desiring to construct them shall comply in all respects with such code. 
(b)  No permanent dock shall be constructed to exceed a height of two feet above the elevation of 279 feet above mean sea level. 
(c)  The walk or platform of such docks shall not exceed two feet in height above elevation 279 feet, nor shall any such dock extend more than 50 feet into the lake from the 279-foot level. Further, no dock shall be so constructed, regardless of length, as to block any channel or slough, it being necessary to leave a minimum of 30 feet of clearance and passageway for boats in the channel or slough. All docks must be a minimum of five feet from the side boundary lines of any private lot, as such boundary lines would be located if extended or protracted into the lake. No dock shall be constructed and projected out into Lake Nacogdoches by any persons not the owner of the land area from which such dock projects. 
(Code 1971, §§ 7-72, 7-75) 
Sec. 114-181. - Public piers. 
(a)  Public piers at Lake Nacogdoches shall be constructed in accordance to the city building code and electrical code, as amended. In addition no public pier shall extend horizontally more than 100 feet into the lake, from 279 feet above mean sea level. 
(b)  Public piers shall be adequately lighted so that they are visible from all directions of Lake Nacogdoches from a distance of not less than 1,000 feet. 
(c)  Public piers shall have their boundaries clearly marked with buoys and signage, visible not less than 150 feet in all directions projecting out at right angles from all sides of a public pier. Buoys shall not be spaced farther apart than 20 feet, signs shall be placed not farther apart than 50 feet on centers, and no less than one sign per pier face will be allowed for any public pier over 50 feet in length beyond elevation 279. No boats shall be allowed within 150 feet of any public pier. No swimming shall be allowed within 150 feet from any public pier. 
(d)  Maximum occupancy limits shall be established and posted for all public piers by the building official. 
(e)  Proper rules shall be posted on all public piers stating: "No alcoholic beverages, no swimming, no loud music, no parties, no fires, no fireworks and no cooking." 
(Code 1971, § 7-75a) 
Sec. 114-182. - Ski jumps and similar structures. 
    No ski jumps or structures of such nature shall be constructed or placed upon Lake Nacogdoches without prior written consent of the city council upon application, and such shall not be constructed except at a point designated by the lake officer in such written permit. 
(Code 1971, § 7-76; Ord. No. 1535-11-09, § 3, 11-17-2009) 
Sec. 114-183. - Buoys, signs and beacons. 
    No buoys for anchoring boats or other purposes or floating signs, markers, or beacons shall be placed in Lake Nacogdoches without prior written consent as to the location by the lake officer. 
(Code 1971, § 7-77) 
Sec. 114-184. - Electric or other permanent lines. 
    No electric transmission line or other permanent line or rope shall lead to any dock, wharf, boathouse or other floating object above water level at Lake Nacogdoches unless it shall be high enough its entire length over water to give at least 20 feet of clearance between it and the high water level, elevation of 286 feet. 
(Code 1971, § 7-78) 
Sec. 114-185. - Use of boathouses restricted. 
    Boathouses shall be used for the housing of boats and equipment only, and human habitation shall not be permitted. 
(Code 1971, § 7-79) 
Secs. 114-186-114-210. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - RESTRICTED AREAS 

Sec. 114-211. - Dam area. 
    The following shall govern the dam and that portion of Lake Nacogdoches adjacent to the dam: 
(1)  No person shall be permitted upon any dam for any purpose. 
(2)  There is created a no wake zone that extends 300 feet outward from the dam with a maximum boat speed of five miles per hour. 
(3)  Fishing, boating, skiing, surf boarding or any other activity shall not be permitted within the no wake zone from the east end of the dam to a point 200 feet west of the water intake structure. This shall not apply to boats having ingress and egress, by the most direct route, from the loading ramps adjacent to the eastside park. 
(4)  Fishing and/or boating activities shall be allowed within the no wake zone from a point 200 feet west of the intake structures to the west end of the dam. No activities shall be permitted within 25 feet of the dam. 
(Code 1971, § 7-96) 
Sec. 114-212. - Other restricted areas. 
    No person shall engage in any activity on Lake Nacogdoches or around the lake in an area which has been designated by the city as a restricted area and which has been plainly marked with signs that such is a restricted area. 
(Code 1971, § 7-97) 
Secs. 114-213-114-240. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - HUNTING AND FIREARMS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Weapons, explosives and fireworks, § 70-26 et seq. 

Sec. 114-241. - Restrictions. 
    Except as may be authorized by the city from time to time, the possession and/or discharge of rifles or pistols, which shall be firearms capable of discharging solid projectiles, on Lake Nacogdoches is prohibited. The possession and discharge of shotguns is permitted only under the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  Hunting with shotguns in the reservoir area will be permitted in accordance with federal and state laws regulating the hunting of game and wildlife. 
(2)  Hunting will be permitted only in areas specifically designated by the lake officer. 
(3)  No duck blinds will be permitted on the lake or city property. 
(Code 1971, § 7-100) 
Chapter 118 - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Airport zoning, § 10-86 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; fences, § 14-386 et seq.; alcoholic beverages in businesses, § 18-26 et seq.; environment, ch. 34; floods, ch. 42; historic preservation, ch. 50; manufactured homes, mobile homes and parks, ch. 66; signs, ch. 78; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 86; subdivisions, ch. 90; telecommunications, ch. 98; waterways, ch. 114. 
State Law reference- Land use regulations, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 118-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Word interpretations. Interpretations of certain words used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
(1)  All words used in the present tense shall include the future. 
(2)  All words in the singular number include the plural number, and all words in the plural number include the singular number. 
(3)  The term "structure" includes the word "building," and the term "dwelling" includes the terms "residence" and "place of habitation." 
(4)  The term "person" includes corporation, copartnership, association, and individual. 
(5)  The term "shall" is mandatory and not discretionary. 
(b)  Undefined terms. Terms not defined in this section shall have the meanings assigned to them in the city building codes. Terms not defined in this section or in the building codes shall have the customary meaning assigned to them. 
(c)  Words and terms defined. The definitions in this subsection supplement, restrict, and define the meaning and intent of the use regulations as set forth in this chapter. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory apartment means an accessory dwelling for the use and occupancy by any person employed on the premises on a full-time basis for domestic or medical help or family members to the second degree of consanguinity and affinity. Such dwelling shall not have separate utility services or meters. This may also include an accessory dwelling located in a commercial or industrial district for the use of any person employed by the business or property owner to provide management, maintenance or security for the property. 
    Accessory use means a structure or use that: 
(1)  Is clearly incidental to and customarily found in connection with a principal building or use. 
(2)  Is subordinate to and serves a principal building or a principal use; is subordinate in area, extent, or purpose to the principal building or principal use served. 
(3)  Is located on the same lot as the principal building or use served. 
    Accessory use (residential) means a subordinate use which is detached from the main building and used for purposes customarily incidental to the residential occupancy of the main building and not involving the conduct of a business or the sale of a service. Accessory buildings include but are not limited to an automobile storage garage, laundry room, garden shelter, hobby room and mechanical room. 
    Airport or landing field means a landing facility for fixed wing aircraft containing a minimum of 60 acres. 
    All-weather surface means a hard smooth paved surface of either hot-mixed asphaltic concrete (HMAC) or Portland cement concrete (PCC) and the appropriate base material, meeting the following minimum specifications: 
(1)  Hot-mixed asphaltic concrete: 
a.  Surface: 1.5 inches of type D or type C material. 
b.  Base: six inches of compacted iron ore gravel or the equivalent flexible base, or four inches of compacted hot sand asphaltic base. 
(2)  Portland cement concrete: 
a.  Surface: five inches of class A, 3,000 psi concrete, reinforced with WWF 6 × 6, W 2.9 - 2.9. 
b.  Base: four inches of compacted granular material. 
Material shall conform to city and state department of transportation specifications. Other possible types of paved surfaces will be considered on a case-by-case basis by the city's planning and engineering departments. 
    Amusement, commercial (indoor) means an amusement enterprise wholly enclosed in a building, including but not limited to a bowling alley, bingo parlor or amusement arcade, but not including a billiard parlor or pool hall. 
    Amusement, commercial (outdoor) means any amusement enterprise offering entertainment or games of skill to the general public for a fee or charge wherein any portion of the activity takes place in the open, including but not limited to a golf driving range, archery range, and miniature golf course. 
    Animal hospital or clinic means a facility for the treatment or care of domestic animals, which includes a veterinarian's office, and may include overnight stays, but does not include outside pens. 
    Animal pound. See Animal hospital or clinic with outside pens. 
    Antique shop means an establishment offering for sale articles such as glass, china, furniture or similar furnishing and decorations which have value and significance as result of age, design or sentiment; and when all such items displayed or offered for sale are housed within a building and there is no exterior display except the usual sign or advertising. 
    Apartment means a dwelling unit in a multiple-family dwelling or apartment house arranged, designed or occupied as a place of residence by a single family. See Multifamily; (apartments). 
    Area of lot means the square-foot area of a lot within the bounding property lines and exclusive of dedicated streets or alleys. 
    Artificial lot means an area within a platted lot, for the purpose of satisfying the requirements of this chapter, that is delineated on the building site plan and the landscape plan and approved by the city planner. 
    Arts school or studio means a school for instruction and practice of the performing, visual or martial arts. 
    Banks and financial institutions means activities and institutions for the extension of credit and the custody, loan or exchange of money. 
    Bed and breakfast establishment means a private single-family residence in which lodging for one or more nights and breakfast is provided by the resident owner for compensation. 
    Billiard parlor or pool hall means a facility for the playing of billiards and pool. Food service may be allowed as an ancillary use. 
    Block means an area enclosed by streets, or if such word is used as a term of measurement, it shall mean the distance along a side of a street between two intersecting streets, or if the street is of a dead-end type, a block shall be considered to be measured between the nearest street and the end of such dead-end street. 
    Board means the board of adjustment as provided for in division 3 of article II of this chapter. 
    Boardinghouse or roominghouse means a building, other than a hotel or multiple-family dwelling, where lodging is provided for five or more persons for compensation, where meals may or may not be served and where facilities for food preparation are not provided in the individual rooms. Where meals are served, they shall be served only to the residents of the boardinghouse. 
    Building means any structure designed, built or intended for the shelter or enclosure of persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind or for an accessory use. When separated by an absolute fire separation, each portion of such structure so separated shall be deemed a separate building. This definition includes structures wholly or partly enclosed with an exterior wall. 
    Building line means a line established, in general, parallel to the front property line, over which no part of a building shall project, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
    Building and landscape materials and lumber sales (outside sales) means a facility for the sale of home, lawn and garden supplies and construction materials such as brick, lumber and other similar materials. The facility may include outside sales. 
    Cabinet and woodwork shop (custom) means a shop for the repair or creation of individual items of furniture and wooden home furnishings on a custom basis, not a factory, planing mill or similar woodworking plant. 
    Carnival or circus (temporary) means a temporary traveling show or exhibition usually housed in tents, and which has no permanent structure or installation. 
    Carwash means a facility or area for the cleaning or steam cleaning, washing, polishing or waxing of passenger vehicles by machine or hand-operated facilities. A carwash may be a single unit, multiple single washing units, or a tunnel type which can wash several vehicles in tandem. 
    Cemetery means a land use intended to be used for the burial of the dead and dedicated for cemetery purposes, including columbariums, crematories, mausoleums, and mortuaries when operated in conjunction with and within the boundaries of such cemetery. 
    Chemical and allied products includes the manufacturing of industrial inorganic and organic chemicals, plastics materials, and synthetic resins, synthetic rubber, synthetic and other manmade fibers; drugs; soap, detergents, cleaning preparations, perfumes, and other toilet preparations; paints, varnishes, lacquers, enamels, and allied products; gum and wood products; agricultural chemicals; and other chemical and allied products. 
    Church or place of worship means a facility or area for people to gather together for public worship, religious training, or other religious activities including a temple, mosque, synagogue or other structure, together with its customary accessory structures and uses, including a parsonage or rectory. This does not include home meetings or other religious activities conducted in a privately occupied residence. 
    City council means the official governing body of the City of Nacogdoches. 
    Club, private means a clubroom or suite of rooms or a building available to restricted membership for meetings, dining and entertainment. Such facilities may include a private tennis court, swimming pool or similar recreation facilities, none of which are available to the general public. 
    College or university means an institution of higher learning beyond the level of a secondary school. 
    Community center (private) means: 
(1)  A building or group of rooms designed and used as an integral part of a residential or apartment project by the tenants of such a project for a place of meeting, recreation or social activity and under the management and unified control of the operators of the project. 
(2)  A private nonprofit community center operated as a boys' or girls' club or similar use. A private community center shall not be operated as a place of public meetings, or as a business. 
    Community center (public) means a building and grounds owned and operated by a governmental body for the social, recreational, health or welfare of the surrounding community. 
    Convenience store means any retail establishment offering for sale prepackaged food products, household items, and other goods commonly associated with such and having a gross floor area of less than 7,500 square feet. 
    Convent or monastery means the living quarters or dwelling units for a religious order or for the congregation of persons under religious vows. 
    Contractor or maintenance yard means an open storage yard for supplies and operational equipment, including buildings, but not constituting a junkyard, wrecking yard or salvage yard. 
    Country club (private membership) means an area of 20 acres or more containing a golf course and a clubhouse and available only to a private specific membership. Such a club may contain as adjunct facilities a private club and dining room, swimming pool, tennis courts and similar recreation facilities. 
    Coverage means the percent of a lot area which is covered by a roof, floor or other structure and is not open to the sky. Roof eaves to the extent of two feet, and ordinary projections from the building not exceeding 12 inches, shall not be counted in computing coverage. 
    Custom sewing and millinery means custom making of items of apparel and millinery, by a seamstress, but not involving a factory. 
    Day care means a facility or area used regularly to provide daytime care, training, education, custody, treatment or supervision to more than four children, adults or elderly in other than a family setting for less than 24 hours a day, whether for compensation or not. This definition includes preschools, private kindergartens, nurseries and other similar uses not listed elsewhere in this chapter. 
    Density means as follows: 
(1)  Residential density means the relationship of dwelling units or rooms to the area of the lot or tract upon which a residential structure is located or erected, and is expressed in "units per acre." 
(2)  Nonresidential density means the ratio of the area of the building to the area of the site. See Floor area ratio (FAR). 
    Dwelling unit means a building or portion of a building which is arranged, occupied or intended to be occupied as a single living quarters and includes facilities for food preparation and sleeping. 
    Eating place with drive-in or curb service means an establishment offering food for sale to customers in automobiles and wherein the food for sale is to customers in automobiles and wherein the food service is to the automobile. 
    Eating place without drive-in or curb service means any eating establishment, cafeteria, restaurant or inn where food service is offered to the customers not in automobiles. 
    Emergency ambulance service means a facility for the operation and dispatch of emergency medical vehicles. Typically this operation is ancillary to a hospital or a fire station, but it may also be a primary use on a property. 
    Escort agency means a person or business association that furnishes, offers to furnish or advertises to furnish escorts as one of its primary business purposes for fee, tip or other consideration. 
    Fabricated metal products includes the manufacturing of ordnance and accessories; machinery, equipment and supplies; transportation equipment; and other fabricated metal products. 
    Fairground means a specific facility that hosts special indoor and outdoor events including exhibits or competitions of agricultural products, livestock, machinery, etc.; a large exhibition or show of products from various countries; an exhibition or sale of fancywork or other items for the benefit of some cause; or a gathering of buyers or sellers of some product or service. 
    Family means any number of individuals living together as a single housekeeping unit, in which not more than two individuals are unrelated by blood, marriage or adoption. 
    Family home and family group home means a community-based residential home licensed by the state department of mental health and mental retardation providing food and shelter, personal guidance, care, rehabilitation services, or supervision. Family homes shall have a maximum of six clients plus two staff members residing in a house. Family group homes shall have a minimum of seven and a maximum of 15 clients plus staff residing in a house. 
    Farm, ranch, garden or orchard means an area of three acres or more which is used for growing of usual farm products, vegetables, fruits, trees and grain for the raising thereon of the usual farm poultry and farm animals such as horses, cattle and sheep, including a private stable and also including the necessary accessory uses for raising, treating, and storing products raised on the premises, but not including the commercial feeding of offal or garbage to swine or other animals and not including any type of agriculture or husbandry specifically prohibited by city ordinance or law. 
    Farmers' market means the retail sale of farm products by individual vendors either within a building or outside. Items sold may include fruits, vegetables, herbs, spices, edible seeds, nuts, live plants, flowers and honey. The sale of new and used household goods, personal effects, tools, artwork, small household appliances and similar merchandise are not included. 
    Feed store, retail (livestock, no mill) means an establishment for the sale of grain, prepared feed and forage for pets, livestock and fowl, but not involving the grinding, mixing or commercial compounding of such items. 
    Flea market means a building or open area in which stalls or sales areas are set aside and rented, or otherwise provided, and which are intended for the sale of articles that are either homemade, homegrown, hand-crafted, old, obsolete, or antique and may include the retail selling of goods by businesses or individuals who are generally engaged in retail trade. This does not include garage sales. 
    Floor area means the total square-foot area of all floors in the building measured to the outside faces of exterior walls or to the line of an omitted wall, whichever includes the largest area.
